(a) consideration of Government Papers;
(b) General Business, Order of the Day No. 78-Income Tax Assessment (Tax Agents' Fees) Amendment Bill 1989; and
(c) General Business, Order of the Day No. 48-Regulation of Video Material Bill 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) acknowledges the important contribution which immigration has made to the economic, social and cultural development of Australia;

(b) recognises that bipartisan support for the dismantlement of the White Australia Policy and the adoption of a non-discriminatory immigration policy have been to the overwhelming national and international benefit of Australia;
(c) welcomes the support now expressed by the newly-elected Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) on 9 May 1989 for a non-discriminatory and bipartisan immigration policy; and

(d) reaffirms its unambiguous and unqualified commitment to the principle that, whatever criteria are applied by Australian Governments in exercising their sovereign right to determine the composition of the immigration intake, race or ethnic origin shall never, explicitly or implicitly, be among them.

The Government welcomes the stand taken by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in regard to Australia's immigration policy. The announcement of a return to a bipartisan immigration policy has, I believe, also been welcomed by all sectors of the Australian community. Indeed, in discussions which have taken place between the Opposition and the Government surrounding the motion I have moved, the Opposition has indicated that it intends to move an amendment to the motion. That amendment is unexceptionable to the Government, and we wholeheartedly support the principles in it. I must say that we would have preferred the nine principles which I think Senator Alston intends to move as an amendment to be attached to our motion by way of an addendum.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is by way of an amendment unfortunately-rather than an addendum.

—Yes, that is what I say. We would have preferred it to be way of addendum and not by way of amendment. In those circumstances we prefer to remain with the motion which has been moved by the Government. Nonetheless, as I said a minute ago, the return to a bipartisan approach implicit in the statements by the Leader of the Opposition and in the discussions which have taken place is welcomed by us and, we believe, by all sections of the Australian community.
—It is still a political ploy.
—It is inevitable that the Opposition will conclude that with the brilliance which one gets in interjections from Senator Hill--
—We all read that letter from Mr Hawke. I have never seen anything so hypocritical in all my life.
—Senator Hill often interjects, `This is political', which I always find surprising in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not be too fussed about this. It is not an issue which--
—I think Senator Button is terribly embarrassed about having to do this.
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—Unless the Opposition wants to change the nature of this debate, I would have thought it would save its interjections for when the Opposition had a bit of heat put on it, but it is not. Senator Boswell, of course, lowers the tone of the debate by saying, `I thought you would have been ashamed'.
—I said you were embarrassed.

—I think he ought to be embarrassed by his Leader who, of course, was the principal contributor to this whole issue. Is Senator Boswell repudiating that? I do not want to go over the detail of the ground we went over last August but there are a number of points which deserve some reiteration. Firstly, I simply make the point that a number of governments of different political persuasion held a bipartisan approach to immigration for over two decades, until the Howard-led Opposition decided last year to break with that tradition. The promised return to bipartisanship by Mr Peacock is reflected in the return to the Opposition front bench of two members of the Opposition, the honourable member for Dundas, Mr Ruddock, now the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, and the current honourable member for Goldstein, Mr Macphee, now the shadow Minister for foreign affairs-two important shadow ministries which bear very directly on this question, as Senator Hill readily acknowledges.
—This higher plane the Government is taking-it is turning into a political farce.

—I think it is very important that those things be acknowledged. Throughout the debate over the last nine months Messrs Ruddock and Macphee have stood by the convictions that they expressed in their commitment to a non-discriminatory immigration policy. That commitment was never more tested than when they-as did Senator Peter Baume in this place-crossed the floor last August to reaffirm that race should play no part in immigration policy. Mr Macphee, Mr Michael MacKellar, Mr Ruddock and others have been quite vocal on this issue. If there was ever any cause for confusion about the stance of the Australian Parliament on these issues it emanated from that very noisy disagreement within the Liberal Party and the coalition over that period.

SPEECH.PARA: Clear bipartisan commitment to a bipartisan immigration policy, along with that of the Leader of the Opposition, marks a return to the great tradition established by previous Liberal leaders and government of all political persuasions until last year. It was this bipartisanship that gave the necessary support to the Holt Government in initiating the dismantling of the so-called white Australia policy. It was this bipartisan support that contributed to the overwhelming national and international benefit of Australia. At the risk of being chastised for quoting oneself, I remind the Senate of what I said when we debated a similar motion in August last year. I said that leaders such as Holt, Gorton, McMahon and Fraser:

. . . were concerned about where this country's real interests lay. They pursued an immigration policy which took that into account. It was a triumph of reason over prejudice, of statesmanship over politics.

With this motion before us today and the amendment moved by Senator Alston-we will not support it; we would have supported it had it been moved as a addendum-we have the opportunity to put aside the deep divisions of the last nine months and to rid ourselves of that debate. Lest anybody be in any doubt about the importance of it, it was often denied in this place that anyone who travelled in South East Asia and places such as Hong Kong, southern China and Thailand during the last few months would have been fully aware of the dangers in that non-bipartisan approach in this country. It was a matter of profound concern in those countries, to their communities at large and also, particularly, to the business communities in those countries.

As the Senate knows, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wrote to the Leader of the Opposition foreshadowing today's motion and invited him to take this opportunity to put aside the debate of the past. I regret that only today we received the amendment to be moved by Senator Alston in response to that letter. The Government invites and encourages honourable senators to support this motion and re-embrace unqualified bipartisanship on Australia's immigration policy once and for all. Responding in a sense to Senator Boswell's interjection about embarrassment about this issue, there are still views on public record which are unrepudiated. For example, on 9 August last year Senator Boswell's leader in this place, Senator Stone, said:
Asian immigration has to be slowed. It is no good dancing around the bushes.
He was asked whether he stood by those comments on 11 September last year. He said:
I've never retracted these words. I would never be likely to do so.
But the will of the Opposition in this matter was expressed in a collective way through the Leader of the Opposition a few days ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly was.

—I am glad for that reassurance. The motion I have moved represents an unambiguous and unequivocal commitment to a non-discriminatory immigration policy. It is a clear statement to Australia and to the world that the white Australia policy is dead and buried, as we believed it was. It is a clear indication to Australia and to the world that Australian governments will not include explicitly or implicitly race or ethnic origin in their immigration selection criteria. It is about acknowledging the multicultural character of the Australian society, and the importance of policies which provide the basis for social cohesion in a culturally diverse society.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to be anecdotal in the course of this debate, but there is an 83-year-old pensioner who lives in my street in Melbourne. When the change in leadership took place I was amazed by what he said in a discussion with me in the street. He said to me, `I think John Howard's problems started when he talked about the immigration debate'. This old man, who has lived in that suburb all his life, said, `You can't talk that way now. It used to be common talk when I was a young man, but you can't talk like that any more. Australia belongs to the people who live in it'. I thought that was a very succinct view on this issue from somebody who has been around for a long time. It was a very enlightened view from a man of that age. That is what this motion is about. It is an opportunity for all senators to endorse a principle and a philosophy that expresses most powerfully the core of Australian values, namely, that equality can never be compromised by race, colour, belief or, least of all, country of origin. It is a unique opportunity for the Opposition, which it has accepted, and us to invite all Australians to acknowledge the significant contribution that immigrants from all parts of the world can make, have made and will continue to make to Australia. Although we may differ on the details of immigration policy, I urge, in moving this motion, that never again should we part company on the fundamental principle of racial equality in this Parliament in terms of what this Parliament stands for-the whole of the Australian community. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to speak on what is a very important subject. I note that Senator Button in moving and speaking to this motion took up less than half the time that was available to him. One can say from that fact alone that he was decidedly uncomfortable in announcing the course of action that he has just announced to the Senate. The Opposition parties welcome the opportunity to reaffirm our commitment to a non-discriminatory immigration policy which was so clearly enunciated by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) at his press conference on 9 May. Unlike our opponents who, until the 1960s, officially endorsed and supported the white Australia policy, we have a long and proud history of non-discrimination. It is no coincidence that at that press conference one of the first matters put to Mr Peacock on his ascension to the leadership was by Laurie Oakes. Mr Peacock dealt specifically with the immigration question and the very deep divisions which Mr Oakes alleged had been caused last year. Mr Peacock said:

SPEECH.PARA: You will see . . . in the policies that I elaborate a clear espousal of a non-discriminatory immigration program and in fact an espousal of bipartisanship.

One could not have a clearer or more explicit enunciation of the coalition's position at the current time. We are proud of the enlightened and compassionate immigration policies which have characterised this country since 1949 and which have seen some 4.7 million new settler arrivals. These people have made an enormous contribution to Australia, to its economic growth and progress, as well as providing a depth of cultural diversity for which Australia is much the stronger. Ethnic communities are represented at all levels of society.

It has been a great privilege for me, until recent events, to have been seated beside a fellow Western Australian, Senator John Panizza-his is a remarkable success story-who is passionately proud of his Italian heritage. I have a similar fondness for my Irish colleague on the other side of the chamber, Senator Jim McKiernan. Our immigration policy was released months ago and is supported by every member of the coalition parties. Our past record and our future intentions are there for all the world to see. So why this motion only two days after the Government got egg on its face in a big way for wasting some hours in the House of Representatives in a futile and counterproductive censure motion on the Leader of the Opposition? Everyone knows the state of the economic crisis in this country. Everyone knows that there are more than 30 Bills log-jammed in the House of Representatives which have to be dispatched by the end of next week. Yet the Government chose to waste the Parliament's time and therefore the country's time. Here we are, two days later, and the Government is at it again.

Why has this motion been moved? After all it is only nine months since both Houses of the Parliament carried a virtually identical motion. The world already knows where the Parliament of Australia stands. This latest version adds two paragraphs. One is an innocuous, motherhood bromide, which acknowledges the importance of immigration to our economic, social and cultural history. Quite clearly, it is nothing that anyone of goodwill could disagree with. So that does not take the matter any further.

The second paragraph is a grubby little effort intended to deliver an implicit backhander to John Howard, who has done so much to set our parties on track for government at the next election-and the sooner the better. The only reason that was introduced was to try somehow to create trouble and hope that somehow the media would see this not as an endorsement of Mr Peacock but as a criticism of his predecessor. So why are we presented with this motion? We are told by the whitened sepulchres on the other side that this motion is necessary in order to send a signal to the region that somehow there is still continuing apprehension and concern about Australia's immigration policies. That is hypocrisy, cant and humbug.

How does a message get to our neighbours in Asia? It gets there generally speaking in three ways: One, by headlines; two, by government action; and three, by people talking about it in the region. Look at the dishonesty and deviousness of the Government. It has endeavoured to talk up legitimate fears and differences of opinion that existed in the community last year and which manifested themselves in the political debate. That attempt to exploit divisions was clearly designed to send the maximum possible signal to Asia of differences between the political parties. It was not intended to somehow heal any rifts or to play down any difficulties.

Look at what Mr Hawke had to say. He started running around the country saying that the immigration debate had been more damaging to Australia's image and influence in Asia than any other event in recent times and that it could have cost more than $350m in lost revenue. He did not say that to the local branch of the Australian Labor Party in Wills because I suppose he hardly ever goes there these days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you believe it.

—Perhaps he should spend more time there and find out what is really going on. He spoke to that august body, the Australian Institute of International Affairs and the Asia Society-a respectable conference. There he was trying to beat up, trying to exploit political opportunities as he saw them, trying to blame the Opposition for a fall off in the business immigration program. Of course, he was doing this for some weeks. This is what he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . one of the first effects of the immigration debates was a reduction in applications from potential business migrants . . . by possibly more than 30 per cent. Such damage to the Business Migration Program could slash capital inflow from Asia into Australia from $1.1 billion to about $750 million, with the potential long-term loss much higher.

What a disgraceful display. What an unforgiveable attempt to explain away a change in economic circumstances-a fact of life that was very much in the pipeline before any so-called immigration debate. How disgraceful to dump it on the Opposition. Is that the sort of unification we are talking about? Is that the sort of social cohesion we are talking about? Is that the sort of message we want to send to Asia? No, it was a purely political attempt-dishonest in the extreme-to give the impression that the Opposition was responsible for a predicted fall-off in the business migration program. That remained almost conventional wisdom in the media until Senator Ray had the political guts in Hong Kong--

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should have stayed.

—He should have. He deserves a plaudit for this one. He blew them out of the water. He made it clear that there was not any linkage between the two, that the business migration program was falling away because of irresistible offers, by New Zealand and Canada in particular, and for financial reasons, not because people in Asia somehow believed the hypocrisy of Hawke.

SPEECH.PARA: Listen to what Senator Gareth Evans, the Foreign Minister, had to say when he decided to wander over to the United Nations (UN). He gave the UN a commitment:
. . . race will never again be used to judge migrants.
He said this in all piousness:

I bring here now on behalf of my Government the solemn undertaking, recently confirmed by both Houses of our national Parliament, that never again shall we allow race to be used as a criterion in the exercise of our sovereign right to decide who shall enter our country.
That undertaking is made not only as a reflection of deeply held principle, but also because if Australia were to do otherwise, we would deserve the censure of the world.

What Senator Evans was saying quite clearly was that at that time the Parliament of Australia had made its position abundantly clear and that he had the honour to repay that solemn undertaking to the rest of the world at the General Assembly, with its 160-plus member nations. Senator Evans was telling the rest of the world in October last year-less than six months ago-that Australia had a bipartisan approach, that the Australian Parliament supported the principles that this Government espouses.

If that is the case, what has changed since then? Nothing has changed, except in terms of symbolism. In his press conference, and in subsequent reporting, Mr Peacock made it abundantly clear-if there were any misconceptions or misunderstandings, here or in Asia-that that is no longer an issue. So why do we need this grubby little exercise? Why was the Government intent on exploiting a sensitive and delicate issue for perceived party advantage? To hell with Australia, was the attitude. What happened on 9 May? There were headlines around Australia. On 10 May, under the headline `Immigration policy to be bipartisan again', the Age said:
Moments after taking the Opposition helm, Mr Peacock signalled changes in coalition policies and a return to a bipartisan approach on immigration.
The Australian Financial Review, under the headline `Repudiation to end damaging immigration row', said:
Within hours of Mr Peacock becoming Leader of the Opposition yesterday, he indicated an end to his predecessor's `One Australia' policy-
that is not factually correct, but we are talking about the symbolism and the impression created in the moments after the change of leadership-
immediately trying to end the ideological battle that has bedevilled the party for almost a year.
Putting aside the hyperbole, one thing is crystal-clear: the Financial Review is signalling what it regards as a very important symbolic change. It mentioned also Mr Peacock's:
. . . subsequent promise that the Party will return to its previous bipartisan and non-racially based immigration policy . . .
What else is there? On page one, the Sydney Morning Herald, under the headline `Libs go back to the future', reported:

Peacock vows `fairer' nation. Mr Peacock immediately signalled an end to the controversial political debate over Asian immigration by pledging a `non-discriminatory immigration program' and `an espousal of bipartisanship.'

There it is. The whole of Australia and the rest of the world knew on 10 May that there had been a very fundamental symbolic change in the immigration policy espoused by the coalition. There was no change to the words because everyone supports the policy. The policy has been in the public arena. If the Government had bothered to read it, it could tell us whether it disagreed with it, but it clearly does not.

If this Government seriously wants to convey a message to Asia in order to enable the nations of the region to know where Australia stands and where the major political parties stand, let it distribute Australian Labor Party and coalition immigration policies to the governments of the region, to the peoples of the region, to any who might be confused and to any businessmen who might misunderstand. Let it write to all of the heads of state and point out what Mr Peacock said at his press conference on 9 May. Let it take out full page advertisements in the Straits Times or the Times of India or any other newspaper in a country of the region where there are supposedly still some people who are not aware of what happened on 9 May and what the headlines around Australia recorded on the following day.

Let the Government confirm, if it is serious, bipartisan support for the nine principles consistently reaffirmed by both sides over a period of 10 years. Yet we have had it from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) that the Government will not do that; it will not join with us to support the fundamental principles upon which immigration policy in this country is based. We are not asking the Government to support the immigration policy--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a total misrepresentation, which I am not surprised at from you.

—I suspect that what Senator Button is trying to say is that, for tactical reasons, the Government will not support the nine principles; in other words, it does not disagree with them but, for tactical reasons, it will not support them.
—We are saying that it took you 10 days to get your act together.

—Well, let us discuss how long it took to get this motion before the Senate. It has taken two weeks since Mr Peacock's press conference. If there has been this supposed outpouring of concern, misunderstanding and confusion, why did the motion not come on day one?
—You could have had it on 10 May.

—It could have been introduced into the Parliament immediately. In fact, that is what that grubby little letter from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said. It said that it would be introduced into the House of Representatives and the Senate on the first day of sitting. This is a sordid attempt to stir up trouble, to excite the media, and to convey precisely the wrong impression to the peoples of the region. I should like to look at Mr Hawke's letter because I think it is instructive. It gives an insight into the seriousness with which Mr Hawke views this very important issue. In his letter-this is sanctimoniousness at its best-he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The divisive immigration debate last year was a deeply regrettable stain on Australia's Bicentennial.
I take that as meaning that he is sorry that it spoilt the party. Those of us who had to sit through the $40m splurge very much regret that the party was not spoilt before it started. He continued:
Australia's major political parties should show national leadership on this issue.

Our nation should make it clear that this departure from bipartisan, non-discriminatory policies is behind us. How does the nation make it clear? I would think a pretty good way of doing it is for the leaders of both political parties to make it clear. Presumably, Mr Hawke is not saying one thing and doing another. He is professing--

TALK.START.PARA: —John Howard made it clear and half of you didn't agree with him. What are you talking about? What's the problem?
—Let us get the chronology right.
—Where were you during the war?

—I was in Perth being born. The chronology is that Mr Hawke supposedly had a consistent view of bipartisanship and non-discrimination. I will come later to the cant and hypocrisy in the current position. The fact of the matter is that, in recent times, Mr Hawke has been parading himself around the world as the arch apostle of non-discrimination. What he is saying is, `We are okay, but what about you mob? You have to make your position clear'. Mr Hawke wrote his letter on 17 May, a week after Mr Peacock had made our position abundantly clear. What more do those opposite want? They are not going to tell me that Hawke did not bother reading the transcript of that press conference, because he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have noted the statement in your press conference of 9 May that the policies which you elaborate will clearly espouse a non-discriminatory immigration program and bipartisanship on this issue.
He knows fundamentally what Mr Peacock has said. He knows absolutely where the Opposition stands. Why does he come up with this tawdry and shabby little exercise? He also said:
I look forward to the opposition's agreement to the Resolution, the passing of which will mark the resumption of bipartisanship . . .

What is he on about? We know what he is on about. He is trying to stir up trouble. He is not interested in the welfare of the nation or conveying messages to Asia. Those messages are already there. There was not a problem until he started playing around with fire in this manner. It is tragic that politics can be used in this way on such an issue as this.

The reason why this matter comes forward at all is that the hard men triumphed over the wise men. There is a wise man sitting on the other side of the chamber. I am sure he was very concerned, as a strategist, about the potential for this exercise to backfire. I would probably put Senator McMullan into the same category. He has been around for a while; he knows what politics is about. He knows that the media can turn on you: that is, people get away with a trick once; the second time around it can blow up in their faces. Wise men would have counselled caution. They know that this is a very dangerous strategy, too clever by half.

But no, the wise men were outgunned. It was the hard men like Senator Schacht and Senator Richardson who called the tune. They wanted to distract attention from the economic crisis. They are not particularly interested that we have got a current account deficit heading for $17 billion, interest rates that are 5 percentage points higher than they were 12 months ago, a gross foreign debt approaching $120 billion or that we need a $58 a week tax decrease to get back to where we were in real terms in 1983. They are not interested in any of those things; they just want to take attention away from the economic crisis. This was thought to be the way to do it. The hard men thought they saw a window of opportunity. The lesson is that before one leaps through an open window one has to make sure it is on ground level. This is going to blow up in their faces. They will jump and find they land in a mess of their own making. It is totally unnecessary to bring this forward.

Instead of trying to create factions and divisions on our side of politics perhaps they should look at their own factional problems. After all, we could say, `Politician heal thyself'. It is a pity Senator Cook is not here to tell us about the inevitable disintegration of the Centre Left. Clearly that is falling to pieces. Maybe those people should establish a resurrected Party secretaries club. I am sure they would be pleased to have Senator Ray as a honorary member. That is about the largest profession represented on the other side of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was I a Party secretary?

—I am saying they could make Senator Ray an honorary member. There are five of them here. If they brought Senator Ray in they might get a bit of common sense. They could let Senator Cook in as an observer. If they put an L-plate on him he might pick up a few tricks. He could get rid of his own faction, which is dumping on him. He might learn a bit about sensible politics. I am sure he would get advice from Senator Ray not to go ahead with a half-baked motion such as this. That is why I will be formally moving the amendment which sets out the nine principles upon which both parties have consistently agreed over a period of 10 years, from the time that the Fraser Government initiated a Green Paper in 1976, followed by the tabling of that Green Paper in Parliament in March 1977 and a statement to the Parliament by Mr MacKellar, the then Minister. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we clearly state that basis on which our immigration policies will operate.
He said that in 1978. Since that time the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), in 1981, has said:
The nine principles of our immigration policy-including the important global non-discriminatory nature of our programs-remain unaltered.
On the other side, the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr West, in May 1983-in other words, shortly after coming to government-said on this very important issue:
The Government has reaffirmed the nine principles underlying migration policy.
Then there was another entrant through the revolving door. Mr Hurford, the then Minister, said the same thing:

In summary, my colleague the Minister for Housing and Construction has been responsible for Cabinet endorsement of a statement of nine principles of immigration. Frankly, those principles are more or less the same principles of the previous Fraser Administration.

That was in 1986. Consistently, this Government has endorsed and espoused those nine principles. They have been slightly modified for the purpose of the migration booklet but they are fundamentally in place.

If we are interested in genuinely sending a message to Asia, let us not play games, let us not try to demean the former Leader of the Opposition. Let us not try to find problems that do not exist on our side of politics. Let us both agree that immigration is too important an issue to be trivialised in this way. Let us agree that the nine principles represent matters of fundamental concern that go the heart of a non-discriminatory and bipartisan policy-in the sense that that term seems to be loosely used at the present time. Of course we reserve the right to be critical of administrative shortcomings and of various other policy settings that we believe are in need of change.
It is a great pity in many ways that the Government has not addressed in more positive terms the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. Dr FitzGerald said:

Problems with current immigration policies are not limited to the numbers. Widespread mistrust and failing consensus threaten community support of immigration. The program is not identified in the public mind with the national interest, and must be given a convincing rationale.

So Dr FitzGerald has made it very clear that there are matters of real concern that need to be addressed. We welcome any constructive attempts to do just that. What we do not welcome are cynical attempts to exploit divisions in the community, to beat up issues where there are no problems, to decide somehow, after two weeks of agonising, that this might be one way in which some problems can be caused on the other side of the chamber. If the Government is fair dinkum, it will support the principles. Is the Government in all seriousness, going to oppose those principles simply because we will not let them be tacked onto a resolution which is flawed in the sense that it adds motherhood-which adds nothing-which contains implicit criticism of Mr Howard but otherwise reiterates all that took place in both Houses of Parliament nine months ago? What is the need for repetition? What has changed?

The Government has a message from the Parliament of Australia. Senator Evans has gone to the General Assembly and told the world about it. It is on the record. If the Government thinks there are misconceptions, it should be telling the world what has happened over the last two weeks. The Government should tell the people of the world what Mr Peacock said. It should tell them about the symbolism implicit in putting Mr Ruddock in as shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs when he crossed the floor nine months ago. It should give them all of those messages. It should let them know if there are problems. It should let them know that the Opposition's policy is clearly one of non-discrimination and bipartisanship. That is the way to do it. The Government does not have to waste the time of this Parliament with all sorts of trivial tactical exercises.

The Government knows full well the critical necessity to ensure that racial tension is not exacerbated and to do nothing to stir up prejudice and enmity. If the Government is looking for division on this side, it is saying that it hopes that there will be some decent headlines out of this in the interests, of course, of creating political capital. Does the Government want to get a message to the people of Asia that there are still problems in Australia? Does the Government want them to be told that there are differences of opinion between the political parties? If that is not what the Government wants, why does it not tell them what Mr Peacock said? Why does it not send them copies of our policy? Why does it not let them know what Mr Ruddock has been saying in the last two weeks? Why does it not explain to them where we stand? Why does the Government not talk to people on this side of the chamber about their attitudes? Why does it not convey those messages to Asia? Why recycle something that has been through the Parliament and is dead and buried? We know why: Mr Hawke and the hard men think there is a bit of mileage in it. That is a tragedy for Australia. The national interest demands that the Government not seek to divide for naked opportunism and cheap political gain.

I do not blame Senator Ray for this squalid exercise. His remarks in Hong Kong were courageous. I am sure that he has had no part in wanting to put this motion on the agenda. That is probably why it has taken two weeks to get to the barrier. The Prime Minister's letter says it all. It bears all the hallmarks of a mean-minded political opportunist who is prepared to sacrifice the national interest for 30 pieces of electoral currency. The people of South East Asia do not need reassurances. There are deliberate and unmistakable symbolisms already in place.

Senator Button quite correctly pointed to statements made by four Liberal Prime Ministers over the last 25 or 30 years, statements about which all Australians can hold their heads high. It is a pity that the same cannot be said of the other two Prime Ministers, Labor Prime Ministers, this country has had in that period. When Mr Hawke was the shadow Minister for employment, industrial relations and youth affairs, he pandered to genuine fears about job security, playing to his constituency. He said that it was absurd, when we had young people unemployed, to be bringing people from overseas to fill alleged or actual shortages. How disgraceful. What is different about the situation now? Unemployment is much higher. Youth unemployment is much higher. Yet the immigration intake is higher. What hypocrisy. What double standards.
The other Labor Prime Minister we had in that period was Mr Whitlam. What did he say in 1977? He said:
Any genuine refugee should be accepted but the Government has a responsibility to ensure they are genuine refugees.
If there is not symbolism in that I will go home. Again he was clearly pandering to a political constituency.

TALK.START.PARA: —Asian Balts, he called them.
—Vietnamese Balts. He was terrified that somehow they might come out here and vote Liberal, I suppose. What callousness! What a lack of compassion! What prejudice! What hypocrisy!
—What rhetoric!
—Mr Hawke said in 1977 that if refugees arrived without government approval `they should be sent back'. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Any sovereign country has the right to determine how it will exercise its compassion and how it will increase its population.

In other words, he was playing politics to the hilt. He was not interested in whether people needed to come here, whether they were dying, whether they had a well-founded fear of persecution. He was thinking, `There are a few votes out there in people who think that every immigrant is a threat to their job security'. We know that is not right. The Government has read Dr Norman's reports for the Committee for Economic Development of Australia and all the economic assessments that show that people who come into this country under the Government's program are not taking the jobs of Australians. The Government would not let them do it. Yet Government members go around and beat up this sort of fear and apprehension.

The most unfortunate aspect of this whole debate is that we have a Prime Minister whose track record is fundamentally flawed, who is guilty of double standards in the extreme and who is now trying to create yet more political divisions. Our side of politics has a clear, consistent and honourable record on the issue. The Leader of the Opposition has made our position known to the world. There can be no argument that we have a non-discriminatory and bipartisan approach as enunciated in the nine principles. Yet, for tactical reasons, the Government is not prepared to support the nine principles. It wants to recycle a motion from nine months ago. It hopes that somehow it can find a few people who are nervous, that somehow it will get a headline that will rebound to its credit. But it will not. The press will see it in the same way as it saw that pathetic little performance in the House of Representatives the other day-as a complete and utter waste of time. Let me quote the West Australian of today:
The Federal Government should drop the idea of launching a motion in Parliament against any racial discrimination in immigration policy.
Despite Labor denials, the move has all the hallmarks of a cynical attempt to exploit divisions in Liberal Party ranks . . .
It runs the risk of stirring up extremists . . . The Government will have a lot to answer for . . . The matter should be allowed to rest there.
I move:
Leave out all words after ``That'', insert:
``the Senate reaffirms the nine bipartisan principles of Australian immigration endorsed by successive Governments, namely:
Principle number 1

It is fundamental to national sovereignty that the Australian Government alone should determine who will be admitted to Australia. No person other than an Australian citizen, has a basic right to enter Australia.
Principle number 2

Apart from people admitted as refugees and for family reunion, migrant entry criteria should be developed on the basis of benefit to the Australian community, and the social, economic and related requirements within Australia. As a general rule, Australia will not admit for settlement people who would represent an economic burden to Australia through inordinate claims on welfare, health or other resources; who would endanger the community by criminal or other anti-social activities; or whose entry would be to their own detriment.
Principle number 3
The size and composition of migrant intakes should not jeopardise social cohesiveness and harmony within the Australian community.
Principle number 4

Immigration policy should be applied on a basis which is non-discriminatory. There are external restraints on the extent to which Australia can apply a non-discriminatory policy. Some countries will not allow their nationals to emigrate; other countries allow only those with exit permits to leave; some countries will not permit the emigration of skilled and professional workers. Some countries will not allow advertising for migration purposes; others will not allow immigration offices to be established within their territories, or allow immigration officers to operate within their territories. In addition, there are varying degrees of interest in migration to Australia in particular areas. The principle of non-discrimination means that the policy will be applied consistently to all applicants regardless of their race, colour, nationality, descent, national or ethnic origin, sex or religion.
Principle number 5

Applicants should be considered for migration as individuals or individual family units, not as community groups. An exception will be refugees in designated refugee situations, although even in such circumstances the criteria for selection will be related to the characteristics of individual applicants.
Principle number 6

Eligibility and suitability standards for migrants should reflect Australian social mores and Australian laws. Polygamous unions will not be accepted, nor the entry of child fiances. The concept of immediate family, for eligibility purposes, will be derived from the Australian norm, ie. the unit consisting of husband, wife and minor unmarried children.
Principle number 7

Migration to Australia should be for permanent settlement although there should be no barrier preventing the departure of persons wishing to leave. The guest-worker migration flow, until recently popular in the industrialised countries of Western Europe, will not be adopted for Australia.
Principle number 8

While migrants will have the same rights as other Australian residents to choose their place of residence individually or collectively, enclave settlement will not be encouraged. Immigration policy will not consider communities for mass movement to Australia in situations where closed enclave settlement would occur.
Principle number 9

Policies governing entry and settlement should be based on the premise that migrants should integrate into Australian society. Migrants will be given every opportunity, consistent with this premise, to preserve and disseminate their ethnic heritage''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sitting on the cross benches, and having heard the contributions to the debate on this motion by Senator Button and Senator Alston, I find it difficult to believe that they both spoke to the same motion. A similar motion came up for debate in this place in August last year. That debate was brought on as a direct result of the unfortunate statements made by the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong, Mr Howard, and other members of the coalition. I said at that time that it was shameful that it was felt necessary to debate within this chamber and this Parliament a motion that Australia should have a non-discriminatory immigration policy. We have now had that policy for some years. I must say that Senator Alston's words have reassured us all that we are now in for a bipartisan, non-discriminatory immigration policy which will be totally unambiguous. I am not quite sure about the meaning of the word `bipartisan'. Does it mean the Government and the Opposition or does it mean government and non-government? Perhaps the word should be tripartisan or multipartisan. Anyway, let us hope that this debate will set the record straight.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's four-clause motion is unambiguous and straightforward; it is, to a certain extent, motherhood. Notice of motion was given by Senator Button on Tuesday. Immediately after I heard that notice given in this place, I telephoned Senator Button's office and received a fax about the motion. The Australian Democrats support the motion as it stands. The Opposition's amendment to that motion, the nine principles, was put into my hand about 40 minutes ago. I have certainly read through them. They are the principles on which present regulations and migration policies are based. However, as I have not been able to discuss these principles with my colleagues at this time, it is very difficult for the Democrats to support them. There are other reasons why they are difficult for us to support. I believe that they would cloud the motion. That would be a great shame. If there is to be any point in this debate at all, it is that the Senate will pass a straightforward, unambiguous motion that Australia continues to have a non-discriminatory immigration policy. Having taken the opportunity to reread these principles, I feel that they may need some updating. As Senator Alston said, they have been around for some time. It may well be that they should be updated in some way, as they have been abused in the past.
Let me look at the principles before turning to the detail of the four clauses of the Government's motion. The second principle in part reads:

Apart from people admitted as refugees and for family reunion, migrant entry criteria should be developed on the basis of benefit to the Australian community, and the social, economic and related requirements within Australia.

That economic benefit clause, which also stands in the first clause of the Government's motion, has been abused in the past. I have only to think of the situation in Wittenoom in Western Australia when during the period of vast immigration immediately after the Second World War a number of Italian migrants-there were migrants from other countries as well but they were predominantly Italian migrants-were taken to work in the Wittenoom asbestos mines. They did not know that they were going to work in mines for the most part; they thought they were going to work on the land. When they got there they were very unhappy about it. I have in my possession certified translations of letters that they wrote to the Italian Consulate in their distress, saying that they did not want to be there; they felt that it was unhealthy. Yet they had no option: they had to stay there and work to pay back their fares. That was of economic benefit to Australia at the time, but now that vast sums of compensation are being paid out at the expense of current taxpayers, that may need some review. I put it to the Senate that if we are going to regard our migrant population as economic units for us to exploit, these people will come to exploit us, and we will indeed deserve that.

Looking at the size and composition of our migrant intake, the Government is suggesting a floating points system. I have discussed that proposal with people who would be directly involved and those not directly involved but concerned about the principle. That would leave itself wide open to abuse. I can think of no other situation and no other system where people can apply on one day when there is one rule and be judged on another day when the rule is completely different.

I turn to principle No. 7, that `migration to Australia should be for permanent settlement although there should be no barrier preventing the departure of persons wishing to leave'. Of course there should be no barrier. However, if we care to look at the breakdown of the figures of people who do leave Australia each year-I do not have those figures to hand but they are quite substantial, in the region of 20,000 to 30,000 permanent departures-we see that there is an extraordinarily high number of people in the professional and high skills categories. That should give us some cause for concern, and maybe that is something that should be looked into.
Paragraph (a) of the Government's motion states that the Senate:
acknowledges the important contribution which immigration has made to the economic, social and cultural development of Australia;

We all know the history of migration in Australia, and no-one can deny that history. We did indeed have a policy of populate or perish immediately after the Second World War. We currently have various categories of migration. I think we need to consider very carefully whether the people we bring in in the categories for skills and business migration are going to make a good contribution to the economic, social and cultural development of Australia, or whether in some cases we are bringing in people who want to make that sort of improvement for themselves and then shift out, even to their countries of origin.

Thank goodness we saw the end of the white Australia policy many years ago. During the white Australia policy period the key words were `assimilation and integration', which all too often meant a denial of origin. Now we live in a more humanitarian era where the key words are `multicultural and democratic pluralism'. I believe that is more in keeping with the Australian fair go for all attitude and in essence will produce the desired one Australia. I read in a recent article that if Australia cannot get it right with its multicultural society, then God help the rest of the world because here we do have a microcosm of the whole world. More than ever before we have no option other than to get it right and learn to live well together.
The second paragraph of the Government's motion states that the Senate:

recognises that bipartisan support for the dismantlement of the White Australia Policy and the adoption of a non-discriminatory immigration policy have been to the overwhelming national and international benefit of Australia;

There can be no doubt about that. The dismantling of that most iniquitous policy has given us international status and an internal national status too. That policy was of course born of a primitive fear and ignorant bigotry, and the present non-discriminatory policy is in keeping with international codes to which we subscribe. In Western Australia over the years there have been very nasty, vicious racist campaigns, with people predominantly using posters, which they stick up all over the place. The main protagonist of this campaign, who blatantly exposes himself as a member of the National Socialist Party, was a few weeks ago publicly discredited. It was revealed that this man, who is mostly against Asian people, in fact has some Asian blood in him. His own father was born overseas and is part Asian. That might help to explain things. We know that this is often the case with other tyrants of the world who have been racist.
The third paragraph of the Government's motion states that the Senate:
welcomes the support now publicly expressed by the newly-elected Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) on 9 May 1989 for a non-discriminatory and bipartisan immigration policy;

I feel that in the circumstances that is fair. I am aware that the Government did offer to withdraw that paragraph in return for an adaptation of the Opposition's amendment, and that offer was not taken up. In the circumstances I think it is fair that that clause should be in. We know that the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) did not vote when the motion was debated last year in the House of Representatives. As I said at the start of my speech, at least it will now lay it firmly on the line. We know that we do have a large number of illegal migrants presently in Australia. In no way can anyone condone deliberate illegal migration, because there are people who do the right thing, who stand in line and wait their turn to be processed overseas in the right way. In no way should favouritism be shown to people who deliberately seek to come in as illegal migrants. However, many of our illegal migrants have been here for a generation or so, and possibly have families and are grandparents themselves. I would like to flag right now that the proposed immigration amendment legislation to be brought in by the Government, which can cause mandatory deportations, could put the situation of many of those people in jeopardy. They could even be related to members of the Senate through intermarriage down through the generations. I think that is something that needs to be looked at very carefully.

A lot of tightening up needs to be done in the area of illegal migration. Surveillance of the northern parts of the coast of Western Australia is absolutely pathetic. The illegal migrants who get picked up I believe are in the minority. Also no follow-up is done on overseas students who come to Australia to attend courses. There is very little checking on whether they actually attend any classes, and when it is found that they have disappeared into the blue, all the information is very much out of date. Likewise, I believe our checking up processes on people who come in under the business migration category, or even as tourists, are not tight enough. While I am on this issue, I flag here that the overseas embassies, consulates and offices which deal with migration are very often understaffed. The staff are not properly trained and many people when first applying to migrate are not given the right sort of counselling and assistance.
The final paragraph of the Government's motion states that the Senate:

reaffirms its unambiguous and unqualified commitment to the principle that, whatever criteria are applied by Australian Governments in exercising their sovereign right to determine the composition of the immigration intake, race or ethnic origin shall never, explicitly or implicitly, be among them.
That was clearly spelt out and reiterated when the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies brought down its report last year. The reference given to that Committee stated:
In carrying out its work, the Committee should:
have regard to the principles that Australia's immigration policies are non-discriminatory in respect of national or ethnic origin, race, sex and religion . . .
That final paragraph is, of course, the crux of the whole matter.

I would like briefly to mention citizenship, because this is also something that frequently comes up in debates on immigration. This is the Year of the Citizen. Many of the people who came out to Australia from the United Kingdom during the days of vast migration in the 1940s and 1950s came under the child migration scheme. These people are now adults and some have no birth certificates. They have no natural rights as citizens of this country unless they apply for citizenship. They would be denied the privilege of becoming members of parliament should they be so elected. Yet when they apply now for citizenship, they are told they have to go through the same motions as everybody else. Some may not, in those circumstances, be able to go back to their original country and may not even know who their parents are. These are people who were orphans when they came out, or who have been deserted by their parents, or whose parents thought that they would have a better life in Australia than in the United Kingdom, and so they were sent out as part of the child migration scheme. I would like to place on record that in the Year of the Citizen these people should be granted citizenship as a special criterion. The Democrats support the Government's motion. It is unfortunate in some respects that it needs to be debated again. If this motion has the unanimous support of this chamber at least the record is straight and we can let the matter drop. Then the whole world and the whole of Australia can know that the Parliament and the Government of Australia are totally committed to a non-discriminatory immigration policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank honourable senators for their contribution to this debate which, by and large, has been of an even standard and relatively without difficulty. I want to reiterate the Government's position on the amendment which was given to us by the Opposition this morning, some 10 days after the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wrote to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) indicating the Government's intention to bring this matter before both Houses of Parliament. The Opposition's amendment seeks to delete everything in the Government's motion and replace it with nine principles. We intend to vote for the Government's motion. We do that on the basis that we believe at this time that it is a right statement for the Government to make on these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Opposition were to move its amendment as an addendum to the Government's motion we would accept it. We accept the nine principles; we support them. But to delete everything in the Government's motion and replace it with the nine principles is not acceptable to the Government. I want to indicate that position formally and place it on the record. I commend the motion to the Senate.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
