SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday as I was finishing my speech I was calling for the establishment of an endangered species unit which could be had at a relatively small cost to the Government but which has not yet come to pass. It is one of the promised things we are still waiting for. With regard to soil degradation, it was disturbing to read the comments of Dr David Smiles, head of the Soils Division of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), on the Federal Government's announcement of a $45m grant for soil conservation. Dr Smiles and other CSIRO scientists who have been in touch with my office claim that the 30 per cent decline in funding over the last six years has had a devastating effect on programs, staffing and effectiveness in addressing the ongoing problem of soil and productivity loss.

SPEECH.PARA: Many rangeland field programs have been abandoned altogether. The cost of these short term budgetary savings are only being deferred to a later date when the bill will be even larger than the current $600m per year estimated by Senator Cook. Other field programs desperately in need of funding include those addressing the infestation of feral animals and plants across Australia. From the assault of cane toads and foxes to the spread of mimosa and woody weeds, we are only deferring the cost of feral animal and weed eradication until whole ecosystems collapse from the strain. It is a classic case of blinkered, short term thinking to make the figures look a little better now, and an attitude of `hang the consequences for the future' when future governments will have to pick up a much larger repair bill.

It is the environment which is the ultimate loser-that includes us, the human species. People make an enormous and drastic impact on the environment. If the environment is devastated beyond repair, ultimately we will be the ones to suffer. It is time we realised our fundamental connection to the land, to the entire ecosystem of our planet. We must see the earth as our source of life and realise that it is in need of urgent nurturing. Sustainability should be the key, as Senator Coulter was trying to point out in his speech yesterday, instead of what we have at the moment which is continued degradation of our environment.

I want to say a few words in defence of grants to voluntary conservation groups. It must be said that some of the best and cheapest environmental research and monitoring is carried out by unpaid volunteers in the community. National Estate program grants contribute to the knowledge base of the Australian Heritage Commission, and other grants enable citizens to participate in environmental assessments and community education. The quality of community input and, ultimately, government decisions increases with the resources allocated to grants to voluntary conservation groups.

Particular bouquets could be given to many of these community groups which make valuable contributions. There could also be a string of requests for future funding. One request that I would like to support is that of Greening Australia for its national afforestation program for which it is seeking a $15m grant. It would indeed be money well spent. Nobody could argue with that in these days of greenhouse awareness. It is just one of many effective programs coordinated by Greening Australia including the Murray-Darling basin project, land care groups, rainforest species trials, a tree database, a schools nursery scheme and the conservation of remnant vegetation. I believe that all of them, especially the national afforestation program, are deserving of government support-and that is, of course, taxpayers' support.

Another area of gross disparity in Budget allocation in Australia over the last 10 years has been the proportion of our gross national product (GNP) allocated to the military and the proportion allocated to overseas aid. In terms of military expenditure there has been a slight drop in the proportion of GNP, but the massive drop in overseas aid expenditure from 0.49 per cent of GNP in 1983 to 0.34 per cent in the last financial year has now taken us below the average for development assistance committee member countries of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. Indeed, we now rank with the meanies like the United Kingdom, the United States of America and Switzerland, while the Scandinavian countries and the Netherlands give twice as much as we give in terms of percentage of GNP.

Two issues are at stake. The first question is how seriously are we prepared to try to eradicate poverty in a world where the rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer on a much greater scale than is happening even here in Australia. The second question is how we view the best investment we can make for Australia's future security. In other words, do we invest in more expensive military equipment, or do we invest in the economic security of our neighbours? I would like to suggest that we take seriously the proposal that Australia increases aid to 0.4 per cent of GNP this year en route to reaching the target of 0.5 per cent by 1992 as recommended by the recent report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau and the Australian aid program. That figure has also been mentioned as a target by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans).

I would also like to reiterate the point made by the World Commission on Environment and Development which recognised a clear link between environmental destruction and poverty. They are one and the same problem. If we are concerned about the world environment we must do something about eliminating poverty, debt reduction and bringing about fair trade. Economic and environmental issues are greater threats to our security than our military ones. Increasingly the world's people are realising this. We must address those real threats now. That is why I chose to contrast the relative rise in military expenditure with the slashing of the aid budget. There are those who say that we cannot afford it, but I suggest that we cannot afford not to increase our aid budget. The very future of the planet and its people is at stake.

In convincing the Australian people that we should be increasing the aid budget, it is crucial to make the point that aid is not a one-way street. It is of mutual benefit to all involved. Close to 80 per cent of what we spend in aid comes back to this country anyway. As our neighbours become more prosperous they want to increase foreign trade. We have already seen the result of the increasing prosperity of some of our Asian neighbours who now want to buy our agricultural produce, visit Australia as tourists, or utilise some of our other skills and services, such as education. There is much talk around Australia about our economic difficulties as there was earlier in this debate and, in such a climate, I recognise the difficulty of getting people to understand how much worse it is in much of Africa and Latin America. Real incomes here have fallen 10 per cent to 25 per cent during the 1980s. In the 37 poorest countries spending on health per capita halved and on education it was cut by 25 per cent in the same period. In half of the developing countries, primary school attendance is actually falling because students cannot afford to go to school and in many cases governments are not putting the necessary facilities in place for them. These figures come from the 1989 United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF) report on the state of the world's children.

In Australia we complain about the trade imbalance with the United States just as the Americans complain about their trade relationship with Japan, yet this is nothing when we consider that overall money is flowing out of the poor countries to the rich ones to the tune of about $68 billion a year. Australia has seriously cut funds to UNICEF and to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities since the early 1980s. I believe that we should announce our intention to rejoin the International Fund for Agricultural Development, and I hope that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade will soon make an announcement to this effect.

It is worth recalling that throughout the 1960s and 1970s Australia was one of the most generous aid donors. Since then, our international standing, particularly our standing with developing country neighbours in the Asia-Pacific region, has been severely undermined by the harsh cuts in overseas aid since the Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government came to office. It is also worth remembering that this same Government was elected in 1983 with a platform commitment to achieve 0.7 per cent of GNP to be allocated to overseas aid within five years of being elected. At the 1988 ALP National Conference, following commitments made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the level of GNP allocated to aid would not drop any further, this commitment was written into the ALP platform as follows:
33. Eliminating the disparities between rich and poor is one of the major challenges of our time. Labor accepts this challenge as an urgent priority.
Accordingly, Labor will-

34. Maintain its commitment to achieve the UN target for official development assistance (ODA) of 0.7% of Gross National Product . . . Labor will seek to ensure that the ODA as a percentage of GNP does not fall below the present level and will seek to provide real and definite increases as budgetary circumstances permit.

`As budgetary circumstances permit' is the opting out clause. Finally, on this point I think it is worth quoting the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade which I referred to earlier. It states:
Australia's continued commitment to achieve the 0.7 per cent target is in real danger of becoming purely rhetorical.

I deliberately do not advocate spending more money on aid at a time when so many other items of government expenditure are being cut. I am not advocating that alone. That is why I continue to advocate, for example, that one per cent of defence expenditure be transferred to the overseas aid budget as an initial contribution to real security in the region. Obviously, much more could be transferred but I suggest that this one per cent transfer is a realistic goal to start with.

Of course it will not be easy but I think that this reallocation would be enthusiastically received by a large proportion of thinking Australians, who understand that we can build security much more effectively this way than by following the more traditional military path. Militarisation is increasingly being seen as a gross injustice to the poverty stricken and oppressed masses. Maybe it is hard for some Australians even to conceptualise the problems suffered by the majority of the world's people because of our relatively privileged position on the world stage. Militarisation is a gross violation of human rights. Increasingly, it is being seen as outmoded and counterproductive in terms of international relations and an immoral waste of human and financial resources. Australia, as a relatively unthreatened nation, with no natural enemies, could be a model for a move away from the extreme negativism of a military notion of national security to a more positive approach based on a better sharing of the world's resources.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on these appropriation and supply Bills with a certain amount of relish. I do so because of the cavalier fashion in which the Government responded to the urgency motion moved yesterday to the effect that we ought to do something about improving our overseas competitiveness. It really is most urgent that we do something about that matter. The economy has been drifting for some years now, despite the protestations of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Opposition. The Minister for Finance was reduced to a case of extremism to the point of offering his resignation because the Government would not listen to the kind of advice that he was giving it. After witnessing Senator Button's giggling gibberish in his reply yesterday, Senator Maguire garbling his usual socialist platitudes, Senator Aulich presenting, in his most plausible and reasonable way, a whole lot of soft soap and snake oil as if he expected us to believe what he was saying-it was almost as if he believed what he was saying himself-I am constrained to reply in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Six Bills are now being debated cognately-three appropriation Bills and three supply Bills. They are designed to provide money for the ordinary services of Government between July and November at which time the Budget 1989-90 Bills will come into effect. At the moment, Australia is faced with a dangerous situation. The high level of foreign debt that we must service means that the interest component is mounting year by year. It will be passed on to our children, our heirs and assigns, forever and ever; and the cost is mounting. It cannot be serviced-not readily, at any rate. Australia's high foreign debt represents the savings of other people. But, as was mentioned in the debate yesterday, Australia's living standards, simply because of that debt, are declining. The way matters are organised at the moment means that our future is insecure. Our current account deficit is over $14 billion for the year-

TALK.START.PARA: —That was for 10 months.

—For the first 10 months of the current financial year. It was forecast at $9 billion for the whole year. It is $14 billion for the first 10 months, so it will probably wind up around $17 billion for the year. If we continue the way that we are going, next year it will reach $25 billion-$2 billion a month. It is hard even to conceive that the country could be involved with figures such as those. To fix the problem, we must borrow more, earn more or sell some assets such as land. Unease is being felt as a result of sales of land and increasing foreign ownership. Not only Japan but also other countries are buying up Australian land. And why not? When Australian assets can be picked up at bargain basement prices and the value of their currency is high while the value of our dollar is low, why should they not do that? Our net foreign debt is already around $100 billion. When Mr Hawke took over it was about $23 billion-a manageable amount. In that short space of a few years, it has quadrupled to $100 billion. It is being nudged along of course by these successive monthly deficits which, by the looks of it, are gradually increasing and also by the fall in the Australian dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: Our consumer price index is moving up. At the moment, it is nearly 7 per cent-and we can safely say-and mounting. Interest rates are high. They are currently at 16 per cent and even 19 per cent in some areas. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) says he will not hesitate to use interest rates as a weapon if he thinks fit. The Government, despite its protestations, has not cut its spending. We had the usual charade of the Premiers Conference and the Loan Council meetings last week. There were some savage cuts to States' spending and their ability to borrow but the Federal Government has not cut its own expenditure at all although it says it has done that.

The famous accord between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions is a failure. They claim that it is not but one has only to look at the figures to see that productivity has not increased. Therefore, real wages have not been provided for and our living standards are down. Our international competitiveness is down. After all, we are an exporting nation and international competitiveness is important to us. Our dollar has fallen in value and our credit rating is down. In other words, all the lights are flashing either yellow or red on our economic indicator board but the Government, up until now, has not taken any notice of it.

I notice that the Treasurer is now starting to show signs of insecurity. Certainly Senator Button and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) are showing signs of insecurity. And it is about time because we have been warning them for a long time. They have thrown the argument back to us and said, `What would you do in circumstances such as this?'. From this side, I have heard the argument put many times as to what we would do. I have not heard the Government mention opening up the mining industry. The Government's policy on mining is abysmal for Australia. If the Government changed its mining policy, this area, on its own, could almost pay off our debt within a few years.

The Government talks of micro-economic reform in waterfront, coastal shipping, transport and communications. In the sugar industry, the Government has pulled the plug on the interstate sugar agreement and is removing the embargo against imports of sugar. This is all very well. The sugar industry will adapt to this but the Government did not do its homework on this matter. It had to be referred to a Senate committee of inquiry, which came out with a reasonable arrangement for removal of the sugar embargo. But the Committee did not pay attention to the cost of transporting sugar round our coast. The cost of shipping and handling is enormous, and it has been shown that proper reform in that area would save the Government approximately $2 billion-just that one measure. But that has not been done, and I can confidently predict that, if the arrangements stay as they are, it will be a lot cheaper to import sugar from surrounding sugar-producing countries than to take it round our own coast from our own production areas. That is a sorry state of affairs. We have seen a similar situation in relation to the wheat legislation. The Government has deregulated one end of the system, the wheat growers, but not the other end, transport and handling. In those areas we could save an enormous amount of money and make ourselves more competitive.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating), in introducing his last Budget, predicated the whole strategy on high commodity prices. He punted on his luck, and he was reasonably lucky, but he cannot go on being lucky forever. It now looks as though commodity prices are going to drop. That will derail the Treasurer's whole Budget strategy. He has refused to change it up until now, but it looks as if the Government is coming to its senses-at least, I hope so-and is going to do something about it.

I want to deal now with a matter that is causing some public comment-health. I do not think that there is one area of the whole health industry that is happy with the way it is being run by the Government at the moment-from the pharmacists to the pathologists, the radiologists, the general practitioners, the Australian Medical Association, all the doctors and health-care providers and the nursing fraternity, plus the hospitals, nursing homes and hostels. If one were to go to any area of health administration in Australia today one would find the people there unhappy. They are unhappy because of Medicare. Medicare is the fundamental and basic cause of the whole problem. It is not as if the Government has not been warned about this for many years. I have warned it myself. However, I do not intend to go over the whole argument. I am getting sick and tired of saying these things to the Government.

Let me turn to the way in which the Government handles legislation that it brings into the House of Representatives. The health Bills are a very good example, but not the only one. The Government brings legislation in subject to the guillotine. It allows only a limited time for debate-maybe one or two speakers on major legislation that is going to have far-reaching effects on many aspects of health. After limited debate the Bills are put to the vote. They do not even get to the committee stage. Any amendments that the Opposition may have are not even discussed; they just have to be tabled. This is a very sour way to deal with Bills. It is a travesty of the political process. It shows the importance of having a Senate, where these things can at least be given time for discussion. At the moment we are having problems because of the cut-off date for Bills in the Senate-when we will discuss them and when we will not. The Government blames the Senate because we have a cut-off date, but it jams so much legislation through the House of Representatives in a limited time that this sort of thing is inevitable. It is not the Senate's fault at all. We have just tried to bring some sanity into the legislative process, and the Government will not see eye to eye with it.

The current package of health legislation is a big one affecting a lot of areas. In particular, it affects medical insurance, which is the fundamental backbone, the driving force, of the whole private sector of health. It affects the elderly, the pensioners; it affects the way general practitioners will practise in the future; and it affects the medical insurance industry itself. Fundamentally, the Government is opting out of its responsibilities in that area. At the moment the main problem about medical insurance arises at the expensive end of the business. I refer to elderly people who require expensive long term care. In that area the Government has progressively reduced its contribution over the years. It has said that care of the elderly has to be handed back to the private insurance industry, that the burden has to be shared by the insurance companies there.

The Government has cut its contribution from about $450m to $100m, and to just $1m this year-a token amount. Of course, this is driving the insurance companies to the wall. They are not going to be able to provide insurance, yet all the Government wants to do is give them a one-shot, quick fix of $20m-largely, I would say, to take medical insurance off the agenda for the next Federal election in the hope of putting it to bed so that it will not become an issue. But the $20m would only exacerbate the problem and take us further down the road of disruption of private medical insurance. That may be the Government's goal. Perhaps it wants us all to be on Medicare and to have nobody on private medical insurance. Right now the medical insurance companies are in a very dangerous position because of the withdrawal of government funding.

I do not want to go on talking about health at this stage. The Bills will be brought into the House of Representatives tonight, I think, so they will be coming over to the Senate next week. This is the only place where they will get a full airing and a decent debate. I notice that the Democrats are going to support the proposal to send the issues of medical insurance and general practitioners' rebates to Senate committees. It is high time those things were inquired into in a big way. I just hope that the committees can report back before our medical insurance industry is completely on its beam ends.
I support the amendment that was foreshadowed by Senator Stone. It is a long one. Let me read just the first part, which seeks to add at the end of the motion:

. . . condemns the Government for its failure to pursue policies which will address the twin evils of a dangerous level of foreign debt and declining living standards, leading to a growing loss of control over the future of Australia . . .
The amendment then lists seven points that are of vital importance to reconstruction and to resolution of the economic plight that we find our country in today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I formally move my foreshadowed amendment in relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 3):

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add:

``, but the Senate condemns the Government for its failure to pursue policies which will address the twin evils of a dangerous level of foreign debt and declining living standards, leading to a growing loss of control over the future of Australia, and notes:

(a) that in the first ten months of 1988-89 Australia's deficit on the current account of our balance of payments has already reached $14,040 million, compared with the Treasurer's budget forecast of $9,500 million for the year as a whole, and that many forecasters are now predicting a total 1988-89 deficit as high as $17,000 million;

(b) that these external deficits can only be financed either through further borrowings by Australians from foreigners, or by further sales of Australian land or other assets to foreign owners and there is growing public unease at the speed and extent of the continuing growth in foreign ownership of Australian land and other assets;

(c) that at end-December 1988 Australia's net foreign debt was already $95.5 billion, and that since then that figure will have been significantly increased both by the succession of monthly external deficits and by the now significant fall in the value of our dollar;

(d) that the consumer price index (CPI) has risen by 6.9 per cent during the twelve months ended in the recent March quarter, that this inflation rate is now expected to increase further in the current June quarter, and that last week the Treasury forecast that during the twelve months ended in the March quarter next year the CPI will rise by a further 6.9 per cent;
(e) that despite the present extremely high level of interest rates, the Treasurer has now stated at his media conference on 16 May 1989 that if necessary he will raise interest rates further;

(f) the sharp cuts imposed by the Government at last week's Premiers Conference and Loans Council meetings in the funds available to the States in 1989-90, and that the Government should be condemned for its expressed intention to refrain from applying the same budgetary medicine to the spending excesses of its own Ministers in Canberra; and

(g) the utter failure of the so-called Accord between the Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions to promote the productivity increases which will provide real wage increases, with consequences for living standards, our international competitiveness and the value of our dollar which are plainly evident in the financial markets''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Stone be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, to the contrary no. I think the ayes have it.
—The noes have it.
—Why don't you wake up and get your act together? You either know what you are doing or you don't.
—No!
—Do I hear two voices? Is a division required?
—Come on! You lot couldn't run a brothel on a battleship.
—For the sake of completeness, the amendment has not been circulated to me and I should like to see it at this particular stage.
—Order! The motion was put and I heard senators expressing only support for the amendment. I therefore declared that the amendment was carried.
—The noes have it.
—Do I now hear two noes? Is a division required?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek your advice on a point of order. Just prior to the previous division there was a loud interjection from Senator Puplick which I believe was unparliamentary. I seek your advice as to how we might achieve a ruling on that and a withdrawal. Senator Puplick referred to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus), as not being able to organise a brothel on a battleship. I consider that demeaning not only to women but also to members of the armed forces, and inappropriate language for this chamber. I seek your advice as to what action might be taken.

—Unfortunately, I was not in the chair at the time. I missed the incident. I do not believe at this stage that there is anything I can do about it. Under Standing Orders I do not think I have any power.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Clauses 1 to 10 have been postponed by direction of the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce
Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw attention to the fact that, even though the last remarks of Senator Puplick might have been considered unparliamentary, the Government obviously cannot organise a chook raffle. We had in here a junior Minister, the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus), controlling the final stages of the debate on the Appropriation Bills. He was handling the final stages of the Appropriation Bills, the most important part of the Government's Budget, yet he had no idea that an amendment was being moved against his Government by Senator Stone and he did not know whether he ought to oppose it. He had to be shaken into action by his Whip, who had absolutely no idea what was going on either. Each had to be prompted by the President in order to bring out some kind of exclamation, which produced a division.

—Order! I have allowed you to speak for a couple of minutes but this is not relevant to the matter before the Committee. You should wind up your remarks or direct them to the matter which is before the Committee, which is the votes in group A.

—I must say that it has relevance to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is responsible for the operations of his Government. He did not see fit to send into the chamber a senior Minister to handle the final stages of the most important debate concerning the Budget and to explain to the Parliament exactly what the Government's intentions were. We had a Minister who had no idea whatsoever about what he was doing.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. You have made a ruling about the monumental irrelevance of all of this. I ask that you draw Senator Messner to order and get him back to the Bill.
—The matter before the Committee concerns the votes in group A. Senator Messner, you will be in order if you can relate your remarks to the votes in group A, but not otherwise.

—I just want to ask whether there has been sufficient explanation to the Parliament when a junior Minister who is paid for by the moneys voted upon by the Parliament and controlled by the Prime Minister does not know what he is doing. Consequently he ought to find every reason to resign his position in the Government of Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —On that subject, I am assured by Senator Bolkus that he could perform the task to which Senator Puplick referred and he does not accept the description of his capacity-nor does anyone else in the Government-offered by Senator Puplick or Senator Messner. It might be appropriate if we turned to the subject matter of the appropriations.

—I have a question in relation to the National Media Liaison Service. What is the objective of this service, how many people does it employ, how are they funded and what is the total cost, broken down to show wages, postage, distribution and other costs?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

The purpose of the National Media Liaison Service, as the name implies, is to ensure that the media are made fully aware of what is happening in relation to Government program announcements and to ensure, in turn, that the Government is made fully aware of what appears in the media, both electronic and print, covering the whole range of Government activities and policy issues to which the Government may be obliged to respond. Beyond that, I will be happy to ensure that Senator Walters gets an answer to her specific question.
—I have another question.
—You did say one question.

—It is on the same subject. It relates to the publication Focal Point put out by the Government. How extensive is the distribution of that paper? I do not see its role as instructing the national media. I would like some information on the cost of Focal Point. Is the Australian Labor Party paying for it-it is a purely political paper-or does the taxpayer pay for it? Could the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) please give me its distribution?

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

—I can give you five copies. You have sent me five.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) is in the chamber because I wish to ask one or two questions regarding the Department of Transport and Communications, which is a portfolio he represents. I have been concerned for some time, as I know the Minister has, with the operations of Imparja Television of Central Australia in Alice Springs. Some recent press publicity has been given to the possible takeover by Imparja of the television broadcasting operations of the Port Pirie commercial licensee and also the associated operations in Broken Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of Imparja is well known. But there has been some concern about its capacity to carry on its broadcasting activities in Alice Springs due to a shortage of money. The Federal Government has been supporting the operations of this Aboriginal station to the tune of something like $3.6m or $3.8m a year. As I understand it, the Government is virtually underwriting all of the cost of operating the station. There is concern in the northern part of my State of South Australia about the service, which is currently based in Port Pirie and, of course, just across the New South Wales border in Broken Hill. Are there any plans or negotiations which may entail the absorption into Imparja of the commercial licences which are currently operated from Port Pirie and Broken Hill?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that I will have to take that question on notice. Officers from the Department are not present at the moment. In any event, this is a specialised question to which it might be difficult to give an answer even if they were. I will simply respond as soon as I can.

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade tell me what action the Federal Government has taken in relation to the political situation between the people of Tibet and the People's Republic of China?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation in Tibet was, of course, the subject of quite sustained activity by my predecessor, Mr Hayden, who visited that country and made clear the Government's concern about a number of human rights issues. Since I have been Foreign Minister I have raised the question on two or three occasions with my counterpart, Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, making the point that, while we accept Chinese sovereignty over Tibet and do not want in any way to be taking issue with China's status in that respect, we do, nonetheless, believe that there is a case for dialogue between the Chinese authorities and the Dalai Lama and, of course, the people the Dalai Lama represents. We have expressed concern about the occasional violence which has erupted in Tibet from time to time in recent months and recent years and have expressed the hope that the situation can be satisfactorily resolved and that the human rights and other related concerns that the Tibetan people have had can be addressed in a sensitive way.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that is probably about as much as any outside government could do in relation to this issue. I acknowledge Senator Walters's concern and the concern of many other people, including members of the Tibetan community in Australia to whom I have spoken on this issue. I will keep the situation under review to see what other action might be appropriate from time to time in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a question in respect of the Department of Transport and Communications. Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade tell me what response the Government has received to the proposal floated by the Federal Labor Government that commercial radio and television be required to make time available at no charge to political parties for political broadcasts?
—Floated by the Labor Party to the Joint Committee, not by the Government.
—Would the honourable senator let the Minister answer my question?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was floated, as Senator Macklin said by way of interjection, by the Australian Labor Party rather than by the Government as such. Be that as it may, I am afraid that again I am unable to give Senator Walters a response to her question in the absence of any briefing presently available. I will seek a reply and make sure that she has it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade relates to that section of his Department which deals with embassies and to recent reports of possible closure of more of our embassies as a cost cutting measure. This is obviously an issue which vitally affects our representation overseas and, as such, it has very much to do with the question of costs that are incurred, which is the subject of the Bills which we are now debating.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not expect the Minister to tell me now, but I wonder whether he is intending to make a statement in regard to that matter-he might be able to say now that there is no truth in it-or whether the Parliament will be receiving a statement at some later stage with regard to our representation overseas. Secondly, can he tell me whether he is likely to be discussing any proposals to establish embassies in some of those countries to which at present our ambassadors may be accredited? Is there any intention to establish additional embassies in countries in respect of which our ambassadors may be accredited on a non-resident basis?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no intention of making a statement on the question of overseas representation, not least because I have no intention whatsoever of closing any further missions. My objective in life is, rather, the contrary-to open some more. I have identified some priorities in this respect if funds can possibly be made available. I do not think it is a terribly satisfactory alternative to extend the accreditation of missions on a non-resident basis although, from time to time, that is an option that is forced upon us by staff shortages.

SPEECH.PARA: I think some of this speculation has been generated by newspaper reports about average staffing level cuts in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade of some 78 proposed for this year. Can I just simply say that although it is going to be a problem for us to accommodate those staff cuts this, by and large, is a task that has been confronting us for some time. It has been in the pipeline and it rather represents an accumulation of obligations in previous years. We think we will be able to accommodate the cuts without any adverse impact on our representation abroad and certainly not in terms of forcing any further closures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point I wish to raise with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade concerns recent statements made by Aung San Suu Kyi, a leading opposition figure in Burma. About three weeks ago it was reported in the press that she had made a statement criticising Australia's supposedly ambivalent attitude towards opposition to the present regime in Burma. Only recently on the weekend, she was interviewed on the Special Broadcasting Service program Dateline and again made the comment that Australia's attitude towards restoration of democracy and human rights in Burma was being compromised because we had economic interests at stake. This has led to some concern on her part that we are not as forthright as we should be in supporting democracy and full human rights.

SPEECH.PARA: As a senator with some interest in Burmese affairs, I wonder whether the Foreign Minister can put on the record clearly the Government's position on this matter and, in particular, whether the aid programs that have been restored, or partially restored-namely, the Mandalay dairy project and the water program in the dry areas of north-west Burma-are in fact in accordance with our policies on humanitarian aid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to take the opportunity to do just that. The Australian Government has in fact been very surprised by reports that the Burmese Opposition Leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, has expressed doubts about Australia's sincerity and speculated that our relations with the ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council, or SLORC as it is called, may have a commercial motive.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's policy towards Burma remains one of unequivocal support for democracy and political and economic reform. Our diplomatic contacts with the Saw Maung regime, as indeed with a wide range of opposition parties and groups, have been entirely appropriate and correct. The Government has never indicated support for the regime, for the way it came to power or for its continued suppression of opposition groups. On the contrary, we have been active in encouraging the Burmese authorities to hold an early general election, not least through the person of our roving parliamentary diplomat extraordinaire, Senator Schacht, and to improve the observance of human rights. As a result of these efforts, Australia is widely regarded within Burma as having contributed to the authorities' decision on 16 February, announced at the time of Senator Schacht's stay in the country, to announce a timetable for elections in April-May 1990. While we naturally want to protect Australia's commercial interests, actual and potential, in Burma and be in a position to take advantage of opportunities which may arise, interest from the Australian business community in Burma is, I have to say, limited. Two-way trade is quite negligible at the moment, amounting to just $22 1/2m in 1987-88.

On the question of aid, apart from continuing humanitarian aid through the United Nations Children's Fund the only Australian aid project in Burma at present is the Mandalay dairy development project, which was reactivated in March but only to ensure that that project would not collapse and that its socioeconomic benefits, which are aimed at addressing a wide cross-section of farmers and other members of the Mandalay community, were not put at risk. In fact, the $14m investment had been at considerable risk of being completely wasted as a result of problems that were arising with the unsupervised assembly of complicated plant components. It was for that reason that the project was reactivated to ensure that it would be brought to fruition without destroying the investment. Decisions on the resumption of other project activities will be subject to the Government's ongoing assessment of the administrative, logistic and infrastructural environment in Burma.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the progress being made to reach a settlement in Kampuchea, or Cambodia, as the Minister quite correctly points out we should now call the country-and I understand that even the Hon Sen Government has now agreed to call it Cambodia again-have preparations been made within the Department, if progress continues and a successful conclusion is reaches with all the parties in the next few months, for appropriations to be made available in order to expand our diplomatic representation in Cambodia as well as other ancillary matters? In view of the rapidity of the progress being made, it may be that within the next few months Australia will be involved in an international conference and be asked to upgrade or establish some representation in Cambodia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a little premature to be talking in terms of making appropriations and preparing for a resumption of diplomatic representation in the way that Senator Schacht is suggesting. As I said on 6 April, in answer to a question from Senator Schacht, what we might do in that respect depends very much on the character of the internal settlement that is reached, assuming that the external dimensions of this fall into place later this year with the withdrawal of the Vietnamese. I repeat that it very much depends on the character of the internal settlement, when it is reached and how and in what circumstances. Once a settlement is achieved, as we hope it will be by the end of this year, the Government's intention is certainly to resume diplomatic representation in Phnom Penh as soon as possible. What will be possible is simply impossible for me to speculate about at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: We have indicated on a number of occasions our willingness to participate in any conference that might be convened in the next few months to address these questions and give some international imprimatur to them. Equally, in the context of any control mechanism, we have indicated that we would be very willing to consider participation in any peacekeeping force that might be established under such international auspices. Again, the nature of any such participation would depend wholly on the nature of the settlement and, accordingly, the nature of the task to be done. Of course, there is also an aid dimension to all this. We do not have a government to government aid program in Cambodia at the moment, although there is some support through multilateral and non-government organisations. We are very conscious of the intense suffering of the Cambodian people over an extended period. We would be keen to resume a proper bilateral aid relationship in the context of an effective settlement which, as I say, we hope will occur later this year. No financial provision has been made for that at this stage. It will depend on circumstances as they unfold. But in the context of both Cambodia and Vietnam, it is to be hoped that circumstances will allow the resumption of a proper bilateral aid program as well as bilateral effective diplomatic representation before very much longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister, in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, provide any more information to the Committee concerning an announcement that he made in August of last year when he was Minister for Transport and Communications about the establishment of a national youth network for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, namely, the extension of the broadcast from 2JJJ from Sydney to the other States? Can he give any details of when that excellent idea and initiative will be in operation within Australia, as many ageing rock and rollers such as myself look forward to it with great glee?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The departmental officers indicate that, to their knowledge, there has been no significant further development on that issue since last August, but we will come through with a supplementary response as soon as the matter can be properly checked out.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot say a great deal about our budgetary strategy, for reasons that Senator Macklin acknowledges, except that the basic way in which I approach these issues of essentially discretionary funds as distinct from locked in funding is to try if at all possible to maintain the same real level from year to year. Of course if we can do better than that in the case of the more deserving programs, I would be delighted. But we have to pay some realistic attention to the condition of the overall fiscal objectives of the Government this year, and more particularly to some of the particular problems we have in the aid budget as a result of an accumulation of locked in contributions to international financial institutions which are going to make demands on the aid budget next year considerably in excess of the forward estimate, which is based on last year's budget taken forward on the same real basis. The Government is giving some consideration to the extension of the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS), which is currently received primarily in capital cities and some country areas. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) is certainly aware of growing interest in regional areas, including Tasmania, in receiving SBS. As a partial response to that interest the Government has initiated two measures which enable country viewers in New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania to receive SBS if they have the required receiving equipment. Firstly, the encoding requirement on satellite distribution of the SBS signal was removed in 1987, by me, allowing those with domestic satellite receiving dishes, which pick up the Australian Broadcasting Corporation satellite service, also to receive SBS. Secondly, the introduction of a self-help rebroadcasting reception scheme enables communities to fund satellite reception facilities to pick up the SBS satellite signal and to rebroadcast it for reception in the same way other services are received in the home. For example Wagga Wagga in New South Wales now receives the SBS service through that community self-help scheme, which I would recommend to some of the smaller Tasmanian communities which might otherwise be denied reception.

SPEECH.PARA: The allocation of substantial resources is involved in any formal extension of the SBS in other ways to additional areas. The Government is giving consideration to that, and will certainly be taking into account the representations of all the Tasmanian members of this Parliament in our examination of Tasmania, hopefully and possibly being one of the first areas to receive the SBS service. Again I make the point that obviously there are resource implications for this which may make it difficult otherwise than through the self-help scheme or the direct satellite reception options to which I have referred.
