SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about the method of taxing trust funds as handled by funeral directors for people who pay money to funeral directors so that when they die their funeral costs will be covered. There is a longstanding practice among many elderly people in Queensland and throughout Australia of paying money to a funeral director while they are still alive to cover their funeral. I think all honourable senators will have met old people who feel very strongly about this. It gives them peace of mind to know that their funeral is paid for and that they will not be a financial burden on their families when it comes to paying their funeral costs. Regrettably, it appears that this is about to change.

SPEECH.PARA: Thousands of elderly people in my State and throughout Australia who have put their savings into a prepaid funeral plan operated by funeral businesses are about to be notified that their contributions will not be enough to pay for their funeral after all. Because of a recent ruling by the Australian Taxation Office, income earned by the funds on their contribution will be taxed at the highest taxation rate of 49c in the dollar. On top of that, the fund money will be further whittled away because the funds will be required to pay, of all things, the Medicare levy and provisional tax with the 12 per cent inflationary factor. The burden, of course, ultimately will be passed on to the contributor.

Thousands of Queenslanders are going to be adversely affected by this ruling. The cruel irony is that many of them are at the stage of their lives where they no longer pay tax. From the information that I have, the vast majority of people who are concerned about their own funeral costs come from the lower socio-economic groups. They are going to be financially disadvantaged at a time when they can least afford it. The initial contribution which has been reinvested by the funeral benefit fund in a trust to keep pace with the cost of living will no longer cover their expenses. Unless this situation is rectified straight away, the elderly will have to increase their funeral contribution, if they still wish to be independent, or else the extra money will have to come out of the deceased's estate or be paid by the deceased's family.

Honourable senators will be aware that in most cases when people make those contributions they go away with a feeling in their hearts that they have done something which will mean that they will not be a burden on their families. This situation will cause widespread concern to those who prepay their own funerals. It will affect those in the community who are least able to look after themselves. A leading funeral director in Brisbane, Alex Gow Pty Ltd, advised me that 88 per cent of those contributors are 65 years or over. Very often many of those people suffer from ailments associated with growing old.

I will give the chamber an example of how the taxes will affect those funds. If, for example, 10 members each contributed $1,000, totalling $10,000, and the trust account was invested at, say, 12 per cent, the income from that would be $1,200. If the management fee, which is a reasonable figure of 2.5 per cent, accounts for $30, the income tax is assessed at 49 per cent, which represents $573.30, and there is a Medicare levy of 1.5 per cent, the net result is a return of about 5.8 per cent. On top of that, provisional tax, plus the 12 per cent, has to be paid. It is patently obvious that, with inflation the way it is, there is no way in the world that, after a period, that prepayment of the estimated cost of the funeral benefit will pay for the funeral when it occurs.

The way the system worked in the past was that the contribution was paid into a funeral benefit prearrangement plan and was reinvested in order that the amount kept up with the cost of living, which it usually did. Then, in 1982, the Queensland Government legislated with the State Funeral Benefits Business Act to require funeral benefits businesses to place contributions paid to them in a trust fund. This was quite a responsible move by the Queensland Government, because it put the funds into the trust fund, which made them safer. This is where the first problem arose, however, because it made them liable for tax.

The Act came into effect in 1984 and operators of funeral benefits schemes registered under the Friendly Societies Act automatically became registered under part (iii) of the new Act. Any previously unregistered and new schemes were required to register under part (iv) of the State Funeral Benefits Business Act. Prior to that legislation, businesses operated under the Friendly Societies Act. Under the new Act, only corporations can be registered to carry on a funeral benefit business and the maximum amount of benefit which may be applied to a funeral expense is $3,000. So there is no question of people using it as a tax haven.

Ever since these changes were made, funeral benefit businesses have been applying for a tax exemption for income generated by a funeral benefit fund, while it remains in the fund or is used for funeral expenses. It has taken until February this year for the Australian Taxation Office to make a ruling, and yet the original letters from the funeral businesses to the Tax Office were made in November 1986. It has taken nearly two years for that response to come in. Most funeral benefit businesses in Queensland still have not been officially informed of their tax liability. All they have received is a tax assessment.

Members of the industry have not been officially informed that they will be liable for the Medicare levy and provisional tax. The Tax Office has merely started sending in assessments, with the charges included in the total liability. The industry even took the matter to the Ombudsman in an effort to have the tax position rectified, but with no success.

The industry is calling for a change to section 23 of the Income Tax Assessment Act specifically to include a funeral benefits business as registered under part (iii) and part (iv) of the Queensland Act 1982, and other similar Acts in other States, to obtain exemption on such funds. They believe, quite rightly, that prepaid funerals should enjoy a tax exempt status. After all, under the Social Security Act 1947, with the application of the assets test, a cemetery plot acquired for the person or funeral expenses paid in advance by the person, or the person's spouse, is disregarded.

The consumer has, in real terms, bought a commodity, a prearranged funeral, and, therefore, should not pay tax on the investment earnings. Funeral directors who hold the funds in trust cannot touch the money until the service is carried out. At this point they will be paid by the trustees and the money received will become part of general taxable income and will be taxed accordingly on the profits incurred, if any. It is believed that, should a contributor wish to withdraw from the fund, the income component of his or her account should be liable to taxation. No-one would dispute that. That tax could be deducted by the funeral director and forwarded to the Tax Office at the time of refund. It is suggested that in cases where there is an excess of a contributor's account after funeral expenses have been deducted, a pro rata income component of that excess, based on the original ratio of income versus principal before funeral expenses were deducted, should be taxed. The remainder of the excess would then be forwarded to the estate of the deceased.

Funeral directors all over the country, both small and large, have for many years been approached by people to hold money for them to cover their funeral expenses. Often funeral directors say to people who come to them, `Why do you not just put the money in a building society?. In the majority of cases it would not be taxed because of their stage of life. Or they suggest that people go to an insurance company, which is an avenue used in some States. The answer they get invariably is, `No, I want to be able to say that I have paid here and now for my funeral, so that I can go away and say that I am not going to be a burden on those who may have to cover that expense'. They should be allowed to continue to do so without fear of what I believe is a grossly unjust, unfair tax levied upon them. It is not as if the Government has not had some warning of this. As I said earlier, in November 1986 approaches were made to the Australian Taxation Office. People who run these trust funds in Queensland and in other States have approached members of this Parliament. The Hon. Ben Humphreys, Minister for Veterans' Affairs, wrote to the Taxation Office and received a reply on 30 September 1987. It is worth quoting the reply from the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation:

The matters which have been raised involve complex questions of taxation and commercial law and therefore have taken time to consider. Similar inquiries have also been received from other areas within the funeral benefits industry . . .

And so it goes on-typical bureaucratic gobbledegook. It is a simple matter: are these funds to be taxed or are they not? As I mentioned earlier, we have an incredible situation where people pay for their funeral and the taxation system is such that when that time comes, five, 10 or 15 years hence, the money that they paid is not sufficient. I think this an incredible injustice. People have written on behalf of contributors to the Treasurer, certainly in more recent times. The attitude of the Government is to ignore what is a patently fair and just approach. I understand that throughout Australia there are in excess of 100,000 people who want to pay their funeral expenses in advance. Their ability to do so is now at risk. It is up to the Government to make the amendment as suggested so that we can bring some justice to bear on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that all honourable senators are aware that in recent weeks and months the Australian community has been paying a great deal of attention to banking and how banks go about their business. Indeed, I have been giving it a good deal of my time in this chamber over the last five months. So much so that senior officers of the ANZ Bank asked to talk with me in Melbourne last week. We had a discussion and they suggested to me that perhaps I was the leader of the current bank bashing movement that is going on in Australia. The expression `bank bashing' I regard as quite inappropriate to describe the reaction of the community. It is suggestive of something that is irresponsible, something that is carried out by thugs in back alleys, whereas I believe that what is occurring in the community is a totally responsible process.

SPEECH.PARA: I have brought the matter into what I obviously regard and what the community regards as the supreme forum of the land and drawn to the attention of the community's elected representatives some of their concerns. Therefore, I consider the expression `bank bashing' to be a most inappropriate description of the process that is occurring within the community. It is a process of revelation, concern and investigation, a process which I attempted to formalise in the form of an inquiry. In that debate Senator Stone and others drew our attention to the fact that there has not been a formal inquiry into banking in this country since the mid-1930s.

What is the focus, then, of the concern that is being expressed within the community about banking and how banks go about their business? There have been a number of focuses. The one that I have specifically chosen over the last few months has been the serious allegations of corrupt practices and malpractices that have been brought to me which I have extended into observations about the general erosion of the ethos of banking in Australia since deregulation in 1984-85. Naturally the community's attention is more sharply focused on bank charges because they are what impact upon the Australian household day by day and month by month. The particular charges which have attracted the attention of the Australian community have been interest charges. I will be turning my attention to some aspects of interest charges in the next few minutes.

Australians are interested in the general cost of obtaining credit. They are interested in the fact that small accounts are being discriminated against by the banking system and that apparently unnecessary charges against the holders of small accounts are now common across the banking system at large. They are particularly concerned about the fact that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) contemplates-and indeed, I think, has endorsed-the process whereby bankers now have access to up to 14 per cent of deposits made compulsory by recipients of social security-in other words, the right to garnishee up to 14 per cent of those deposits. These are the sorts of questions and observations about bank charges that Australians are particularly concerned about.

In the last three of four days their concern about these charges would appear to be totally justified in the light of the extraordinary profits-indeed the banks have even described them as super profits-that have been announced by Australia's leading banks. Honourable senators will be aware that in the last four or five days Westpac announced a record half-year profit of $366m, an increase of 63 per cent on its profit of the previous half-year. The National Australia Bank announced a profit of $408m, an increase of 52 per cent. Yesterday the ANZ announced a profit of $368m for the half-year, an increase of 60 per cent. Yet in the same breath, on the same day, the banks attempt to justify increases in mortgage interest rates of 0.5 and one per cent. We are advised in today's newspapers that the householder and the small borrower will be paying in the order of 17 or perhaps even 17.5 per cent in the very near future for a basic home mortgage.

And the banks wonder why the Australian community is showing an interest in the rates at which they are paying interest, to contribute to what the banks themselves describe as super profits! Super profits! What an extraordinary term to use to describe the billions of dollars that banks are taking on a half-yearly basis from average Australians, saying that they can justify them.

So record profits have become the major focus of the media in the last few days. It is inevitable, however, that interest rates, particularly mortgage interest rates, will be the concern of the average Australian. I am going to seek leave to table a document which will reveal to average Australians something they normally do not know about their mortgage interest rates. I seek leave to table a memorandum from the Executive Director (Banking) of the National Australia Bank which he sent to the general managers of all State divisions on 4 April 1989.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this memorandum, which is signed by D. R. Argus, Executive Director (Banking) of the National Australia Bank, to all his State managers, Mr Argus predicts to his State managers that the foreclosure of interest rates will become a matter of great interest to the Australian community and Australian borrowers. He outlines the formula by which banks charge interest. Australian borrowers will be interested to know that they may be paying in the vicinity of 10.75 per cent more for their loans than they believe they are paying for them.

SPEECH.PARA: Later I will read several paragraphs from the memorandum. Mr Argus says that they have surveyed the rates of interest being charged by National Australia Bank branches on borrowers and it is revealed that in various zones they are charging what he has called `B', or a base rate, a benchmark rate, but with loadings. I understand that these loadings are usually applied. It is indicated in this memorandum that the loadings vary in the case of the National Australia Bank-the date is April 1989-from plus 4.5 per cent up to plus 10.5 per cent over and above the base rate.

The base rates are advertised periodically in the metropolitan press, presumably with the intention of advising Australians of the rate at which they will borrow from their banks. In April the National Australia Bank advised Australians that they would be borrowing at a benchmark rate of 18.75 per cent, a base rate of 18.75 per cent, a home loan rate of 16 per cent and a home equity loan rate of 17 per cent, but it did not advise Australian borrowers that there were penalties or loadings ranging from plus 4.75 per cent to 10.5 per cent over and above that base rate.

Average Australians do not know what they are paying in interest rates unless they actually sit down when they get their bank statements and calculate in retrospect what they have paid as opposed to what they believed they would be paying. These loadings can be varied on a week by week basis without promulgation, without disclosure by law or by regulation. They are a variable available to and applied by the bankers of this country week by week and can be as high as 10.5 per cent on top of 18.5 per cent. I wonder how many Australian borrowers out there know that they are paying almost 30 per cent interest on their short term borrowings. I wonder how many Australians out there know that Australia's leading rural financier, non-bank, charges up to 43 per cent for short term bridging finance. This memorandum is in anticipation of the furore that will arise when all this is disclosed. It tells the bank how to cope with the problem. The last three paragraphs of this memorandum state:

It is imperative to ensure that no unwelcome disclosure results. Experience with the media to date on consumer related issues demonstrates clearly that relatively exceptional instances of customers dissatisfaction are readily portrayed as being typical of the institution and even of the industry involved.
These loadings are typical. They are declared in this memorandum to be typical of the banking industry at large, and particularly of this bank. The memorandum continues:

As a matter of urgency, branches should review all pricing practices which may have resulted in inappropriate customer charging or situations in which customers may be unaware of their current pricing status.

In other words, change the practices-the scare is out, the panic is on-because of the process of disclosure. Attend to your books, attend to your rates, because it is going to be on. You bet it is going to be on! The memorandum continues:

Penalty rates should be looked at both in terms of defensible pricing, and in terms of disclosure rates and their application. This review should cover not only non-business consumers but also all small business loans and all loan accounts of rural customers.

Should you have any query on the implications of this initiative, please don't hesitate to contact me, as I see the management of this particular issue being very sensitive and vital in a climate of potential super profits being generated within the banking industry generally.

How right Mr D. R. Argus was in relation to the super profits-up by 60 per cent, 62 per cent and 52 per cent in the case of the three leading banks in this country in the last half-year. It is no wonder that the banks have started to suggest that they appoint, voluntarily at this stage, of course, an ombudsman. The fact is, and I have mentioned it to Mr Allan Cullen, the executive officer of the Australian Bankers Association, that I have had to be the ombudsman over the last eight months. That is why I have 200 cases in front of me. That is why I have been tabling these cases before the Senate. I will give the new ombudsman, or ombudswoman, his or her first 200 cases. All of a sudden, the banks are running scared.

The ombudsman issue is an attempt to hose down the revelation and the realities of what has been happening in banking in this country for decades. As was revealed in the debate over a potential inquiry, there has not been a process by which these factors and these realities could be revealed since the mid-1930s. Is it any wonder that Australians are up in arms about what is happening in banking?

This is not an irresponsible process of bank bashing. It is a process of investigation, revelation and demanding accountability for what banks themselves declare to be super profits, at an obscene level, at a time when the average Australian household has to bend its back incredibly even to have a roof over its head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have before me the photocopies of two photographs. The first one was taken in 1951 in Rome on 6 April and shows nine young men about to leave Italy to come to Australia. Five of those men are now dead from asbestos-related diseases. Four are still alive but are sick and suffering from those same diseases. The other photograph was taken in the 1960s in Wittenoom. It shows 13 happy children in festive mood, some of them dressed up and sitting on the back of a cart. Of those 13 children, six are now dead from asbestos-related diseases. On 10 March 1981 in the other place, Mr Kerin asked the then Minister for Health a question upon notice, He asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Is asbestos included by the National Health and Medical Research Council on the list of human carcinogens?
The answer was:

The National Health and Medical Research Council does not maintain a comprehensive list of substances which may be carcinogenic to humans. The list of carcinogenic substances probably referred to is limited to know chemical carcinogens. This forms part of a document on model regulations for the use of industries which handle such substances.
He also asked:
If asbestos is not on the National Health and Medical Research Council list as a human carcinogen, what is the reason?
The answer was:

It is obviously more useful to the professions, industry and consumers to provide information, advice, codes of practice, guidelines and other such documents on specific materials likely to cause health hazards than merely to produce lists.

It must be obvious to all honourable senators here that this is a kind of doublespeak. This sort of obfuscation over a period of years by various governments has been instrumental in the suffering and death of the children and young men in the photos that I previously spoke about. But I shall be more direct. I quote:
Mesothelioma is a malignant tumour of the tissue lining the lung. It is causally associated with asbestos.
That means that one needs to be in contact with asbestos fibres to suffer from the disease. The quote continues:

Western Australia has one of the highest incidences in the world because of the exposure of large numbers of workers at the Wittenoom Gorge asbestos mines. Whereas 15 years ago there were one to two cases of mesothelioma per annum in Western Australia, there are now 30 to 40 new cases per annum and this incidence continues to rise alarmingly . . . such that we can expect 300 to 500 cases before the year 2000 in Western Australia alone. Unfortunately neither surgery nor radiotherapy nor chemotherapy improves survival and the disease is uniformally fatal with the median survival time being only 12 months.

There has been documentation over the years going way back. I will cite some of that documentation. Way back in 1918, the last year of the First World War, it was the practice of American and Canadian insurance companies not to insure asbestos workers due to the assumed health injurious condition of the industry. There were various reports of asbestos-related diseases throughout the 1920s. In the 1930s there were numerous reports of asbestosis. In 1931 the British Government amended its workers compensation laws to cover asbestosis. In 1943, in Australia the Baryulgil mine began operation in New South Wales. Also in 1943, CSR Ltd operated a blue asbestos mine at Wittenoom in Western Australia and called the company Australian Blue Asbestos Ltd. Also in 1943, Dr J. McNulty, who at the time was the government radiologist in Kalgoorlie, told Mr Charles Oliver of the AWU of the hazards of asbestos exposure. In 1944, CSR operated a white asbestos mine in Tasmania.

In 1948 Dr Eric Saint serviced Wittenoom as a flying doctor. On his first visit to Wittenoom he immediately wrote to the Commissioner of Public Health in Perth warning him of the danger of asbestos and at the same time he warned Australian Blue Asbestos likewise. In 1949 the United Kingdom Parliament received a report which linked asbestosis to carcinoma of the lungs and stated that the length of exposure necessary to contract asbestosis could be as low as six months and, for carcinoma, 18 months. The report was available in Western Australia in 1951.

We carry on with the sad and sorry saga. In 1954 the annual Mines Inspector's report on Australian Blue Asbestos stated that the situation in the mill was disgraceful, with severe dust concentration polluting the entire plant, but added that the most effective remedy would be to exhaust large volumes of air through the roof of the mill building. In 1958 the first diagnosis of asbestosis was made in Wittenoom. In 1959 the annual report of the Health Department of Western Australia drew attention to the number of men affected by asbestos-caused diseases. In 1959 the first case of pleural mesothelioma was diagnosed in South Africa. In 1961 Dr McNulty, in a confidential letter to the Under Secretary of Mines, wrote:
It would appear that repeated advice and warnings of the health hazard from asbestos dust have been ineffective and that strong action will need to be taken.
In 1962 the first case of pleural mesothelioma was diagnosed outside South Africa, in an ex-Wittenoom mill worker, as reported by Dr McNulty.

The saga goes on. In 1966, mesothelioma was listed as a prescribed disease for worker's compensation. In 1977 the first autopsy was reported to the workers at Baryulgil in New South Wales. This was the first time those workers, who were mainly Aboriginal people, became aware that asbestos was harmful. In fact, they had been told that asbestos-related diseases could only affect non-Aboriginal people. It is a sad fact that the majority of workers at the Wittenoom mines and the Wittenoom mill in Western Australia were migrant workers. I have in my possession the translation of a pathetic letter which was written to the Italian Consulate in Perth relating how nine Italian immigrants wanted to leave Wittenoom and work no more in the dreadful conditions which they found there. This was not allowed. They had to stay there. Four pounds a week was taken out of their wages to help pay back the fare that had brought them to Australia. They were stuck there. They had no escape. Yet we read in the leading article in the West Australian newspaper on 23 May 1958:

The new mill under construction at Wittenoom will double output and add more than $2m annually to the State's mineral wealth. State Governments have assisted the industry and their faith in the enterprise is now being amply rewarded, but only a company of the status of the CSR could have ridden out the crises which have beset the industry. The Wittenoom story contains several lessons. The most important is that thriving mining centres can attract population to the empty North.

But at what price? We all know the more recent history. We have all read in the newspapers of the claims before the courts. But, before moving on to that aspect, I draw to the Senate's attention some extracts of letters that were written in the early 1960s. On 20 September, 1961 a letter was written to a Dr Rennie, a doctor associated with the CSR mines, by a physician, Dr D. D. Letham, who worked in the occupational health section. He states:

I have been able to locate in Perth records of 12 cases of asbestosis, plus three probable cases, four cases of silicosis or silicotuberculosis, six cases of probable silicosis and one in which asbestosis and silicosis both appear to be prominent.
When it is known that the labour turnover at Wittenoom has been high, this is indeed a large number of cases . . .

There is no doubt that early conditions at Wittenoom were appalling. I have had several eyewitnesses' description of the dust around the mill being so thick as to preclude vision for more than a few yards . . .

It is essential that the management do not rest content with the fact that they have spent so many thousands of pounds on ventilation but that they should not rest content until they are satisfied that their employees are adequately protected. I am suggesting that the Company itself should take an active interest in measuring dust levels. If they are found to be consistently high then steps must be taken to lower the dust levels to those regarded as `safe'. Surely this is the least that can be asked of a company with such a poor record of interest in the health of their employees.
Another letter to Dr Rennie, this time by Dr Hunt, who was a respiratory specialist, is dated 25 September 1962. It is quite a friendly letter in part. It states:

My dear Ted, this matter cannot possibly be allowed to rest. . . After examining the evidence which has been produced for you I find it very difficult to believe that a reputable public company could remain in its apparently self-satisfied state and continue to allow the asbestos mining industry to go on killing men unfortunate enough to be employed in it. If however the present situation is to remain unaltered I would feel it my bounden duty to bring the matter to the personal attention of the Premier. I would prefer not to have to do this. I do not want to cause worry and possible distress to a very good friend of mine named Rennie, and I prefer not to start a bout of public mud slinging. Surely you will come and see for yourself, following which I am confident that any further action on my part would be unnecessary.
Now a letter from Dr Rennie, also dated 1961:

Apparently, it is quite possible to be so badly dusted as to be totally and permanently incapacitated within four or five years. Both doctors are of the opinion that very urgent action is required . . . As you know, in Western Australia at the present time we are endeavouring to boost our production in every possible way and a public outcry is not going to help to attract Western Australian mining capital to the State. It would also, I am sure, bring about very considerable difficulties for the Company in securing and maintaining an adequate labour force.

Dr Rennie then instances figures relating to diseased workers as being quite horrifying. Today these people have to go before the courts and press very hard for workers compensation. Some workers compensation has now been granted to people. I have here a memo dated 21 November, 1984 written by the Director General of Mines to a Minister in the Western Australian Government. It states:

In hindsight, it is difficult to understand how the situation could have been allowed to continue; however, it must be remembered that Wittenoom was then one of the few mining operations in the State outside the Goldfields and it was heavily subsidised. If a decision had been made to close the mine it is most unlikely that this action would have received support from either the general public or the miners, as few would have believed that the health situation was sufficiently serious. The company had threatened on at least one occasion (in 1962) that because of demands being made by the Mines Department for improved dust-control equipment, and in view of the low profitability of the operation, the mine might have to close.

That sets the scene in a nutshell. We know what we have been up against. When we read in the press of people having to struggle to gain compensation and when we read in the press that the State Government Insurance Commission of Western Australia is trying to delay settlement of claims so that people are dying before they receive compensation, it puts a bitter edge to the very sad story.

But something can be done. Currently, research is being carried out in Western Australia by Dr Bruce Robinson and his team. However, the money for that research will run out later this year. I conclude my speech with an appeal to the Federal Government that, as Medicare expenses, that is, the Australian taxpayer, are now subsidising a lot of the treatment for these people, it would be most apt for the Federal Government to donate very generously to the research being carried out in Western Australia which, as is acknowledged all over the world-I have letters here from the United States of America to say so-is the best place for this research. Unfortunately, Western Australia, with its large number of asbestos-related cases of disease, is the best laboratory in the world for this research to be carried out.
