That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 proposes to amend the Defence Act 1903 to exempt Australian Defence Industries Pty Ltd (ADI) for a transitional period of six years from certain State and Territory laws, charges, taxes and rates. The Opposition understands that the amendments will exempt ADI from being liable to pay approximately $16m in State and Territory stamp duty on the transfer of establishments to the new corporation and will also help them in avoiding the costs of complying with State and Territory regulatory laws for a period of six years, a transitional period, to allow the new corporation to get on a commercial basis.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is not prepared to oppose this legislation because we believe that there is an urgent need for ADI to become commercial as soon as possible. The Government has had our support in the establishment of ADI Pty Ltd. It also has our support in the reduction of the number of personnel that have been involved in defence production. Quite rightly the Government has reduced the number of people who were employed in the Department of Defence Support from 15,000 to an expected work force at ADI of 6,700.

In saying that we support this legislation there are, however, a few matters that I would like to raise while I have the opportunity. The negotiations which have been taking place for some considerable period with the unions are still not completed. In the Estimates committee hearings I asked some questions about this. On 16 May I received an answer to a question I asked about a woman's rights to maternity leave. For example, would she have the right to go back into the Public Service and would she lose her maternity leave? What is the situation generally? The response which I received was that conditions of employment under ADI are still subject to negotiation with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and resolution by the Industrial Relations Commission. So that will affect that specific case of maternity leave.

I was interested, just before coming into the chamber, to receive the latest copy of Australian Defence Industries' newsletter. In it there is a fairly frank discussion of personnel issues. It is an interesting commentary on the problems which public employment has caused this country. This is a newsletter for the new company's staff, as much as for anybody else. It states quite categorically that in order to become competitive it has had to make a strong start in bringing its costs into line with those of industry generally. It states, `We have moved away from public sector conditions of service and where appropriate have adopted commercial industry provisions'. It is a sad condemnation of public sector conditions of service when, in order to make a crust in the commercial sector, a company has to jettison some of the benefits which have been the norm for people in the public sector.

Sick leave is given as an example. I have had quite a connection with this problem. It has been an interest of mine. I have been watching what has been happening in the public sector with sick leave. Most honourable senators would realise that some great rorts have been perpetrated in the name of sick leave. The ADI management has recognised this. While reducing the personal credit available to individual employees, the company has put in place a sick leave pool. It puts on the record that the attendance of staff will be monitored closely and that the managed use of sick leave and other forms of leave so that personnel can maximise their absences from duty with and without pay will not be allowed to continue. I am very glad to see that being stated so clearly. Sick leave is a real canker in employment these days, particularly in the public sector, where it has been allowed to grow. People have had unsupervised access to more sick leave than they should rightfully take.

Also in this personnel newsletter the company states that the removal of many of the unnecessary demarcations which currently exist and which are a source of frustration for employees and a source of unnecessary costs that prevent it from being competitive are to be aimed for, and achieved, hopefully.

The full bench of the Industrial Relations Commission approved the ADI awards with effect from 8 May 1989 but ordered that they remain in force for a period of six months. That is the clue. The Government has failed so far to see the final negotiations succeed for the work force which will be involved in the new company.

The short period of operation of the awards reflects the fact that further changes are to occur. Those further changes are to occur simply because the Government has not been successful in negotiating the changes. It reminds me of the ironic circumstance when the Fraser Government tried to take some action to privatise the Bendigo ordnance factory several years ago and it was the Australian Labor Party and its friends in the trade union movement who managed to defeat that exercise. It is ironic to me that the Government is now negotiating the commercialisation of the Office of Defence Production (ODP). It is still having difficulty with its mates in the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Senator Tate was the Minister who gave the second reading speech in the Senate. It referred to the management and the cost structures of the ODP as not always being appropriate to a large manufacturing company. I do not want to labour that point; I am glad that the management and the structures are going to change.

We also have a problem with the future scrutiny of this company. Being government-owned, it will not be subject to scrutiny by private shareholders. The Government, presumably, will have the opportunity to scrutinise it, but the Parliament will not. We were also concerned that the Auditor-General may not have been in that position. I am glad that the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, made it clear in the other place that our concerns about the Auditor's scrutiny were unfounded and that the Auditor-General will be able to exercise the scrutiny that is necessary over the new company.

That does not get away from a couple of problems we still see. One is the question of annual reports. I am informed that the ADI, being a company registered in Canberra, will have to produce its annual report for the Corporate Affairs Commission but that it will be produced for the Parliament only if the Minister so chooses. I hope that something is done to ensure that the report is automatically tabled in the Parliament each year. I feel that it is very important that the Parliament not lose the opportunity to debate the annual report of a government instrumentality.

Finally, there is the problem of scrutiny of the company by the Estimates committee. This is a problem that we are facing more and more now with government-owned enterprises. I raised the issue during the Senate Estimates Committee D hearing on 13 April. Mr McLeod, for the Department, answered:

. . . with the Government's decision to establish ADI as a wholly-owned Government company which was very much against the background of a desire to give to the organisation the same sort of flexibility that is available to a company operating in the private sector, that the public accountability which would be associated with ADI would reflect what is true of a company. I am not sure that it would be appropriate for the company to be examined before the Senate Estimates Committee. Certainly the Department would be entitled to be examined in respect of any funding that it makes available . . . Defence would remain fully accountable for any funds that are made available to ADI in terms of supplementary funding.

The problem is that ADI will not be available. That concerns me because it is a company on which the future of Australia's defence capability rests. Its ability to supply the forces will have a major impact on our defence capability. If the company is to fail in the exercise of that role, it is a matter of national concern. I recognise the technical difficulties once there is no government funding going into the company. It is not a satisfactory arrangement that the Parliament will be able to scrutinise the doings of ADI only if Commonwealth money is going into it, and then only second-hand through the Department of Defence, which is not always as open in its answers to questions as I, for one, would like. The company will always be at arm's length from the Parliament. It is something which the Parliament must give further thought to because it is a growing phenomenon. I can foresee very real difficulties in the future if ADI and other such organisations are to be safe from the inquiring minds of my colleagues in the Senate Estimates Committee. I do not intend to take the time of the Senate any longer. I simply reiterate that the Opposition is prepared to support this legislation, with the concerns that I have expressed previously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank Senator Newman who has spoken on behalf of the Opposition parties in relation to this Bill and I thank the chamber for its support for its passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 August 1988, on motion by Senator Reynolds:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill is not supported by the Opposition. The second reading speech which was given in this chamber by the Minister for Local Government, Senator Reynolds, gives the Government's reasons for wanting to reduce the quorum in the House of Representatives from its present one-third to one-fifth. A quorum of 30 members would enable the House to meet and proceed with its business. The second reading speech is interesting in that it refers to the responsibilities of members, and in particular Ministers, outside the chamber. There is no doubt that there is a great deal that all of us are involved in at any one time. There are meetings all over the place, constituents coming in, research to be done on speeches-all legitimate work that is done outside the chamber. But reducing the quorum is perhaps not the way to deal with it.

SPEECH.PARA: The real problem, that I see at least, with this proposal to reduce the House of Representatives quorum is the Government's general disdain of the Parliament and the way it will use the Executive to overrule the Parliament. In the House of Representatives, Bills are guillotined through with very little debate. Frequently they then come to the Senate and are subject to a great deal more investigation and consideration. They are frequently amended here in a way the Government accepts. Amendments are made which one would have expected to be made in the House of Representatives had the Bills been analysed more closely.

We find this attitude displayed in particular by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). His cutting of the parliamentary appropriations and his attitude that Senate committees are a waste of money I interpret as a general disdain for the parliamentary process. I would have thought that amendments as to how the chambers should function would be discussed between the parties and a bipartisan approach reached. That has not been the case.

Perhaps the example that most of us would think of at present is the immigration review fee. That fee was proposed and brought into the Parliament. It was rejected by the Senate. The Executive, not being happy with the Parliament's rejection of its proposal, brought it in administratively. We all know now the trouble the Executive has got into as a result of proceeding to do something the Parliament had rejected, attempting to get around the parliamentary process. For reasons such as those we do not feel disposed to agree to this proposal whereby a quorum of the House of Representatives will be less than it is at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had believed, until I heard Senator Reid's speech, that the Opposition was not going to oppose this Bill. Now that Senator Reid has said that the Opposition is going to oppose the Bill I think I had better make some comments as to why we will be supporting it.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of quorums fundamentally ought to be a matter for each chamber. The Senate, in a recent report, canvassed some points with regard to a quorum of this chamber. I notice that the Government has not broken that one open and decided to have a go at it, and probably for the good reason of wanting some legislation. The House of Representatives has passed this Bill and sent it to the Senate for our concurrence. I think that a reasonable position would be for us to accept the view expressed by the House of Representatives with regard to its quorum arrangements. I am mindful of the fact that there is always a government majority in the House of Representatives, almost by definition. We will see whether that situation continues, given what has occurred in the lower House in Tasmania recently.

At present it would be the view of the Democrats that, since a majority of the House of Representatives has determined that there ought to be a change to its quorum rule, it would be appropriate for the Senate to concur with that expressed wish of the House of Representatives and pass this legislation. I am quite sure that we would want reciprocal arrangements with regard to any changes that we may wish to make as to how we conduct our business in this chamber. Although the House of Representatives could do the reverse to us, that is, a majority in this place may express some particular wish and the alternative majority in the House of Representatives may wish to frustrate that, I support this Bill on the understanding that if at any stage in the future the majority in the Senate expresses a view with regard to how it wishes to organise its business, and that may require legislation-of course, not many such arrangements do-then the House of Representatives would simply concur, although it would not necessarily be the view of the majority there, as it were, because it may be aligned with a minority in the Senate. It is upon that reciprocal basis that the Democrats support this legislation, which obviously is the expressed wish of the majority in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on this matter is mercifully short, and I believe it should be put to a vote very speedily. In principle I think Senator Macklin's points are the ones that should carry the day, namely, that each chamber should be able to regulate its own affairs. For that reason the Senate ought to support this measure.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Sitting suspended from 1.50 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that Senator Cook will be absent from the chamber for Question Time today because he is in southern New South Wales having a series of urgent meetings on forestry matters. I do not normally regard that as an appropriate reason for a Minister being absent but, because the Parliament is sitting for the next three weeks and these matters are particularly urgent, I want to make sure that the absence is put in that context. Any questions in this chamber which would normally be directed to Senator Cook in relation to his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to Senator Walsh.

—Has the Minister representing the Prime Minister seen reports of a speech in Sydney last night by the Governor-General in which His Excellency said that much more needs to be done in micro-economic reform and restructuring of a broad range of Australian industries including the waterfront and coastal shipping? I note that he commented that this is a sensitive matter to be talking about at this time, but in saying what he had to say is the Governor-General reflecting the advice to him from the Government?

—I am unable to say whether there have been any discussions between members of the Government and the Governor-General on this issue. Probably the Governor-General is speaking as an Australian citizen who is concerned about these issues on which there has been wide-ranging public debate. I think that is probably the context in which the comments were made. In order that I might put that beyond doubt, I will check whether any person in the Government spoke to the Governor-General about these issues, but I would think not.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Can the Minister also advise the Senate whether the Government is in disagreement with anything that has been said by the Governor-General on these vital issues? If the Minister has not read the speech perhaps he could check that and let us know.
—I have not read the speech, but in so far as Senator Chaney indicated that the Governor-General suggested that they were very important issues, I do not retreat from that description.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEREGULATION OF THE DOMESTIC WHEAT MARKET

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has he seen the report on the front page of today's Sydney Morning Herald headlined, `Peacock backs down on wheat'? What action will the Government take if the Leader of the Opposition fails to stand up to the National Party by maintaining Mr Howard's final position that the coalition would try to amend the legislation but that even if the amendments were defeated the deregulation of the domestic wheat market would not be opposed?

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. Standing order 99 requires that questions shall not ask Minister to indulge in hypothetical matters. Senator McKiernan's question is `What happens if' and it is a comment about something which does not in any sense constitute a proper matter in terms of avoiding the requirement of paragraph (g) of standing order 99 that the question shall not be based upon hypothetical things that may or may not happen. It is clearly a question which is out of order.

—I am aware of the difficulties with the particular standing order that Senator Puplick refers to. I ask Senator Walsh to limit his answer to the Government's intentions and to areas of his portfolio and not to hypothetical questions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very easily done, Mr President, because Mr Kerin has already sent out a letter to all senators, I understand, telling them what the Government will do. I was asked whether I saw the press report with the heading `Peacock backs down on wheat'. I certainly did. I must say that I was not at all surprised. Indeed just two weeks ago in the Senate I forecast precisely this outcome. I pay tribute to Mr Howard-although I have been critical of him from time to time for which I neither apologise nor resile-for being the first Liberal Party leader in history to have the courage to stand up to the National Party. I made the forecast that that situation would change under the new wimpish leadership of the Liberal Party.

—On the point of order, Mr President: the clear direction which you gave to Senator Walsh was to confine himself to matters which are within the portfolio responsibility which he administers or which he represents. The question of hypothetical situations arising or indeed of the Opposition's policy which has been already laid down in this place is not one which conforms with the direction which you have given Senator Walsh. The question, in terms of its hypothetical basis, was clearly out of order. The direction which you have given to the Minister is clearly being ignored by the Minister, and I suggest that you bring him to account.
—Order! I was listening to Senator Walsh's remarks and I thought they were an introduction to his answer. I remind him of my previous direction.

—Certainly, Mr President. I have made the point: it is not hypothetical. It may have been hypothetical that I forecast that under this new wimpish leadership the Liberal Party would revert to type and allow the National Party to run the show. It is no longer hypothetical. We now know that that has happened. The Government's response is, as I mentioned earlier, set out in a letter which Mr Kerin dispatched yesterday. Mr Kerin made the point very firmly that if the Senate proceeds with the amendments, which it proposes to do, the Government will not accept the amendments. Therefore, on 1 July the Australian Wheat Board will no longer be able to trade on the domestic market and two years hence it will not exist at all. It will not be trading on the overseas market either. The consequences of that are that those who said they did not want private trade in wheat on the domestic market will have nothing but private trade as from 1 July.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Puplick

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr President, both as to the failure of the Minister to observe your strictures on this matter and now to the additional point which relates to the final part of standing order 99, which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: Questions shall not anticipate discussion upon an Order of the Day or other matter which appears on the Notice Paper.

I draw your attention to item No. 34 appearing on the Notice Paper which reads, `Wheat Marketing Bill 1988-89-Consideration in Committee of the Whole of Message No. 445 from the House of Representatives', and other matters. I ask you to rule that, both in terms of ignoring your earlier ruling and in terms of the matter which the Minister has now introduced which is contrary to that part of Standing Order 99 relating to items which are on the Notice Paper and the fact that item No. 34 appears on the Notice Paper, the Minister is clearly out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. I do not know what Senator Puplick has had for lunch, but if we cannot discuss at Question Time things that are on the Notice Paper, nearly every matter will be put on it and we will not be able to canvass anything. I know what is in the Standing Orders and Senator Puplick knows what is in the Standing Orders. He also knows what the practice has been over many years. It has been to allow flexibility in asking questions which applies as much to the coalition side as it does to this side. If the Opposition wants to narrow the scope of that it will get an even more sterile Question Time than currently exists.

—On the point of order, Mr President: following what has been said by Senator Robert Ray, it is true that in normal debates in this place and in Question Time the strict Standing Orders are often not applied and that is on both sides and for the convenience of both sides and for the ebb and flow in this place. Points of order are often not taken even though they could be. The point is, however, that on this occasion the Opposition is taking the point of order because the Minister is playing politics with Question Time in a way which we object to and we are entitled to take advantage of the Standing Orders. Let me say that the simple reality which the Minister obviously has not heard about is that Mr Peacock confirmed this morning that our stance on those Bills is precisely the same as the stance that we originally adopted. So there is no change in the Opposition's position at all. Therefore, the game that is being played is one that we do not believe is a proper use of Question Time and I suggest that you rule on the point of order in accordance with the Standing Orders and not in accordance with some sort of general gloss of them.

—Order! I have ruled before that a strict interpretation of standing order 99 would mean that there would be practically no Question Time. I point out to Senator Walsh, however, that I believe he is debating the question. I ask him to conclude his answer.

—I readily understand Senator Puplick's embarrassment. Having helped to engineer the coup of a couple of weeks ago, he is now a bit shocked by its consequences. I have been asked about the Government's response. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard for the definitive record the letter that Mr Kerin circulated yesterday.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite reckon that they do not want to waste time in Question Time! I will read out the letter. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: Dear Senator,
I am writing to you to seek your assistance to prevent a severe crisis of confidence from engulfing the wheat industry.

The House today passed an amended Wheat Marketing Bill, but rejected a number of Senate amendments. Those amendments can be portrayed as allowing the Board to ignore the Australian Constitution, to abuse its market power, to risk having people on it who are not the best available, and to expose the taxpayer to the risk of 95 per cent underwriting. These are all unacceptable to the Government.
If the Senate insists on these amendments, there will be no Bill passed, and the sunset clause in the existing Act will be triggered on 1 July-
that is 1 July 1989-
This means there would be no underwriting of the 1989 crop and the Board would suffer a severe crisis of confidence as its very existence after 1991 would be at risk.
The Senate must pass the Bill as it now stands. The Government has shown a great deal of flexibility throughout the wheat debate-there is no room for more.

In particular, we will not extend the existing legislation, so any attempt to use these amendments as a back-door attempt to sabotage domestic wheat market deregulation will not work. On the contrary, those who do not want private trade in wheat will risk there being nothing but private trade.
The issue is no longer about deregulation-that was settled by two weeks ago.
I trust that you will be able to assist the wheat industry by ensuring that the Bill is passed in the Senate.
Yours sincerely,
John Kerin

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources to the continuing disarray within the Labor Government on uranium policy, as reported in today's Australian Financial Review.
—That is a hypothetical question.

—The Minister will be aware that with the worldwide concern about the greenhouse effect it is inevitable that nuclear powered electricity generation will increase; that Canada, with 10 per cent of uranium reserves, supplies 30 per cent of the world market whereas Australia, with 30 per cent of reserves, supplies only 10 per cent of the world market; and that, because of the failed economic policies of this Labor Government, we are now facing a current account deficit and foreign debt crisis. I ask the Minister: Why, in the light of these circumstances, does the Australian Labor Party, apparently with the support of the Minister, continue to entrench for the next two years its loony three-mine policy? What special market expertise does the Government have which it believes is superior to that of those who are prepared to risk their own money in new projects?

—Senator Robert Ray, by way of interjection, pointed out that the question is based on a hypothetical report in today's Financial Review. Therefore, in order not to offend Senator Puplick again, I do not think I should answer it.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: Is this delay, to use the terms that he used in his last answer to a question, just a wimpish response by this Government to hard decision making?
—Senator Parer should not believe everything he reads, even in a reputable newspaper such as the Financial Review.

—Is the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs aware of statements of the new Victorian Opposition Leader, as reported in today's press, in which he advocates the deportation of convicted drug traffickers? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the current practices regarding people from overseas who have been convicted of serious offences involving drugs or violence in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government takes a very serious view of non-citizens who have become involved in serious crimes involving drugs or violence. Our policy on deportation was first set down on 4 May 1983 by Minister West and was again clarified by my statement in this chamber on 8 December 1988. This Government of course does not accept gratuitous advice in the form of glib one-liners from the latest Leader of the Opposition in Victoria about the need to convince us to protect Australia from the possibility of further criminal behaviour by individuals.

ANSWER.PARA: Our statements and actions over a number of years demonstrate the seriousness we attach to our responsibility to exclude from this country those non-citizens who have seriously abused the privilege of residence accorded to them by the Australian community. Stated briefly, it is our policy that non-citizens who are convicted of the production or distribution of heroin or other hard drugs, organised criminal activity, serious sexual assault, violence, kidnapping or extortion and sentenced to more than 12 months in gaol are liable for deportation. Such deportation decisions, which of course are appealable to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), take effect at the conclusion of the gaol sentence. AAT decisions on deportation are also subject to overruling in the national interest by ministerial statement to this Parliament.

Whilst there is always consideration of compassionate and humanitarian circumstances in making any decision to deport, the overriding principle must be the general protection and well-being of the Australian community and its standards. This has meant that, since 1983, 143 non-citizens have been deported as a consequence of being involved in criminal activity. About one-third of these people have been involved in drugs. It should also be noted that we have in place security processes which are second to none in our effort to screen out people with a criminal background and prevent them from entering this country in the first place. To place this matter in perspective, however, my answer would be incomplete without pointing to the fact that people who have migrated here, on average, have half the level of involvement in criminal activities of their Australian born counterparts.

I also note that the Victorian Opposition Leader, in his descent into the Dark Ages, has also called for the reintroduction of capital punishment. I can only hope that in future Mr Brown, and anyone else who seeks to grab a cheap headline at the expense of our migrant community, at least takes the time to check the history of the matter. As Mr Brown has been in politics since 1979, I would have thought that at least he would have known government policy as enunciated on two major occasions in the Federal Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware of the 10 recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs inquiry into asbestos contamination of the Aboriginal community at Baryugil Square in New South Wales? When were these recommendations made? Was the Minister, Mr Hand, a member of that Committee? How many of the recommendations have been fully implemented? Is the Minister aware that the Committee recommended that a vigorous program to decontaminate Baryugil Square be instituted, yet open tailings dumps of asbestos still exist and the surface soil in the living area still contains 10 per cent asbestos?

—The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is aware of the 10 recommendations of the House of Representatives inquiry into asbestos contamination of the Aboriginal community at Baryugil Square in New South Wales. Whilst a more detailed response to the honourable senator's questions is being prepared, the Minister's knowledge of these matters of course comes from the fact that he was a member at the time of that inquiry, before he assumed ministerial office. As to the number of recommendations that have been fully implemented, a detailed response will be provided to the honourable senator. It may be of interest to him that the Minister is meeting with the people of that area today. I am sure that much will come out of that meeting between the Minister and those concerned.

—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen the press release issued on 1 May by Mr John Moore, shadow Minister for business and consumer affairs, dealing with aspects of the Government's decision to invite the public to subscribe funds to an Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) subsidiary? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether there is any substance in Mr Moore's claim that the float is not being managed in the public interest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen that press release. I thought that I should comment on it because it is an extraordinarily irresponsible piece of work from a shadow Minister. Fortunately, journalists working for Australia's major daily newspapers did their homework better than Mr Moore-much more thoroughly, and earlier. Newspapers ignored Mr Moore and gave the public an accurate and favourable picture of what the Government and the AIDC are trying to achieve by this float.

ANSWER.PARA: I should remind honourable senators of certain facts concerning the Government's decision to offer the public equity in AIDC Ltd, a new company in which the Government, through the AIDC, will retain 70 per cent ownership. The Government is not interested in privatisation by stealth, as Mr Moore suggests; it is interested in making sure that the capital base of the AIDC grows sufficiently strongly to allow it to play a strong role in supporting the development of Australian industry. Hence the decision to offer shares in it to the public. The AIDC has been managed very professionally and with great prudence. Its assets and profits have grown steadily and at a respectable rate. In terms of comparative performance, it is one of the most successful enterprises of its kind in Australia.

I have every confidence that the float will also be managed competently and professionally by the AIDC. Contrary to what Mr Moore says, the AIDC has engaged professional underwriters to the issue. Journalists were quite aware of that, but apparently the shadow Minister was not. The Government has engaged its own independent adviser on the float-Mr Charles Goode, the Chairman of Potter Partners. His advice and expertise are available both to the Government and to the management of the AIDC. It is a matter of obvious concern that the issue be correctly priced and competently managed.

It was careless-or, worse, suspicious-that Mr Moore's intervention was made in the way it was and in a manner likely to damage the prospects of a successful float. I do not think it is entirely surprising that this press release was ill-informed. In answer to a question yesterday, Senator Walsh pointed out that Mr Moore had obviously been well tutored by those who had made significant profits from Britain's privatisation program. Apparently he is not concerned with the broader industry restructuring issues, nor is he concerned to get the best deal for the Australian taxpayer. If he were he would not have said what he did. He certainly seems to be obsessed with the process of wholesale sell-offs that can only benefit friends on the stock exchange. In contrast to the way in which the Government is managing the float, Mr Moore has never demonstrated much care or attention to detail, and he seems to have a limited sense of shadow ministerial responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the press article in yesterday's Australian newspaper, in which he is reported as having stated that Australia's major economic policies are currently under review. That was before, having been reprimanded by his Leader, he had to substitute `constantly' for `currently'. Can Senator Button confirm that the major economic policies that he referred to will be reviewed at the Australian Labor Party (ALP) conference in July? Can he deny that the ALP's policies on privatisation will be changed at the conference, that Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd will be privatised, and that the Commonwealth Bank will be amalgamated with a major Australian bank?
—Again it is not a surprise that Senator Boswell's question is so riddled with error that it resembles a colander.
—Are you going to deny it? Just deny it-that is all you have to do.

—The honourable senator knows perfectly well what I said in the Senate. I guess that the imagination of Steve Burrell, a journalist with the Australian Financial Review-I must say his imagination exceeds his talent-enabled him to put a quite extraordinary interpretation on what I said in the Senate. I was not reprimanded by anybody, and I did not apologise to anybody for anything I had said. The honourable senator should not believe all that he reads in that column. As for the question of the review of ALP policies, there will be no national conference of the ALP in July and, therefore, no policies will be reviewed then.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. It concerns Australia's household savings ratio and the need for that ratio to be increased. Can the Minister say whether there are marked differences in the household savings ratio between the different States? If so, which State has the highest ratio, and which has the lowest? Are these ratios tending to converge?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —National accounts data on household savings are available, but only on a whole year basis. In other words, there is no quarterly publication, broken down by States. Therefore, the most recent figures for States are those for the last financial year, 1987-88. In that year Australia as a whole had a household savings ratio of 8.2 per cent. There are very considerable differences between States. Indeed, when I first became aware of them I found them to be quite remarkable. The State with the highest ratio in the last financial year was Victoria, with 12.8 per cent. The State with the lowest ratio was Queensland, with 2.4 per cent. In other words, Victoria's figure is some 400 per cent higher than Queensland's-an enormous difference.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of whether the rates are converging, I have figures for the changes between 1986-87 and 1987-88. For Australia as a whole, the savings ratio increased from 7 per cent to 8.2 per cent; in Victoria there was an improvement from 10.8 per cent to 12.8 per cent; but in Queensland there was a deterioration from 4.1 per cent to 2.4 per cent. No other State has a savings ratio anywhere near as low as that of Queensland. The only other State to experience a decline in the household savings ratio between 1986-87 and 1987-88 was South Australia, and in that case the figure fell moderately from 8.5 per cent to 8.2 per cent, which was right on the national average for that year.

The determinants of household savings are rather complex. It is suggested by some that the very low figure for Queensland could be affected by the State's high proportion of retired people. There may be some validity in that-I am not sure-but it is certainly not feasible that that difference, or any other similar difference, could alone account for the enormous gap between Queensland's figure and the national average, let alone between Queensland's figure and that of Victoria. By a process of elimination one is led to the conclusion that the appalling economic record of the Queensland Government must be the dominant factor.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to a press statement of 19 May in which he claimed that local government was to receive an extra $18.5m under Federal funding arrangements in 1989-90. In fact, the press statement said 1988-89, but I presume that he meant 1989-90. The Minister will be aware that the last allocation to local government was $652.5m. The amount for 1989-90 is to be $671m. Does the Minister agree that, given a projected consumer price index increase to March 1990 of at least 6.9 per cent, local government should have received $697.5m to break even with its allocation for last year in real terms? Further, does he acknowledge that, rather than being $18.5m better off in real dollar terms, as he claimed in his press release, local government will be $26.5m worse off in 1989-90-a loss of 3.8 per cent? Can the Minister please explain to local government a method by which it will be able to absorb this massive cutback to its Federal funding which does not involve either a significant cutback in the services provided or a rates hike at the expense of the ordinary Australian family, already reeling under the crippling effects of this Government's economic mismanagement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —One matter is missing from Senator Calvert's question, that is, whether I said in the press release that the extra grants to the States were in real or nominal terms. I have never, even in this chamber, alluded to them as being in nominal rather than real terms. The reality is that, in nominal terms, an increase of $18.5m constituted a 2.8 per cent increase compared with 2.4 per cent to the States. Allied to that was Australia Post and Telecom Australia becoming rateable. My memory is that that will be worth an additional $90m to local government. I do not want the honourable senator to hold me to that figure, but I think it is in that general area.
—That is a separate issue.

—What we are looking at is the overall well-being of local government. As I say, local government did relatively better than the States at the Premiers Conference. I am constantly amazed that Senator Calvert and other Opposition senators come into the chamber and deal with one little area of interest and say, `We want more money'. It is a classic case of the difference between the micro and the macro. Senator Newman comes in here and says, `We want more money for defence personnel'. Senator Walters will want the Special Broadcasting Service extended to Tasmania. What a joke! It is a question of priorities but Opposition senators never list their priorities. They come into this chamber time and time again and say that money should be spent in this area or that area but, in their big, bumptious speeches on Appropriation Bills, they say, `We want billions of dollars off the Budget'. They never nominate one area that they want cut. Which areas do they want cut?

ANSWER.PARA: That is the test of the Opposition. That is why Opposition senators are such hypocrites. That is why they will always remain on that side of the chamber. Senator Lewis will want more money for industry. Senator Puplick will want more money for the environment. Senator Hill will want more money for law enforcement. Senator Boswell will want hundreds and hundreds of millions of dollars for rural subsidies. They want brown paper bags handed out everywhere. Taken from the front bench to the back bench, their requests add up to billions of dollars. They come in here and say, `Look, just in our particular area, we want more money'. But they never add up their requests. They do it so that they can go to individual groups and say, `Look, I asked a question in the Senate about why you didn't get more money'. At the same time they deliver the old, pompous speeches about wanting millions of dollars in expenditure cuts. They never nominate the areas in which the cuts should be made. I have always acknowledged that Senator Calvert has an interest in the local government area and I do not challenge his credentials in that regard. But, sooner or later, he must come to a realisation that there must be some sort of equilibrium between the micro and the macro.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I appreciate the Minister's attempt to answer my question, but all I asked him was whether he claimed in his press release that local government will be better off when in fact it will be worse off.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Local government will be better off in more than one way. The first way is globally, considering what it will get from Telecom Australia and Australia Post. The second is as a result of what it got at the Premiers Conference in real terms. It achieved a result far better than that achieved by the States. Third, it is better off because the economy of this country is operating properly. Local government knows that it has to make a contribution to the economy. If various things have to be sacrificed across the board, that sacrifice must be made equitably and local government, like State government, has a role to play.

—I ask a question of the Minister for Finance dealing with foreign investment. Does the Minister recall seeing advertisements in the national press asserting that Elders IXL Ltd is 110 per cent Australian and is Australia's largest broker and processor of superfine wool? Is the Minister concerned that Elders, a company that is so important to Australia's primary industry, is about to undergo a change of control without a formal takeover bid being mounted? Can the Minister say whether the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) will be looking into this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall very well the advertisements which described Elders as a 110 per cent Australian company. Presumably it was prepared by the sort of people who put the Liberal Party alternative Budget together, maybe with some assistance from the new Liberal Party Leader who, on his own admission, does not bring an accountant's approach to bear on the preparation of Budgets or expenditure proposals. Last Friday, Mr Elliott announced a plan that will have the effect of giving Harlin Holdings 49 per cent of the capital in Elders, Harlin being a company in which Mr Elliott has a substantial personal interest. Stephen Bartholomeusz, in his column in yesterday's Age, described the Elliott plan in some detail. He suggested that the proposal may be described as a pro rata issue by Harlin and AFP Investment Corporation Ltd but in reality it is an attempt by Harlin to buy the AFP parcel while camouflaging it as an offer available to all shareholders. He wrote:

ANSWER.PARA: If Harlin had simply sought shareholder approval to buy 18 per cent of Elders from AFP in a clean and clear transaction, it is hard to see how the proposal could possibly be sold to shareholders.

I understand that Mr Elliott's plan has been organised in such a way that it sidesteps the normal requirements regarding making a fair offer to the takeover target's minority shareholders. Essentially, Mr Elliott is making his shareholders an offer that is not too good to refuse. If they do refuse the offer, Harlin, which is the underwriter of the issue, I gather picks up the shares and wins control of the company. Hence the comments from Mr Bartholomeusz which I have quoted. It seems that Mr Elliott is pulling another swiftie on his shareholders, similar to the swiftie he pulled when he issued shares to himself, paid up to one cent, which then attracted fully paid bonus shares at some later point.

I am not sure why there is reference in the question to the FIRB-my understanding is that Harlin is an Australian company-unless, of course, it may be believed that control of the company lies substantially in Monaco, which of course is Mr Elliott's favourite tax haven. However, I shall refer that part of the question to the Treasurer for his advice.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CHINA STEEL CORPORATION: INVESTMENT IN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer him to the possible investment of about $4 billion by China Steel Corporation in a steel mill in Australia. Is the Government prepared to acknowledge that investment from Taiwan is welcome in Australia? Is the Government prepared to protect, from the People's Republic of China (PRC), assets owned by the Taiwanese Government in Australia?

—Of course the Government welcomes foreign investment. Foreign investment proposals, wherever they come from, are subject to the same scrutiny. Proposals such as that mooted by China Steel Corporation, of which I have some knowledge, would normally be approved. There is no basis for the suggestion that such an investment would be at risk through claims by third parties. Investment of this kind from Taiwan is welcome and is in accordance with our constructive relationship with the PRC. In so far as investment protection is concerned, I am advised that an investor from Taiwan is accorded exactly the same protection under Australian law as any other corporation or investor.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR REFUGEES: NAMIBIAN REPATRIATION PROJECT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It refers to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) Namibian repatriation project. Has the UNHCR called for voluntary contributions of $38.5m to meet the cost of the project? Has Australia contributed? If not, are we planning to contribute and, if so, how much?

—The UNHCR launched an international appeal for $38.5m back in January to repatriate and support an estimated 58,000 Namibian refugees, mainly from Angola but also from Zambia and other countries. The Australian Government has provided $500,000 towards this appeal. The Government has a continuing interest in a peaceful resolution to the situation in Namibia and will keep under review the question of providing further support.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. I refer to the Whitlam Government's decision not to grant an end of war list of military decorations for individual acts of bravery by Australian armed forces personnel in Vietnam who were overlooked during the war. The Senate, by passing the war crimes legislation last year, established the principle that time should not be a barrier in seeking justice for victims of war atrocities. The principle should also be adhered to in seeking just recognition of acts of valour during war time. Will the Minister recommend approval for an end of war list?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —A decision was taken not to have an end of war list. That part of Senator McGauran's question is correct. Unfortunately, it is about the only part of his question that is correct. To explain it all requires some little detail, but the decision taken originally was taken on the recommendation of the Department of Defence and the then Chairman of the Chiefs of Staff Committee. There were a couple of reasons for that recommendation. The Vietnam conflict itself differed from other wars in that the Australian commitment there did not end in a decisive result. In fact, we still had troops there at the time of the request. Secondly, there was no evidence that insufficient awards were available during Australia's commitment in Vietnam. The proposition that there should not be an end of war list was endorsed by Mr Lance Barnard, a member of the Whitlam Government, but only after it had been endorsed by the Fraser Government and by the Minister for Defence in that Government, Mr Fairbairn.
—Lance Barnard did not endorse it after the Fraser Government.
—I should say the McMahon Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Lewis interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the Fraser Government, the McMahon Government. There has been no Service proposal since then for that decision to be reviewed.
—What a dreadful statement.

—When it comes to things dreadful, Senator Walters has the market cornered. Given the reasons for the original decision, having been taken by a Liberal Minister at the time, the current Minister for Defence Science and Personnel sees no reason to review that decision. It should be noted that even if there were an end of war list it would not guarantee anyone an award. Its establishment would not make that guarantee in any event.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Consistent with commitments made by the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the former Governor-General, the Prime Minister and the current Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to establish an endangered species unit within the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, how much of the $2m recommended by the Endangered Species Advisory Committee to initiate a national strategy for endangered species and their habitats has been made available to the ANPWS? Which priority programs identified by the Advisory Committee-that is, research and survey work; a nationally networked database; an education and publicity program; and a national network of non-government organisations-have been set up and staffed? If some of the priority programs have not yet been established, when will they be? Finally, will the Endangered Species Unit receive the resources necessary for a Director and support staff consistent with the commitments given by this Government or will it involve the secondment of staff and resources from other ongoing programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of parts to Senator Vallentine's question. The Government does recognise the need for something to be done to take action to save those species of Australian plants and animals which face extinction. Unfortunately, there are many of them. I will not be so unkind as to carry on with the comments of some in the Opposition about the endangered species closest to us. They were referring to Senator Vallentine but there are a few others who I can think of, such as Senator Hamer and Senator McGauran. But I digress.

ANSWER.PARA: Since European settlement almost a tenth of Australia's terrestrial mammals have become extinct. Another fifth are considered to be endangered. I know the situation is no better for plants. Almost 4,000 species of plants are now listed as rare or threatened. Following staff reallocation and refocusing of endangered species activities in the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, a unit has been established. Interviews have been held to select the head of the unit, and three staff have so far been allocated to it. Some time ago I appointed the Advisory Committee to which Senator Vallentine referred. It includes representatives from State governments, the scientific community and conservationists. I met with them during April. We discussed at that time a national strategy for the conservation of endangered species. They know of my support for their work. That Committee, as Senator Vallentine has pointed out, has set down a list of objectives that it believes ought to be met and the funds that it believes are required to meet those objectives. I am in the process of addressing the question of funds. During Budget discussions I know that I will receive very strong support from my colleague Senator Walsh in my attempt to do justice to the cause.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. Can the Minister tell me what is the position in regard to Australian Federal Police duties at overseas and domestic airports? Do members of the Australian Federal Police remain in their jobs or is the Government going ahead with contracting out their jobs to State police?

—I have already answered this question in response to Senator Archer only a few weeks ago. My answer was to the effect that the Government some time ago received a report compiled by Mr Holdich, from the then Department of the Special Minister of State, on counter-terrorism in Australia. He pointed out that it would be far better for the ready response of sworn police officers to an incident at an airport if those police were subject to one line of command. In any case he pointed out that we are not often engaged in those sorts of incidents, which are mercifully rare. He suggested that police forces at airports are clearly more akin to those engaged in ordinary community policing activities in jurisdictions which surround the airports. For those reasons it makes good sense that the uniformed police officers undertaking these duties at airports be subject to the same command as the State or Territory police force surrounding them. May I just interpolate that the non-uniformed Australian Federal Police courts watch function will continue and bears no relation to this particular matter.
—I am talking about the uniformed police.

—As far as the uniformed police are concerned, the Prime Minister has written, I believe, to all Premiers indicating that the Federal Government wishes to enter into discussions about the transfer in accordance with that report's recommendations of uniformed policing functions to the States and to the Northern Territory. That series of discussions will be undertaken. At the meeting of the Australian Police Ministers Council held last Thursday in Adelaide, this matter was raised and discussed between the Ministers concerned. They indicated that those discussions should take place over the next several months, which is exactly what is happening.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NORTHERN TERRITORY: ABORIGINAL SACRED SITES LEGISLATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Is the Minister aware that on Tuesday of this week the Country Liberal Party (CLP) Government of the Northern Territory introduced into the Northern Territory Parliament over 60 amendments-comprising 22 pages-to a Bill to protect Aboriginal sacred sites in the Northern Territory? Is he further aware that these amendments, which in fact redraft the Bill, will proceed through all stages of the Northern Territory's Parliament today? Is he further aware that these amendments to redraft this Bill were introduced without the slightest consultation with the people most directly and, I might add, adversely affected by this legislation-the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory?
—It sounds like ATSIC.

—On that point, is the Minister further aware that this reprehensible action by the Northern Territory Government is hot on the heels of a 12-month examination of Federal legislation by a committee established by the CLP's representative in this chamber, Senator Grant Tambling?
—Humbug!

—It is absolute humbug and hypocrisy-the honourable senator is quite right. Is the Government concerned with these developments in the Northern Territory and is it monitoring the progress of this legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Tambling asked me a question about the status of this legislation in the Northern Territory House of Assembly.
—You cannot pass a legal opinion here in Question Time.

—I am not going to give a legal opinion. I was asked about the status of this legislation in the mind of the Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I think the general tenor of the question was whether in fact the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs approved of the legislation. I indicated that we were taking an interest in that legislation, as one would expect, and that the consultation between Mr Manzie and Mr Hand had been going quite nicely until Tuesday when, as was indicated again in the question by Senator Collins, I believe some 60 amendments, running to 22 pages, were introduced into the Northern Territory Parliament. That was done without-I think this would be conceded-the very necessary consultation with those very people in the Aboriginal community in the Northern Territory who would be affected by those changes.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to some of the interjections, I believe that the Senate plays a very useful role at times in being something of a restraint on an over-enthusiastic government in the lower House. Indeed, in Queensland, and now in the Northern Territory, we have evidence of what happens in a democracy where there is only one chamber of parliament monitoring the actions of a government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Australian Capital Territory?

—I do not want a Senate in the Australian Capital Territory-that would be too much to bear. Nevertheless, it is a fact that the total lack of consultation in relation to these many pages of amendments is at odds with the Opposition's campaign against the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation. I would say that the long period of consultation which was afforded by the operations of the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, which looked at that legislation, indicates the sort of procedure that might usefully be adopted by the Northern Territory Government and Parliament in relation to this matter. It may well be that Senator Tambling and Senator Collins, in a bipartisan way, might suggest to the Northern Territory Administration and Parliament that some such committee be established to look at the many pages of amendments-22 pages of 60 amendments-so that consultations can take place over an extended period. I do not mean to drag out this point, but such a process could be carried out in such a way as to enable consultation not only with the Aboriginal community but also with other interested and affected persons in the Northern Territory.
—They gave two years notice of these Bills.

—They did not give two years notice of the 60 amendments; I do not think even the honourable senator could claim that. I hope that those consultations, which are necessary to the passage of good legislation, can be undertaken and, as I say, perhaps the model of the Senate Select Committee would be a good one.

—My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations relates to the recent loss by Australian wheat growers of a $2m wheat sale to New Zealand to United States traders, an earlier lost New Zealand sale to Turkish traders and the loss by CSR Ltd of a gypsum sale to New Zealand. Is the Minister aware that these lost sales are a direct result of both additional costs and shipping delays caused by the trans-Tasman freight agreement between Australian and New Zealand maritime unions, allowing only Australian and New Zealand crews to operate across the Tasman, and which now threatens the $24m wheat trade with New Zealand? Is the Minister further aware that, despite the fact that no local shipping was available in these recent examples, the Australian Council of Trade Unions delayed so long in agreeing to waive the agreement, as sought by the Australian Wheat Board, that the sales were lost to the United States and Turkey? When will the Government act to stop this industrial blackmail which keeps freight costs to New Zealand artificially high by excluding competitive shipping, while at the same time it is exposing Australian wheat growers to greater competition? How long can the Government turn a blind eye to this cosy union deal which threatens significant export income at a time when the Government is presiding over a disastrous balance of payments performance?

—I am not familiar with the considerable array of detail the honourable senator gave in his question. I will try to obtain some advice from the Minister for Industrial Relations as quickly as possible and provide the honourable senator with an answer. I must say that I will also provide a more detailed answer on some of the assumptions in the honourable senator's question relating to the competition which exists in regard to the trans-Tasman route.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. Has the Minister read the report in the Melbourne Age of 23 May about concern expressed at the Australian Police Ministers Council (APMC) meeting about the increasing rate of car theft in Australia? Can the Minister inform the Senate of the details of the proposed national blitz on car theft and how this campaign will be coordinated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the article to which Senator Zakharov referred. It is headed `Car Theft: A racket with thriving profit margins', and indeed that is the case. The Australian Police Ministers Council, meeting in Adelaide, was, of course, much interested in this matter because most of the participating jurisdictions are those of State governments and the question of car theft is, of course, high on their law enforcement and political agendas. This is particularly the case in New South Wales where the number of cars stolen and not recovered is exceedingly high. Indeed, I believe some 15 per cent of stolen vehicles are not recovered within a week. It is in relation to that 15 per cent, of course, that most concern is expressed because they are reintroduced into the system either as reregistered whole vehicles or as component parts due to the stripping and the conversion of the parts.

ANSWER.PARA: The Ministers were most concerned at the assessment by police forces that a significant component of thefts of unrecovered vehicles is conducted by organised groups who make very considerable profits from their activities. It is not just a question of a spur of the moment decision by people seeking to take a car for a short time. Notwithstanding consideration of this matter over some time in a jurisdiction by jurisdiction way, the APMC was convinced that nothing less than a totally coordinated effort against all aspects of the problem of organised motor vehicle theft is required. That coordination is required because, if one jurisdiction deals with the matter in a strong way and perhaps puts special vigilance, supervision and surveillance on panel beating shops and so on, the car subject to the theft can be transported across State borders or, indeed, into the Northern Territory.

The Council discussed this matter at its meeting last week in Adelaide. The report concluded that law enforcement agencies cannot be expected to be successful in their efforts against organised motor vehicle theft if holes remain in key areas of the system outside their control. Indeed, there are matters which have to be taken into account by licensing and registration authorities and not merely by police forces and those involved in the law enforcement community. Thus, for example, it is recommended that registration procedures be standardised across all jurisdictions. That would embrace a number of matters and factors, including registration records containing both engine and chassis numbers as prime identifiers. That would be only one part of the uniform registration process which is recommended by Australian police Ministers. It was recommended that the registers of encumbered vehicles should be made compatible between jurisdictions. That would obviously be an important step to take. It was also recommended that component identification on new vehicles be introduced; that the vehicle identification number be stamped directly on the vehicle chassis; and that the establishment of wrecks registers of repairable and non-repairable vehicles be looked at.

The opinion of the New South Wales Police Minister, Mr Ted Pickering, who has taken a very keen interest in this matter, was that perhaps the single most important thing that could be done would be the introduction of component identification on new vehicles so that each component could be readily identified. At the moment that does not occur, as I understand it, in relation to vehicles produced for domestic sale within Australia. Mr Pickering commented that cars produced for export from Australian factories and manufacturing agencies have this component identification stamped on them. There seems to be a disparity which requires some explanation. Nevertheless, the Council has appointed a working party, headed, I think, by Mr Ted Pickering and supported by representatives from three jurisdictions, to implement the recommendations of the APMC. I believe this matter of great importance to Australians with regard to the safety of their motor vehicles will be very speedily attended to.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: IMPORTATION OF PIG IRON FROM SOUTH AFRICA

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Peter Baume asked me a question about South Africa and sanctions. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a detailed response to that question.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SOUTH AFRICA: SANCTION: SORELMETAL

I would like to reply to Senator Baume's question yesterday asking why an exemption was granted to allow the importation of a particular pig-iron product from South Africa when, he claimed, there are two other satisfactory sources, Norway and Brazil.
The importation into Australia of iron and steel products from South Africa is prohibited under Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations.
In November last year, an application for exemption from those regulations was received from an Australian importer to allow the import from South Africa of a product known as sorelmetal.

Sorelmetal is the brand name for a high purity, low manganese iron product used in the foundry process to stabilise very large iron castings required, in particular, by the mining industry. It is manufactured by a Canadian firm with plants in Canada and South Africa.

The producers of sorelmetal advised the importer that the Canadian plant's output had, through heavy demand, become fully committed to the North American and European markets and that they would have to obtain their supplies from the South African plant.

Australian foundry industry stockpiles of sorelmetal were expected to run out in about March 1989. Seventeen Australian foundries depended to some extent on sorelmetal and six, employing some two to three thousand people and including the largest producers of cast iron products, were critically dependent on it.
If these producers of cast iron were unable to meet orders for heavy equipment, other industries, including the mining industry, would be adversely affected.
The application by the importer was considered by the interdepartmental committee established in December 1986 to examine representations made by Australian companies for exemptions from sanctions.

After seeking advice from the foundry industry and information from relevant Australian missions overseas, the committee concluded that, while alternative products to sorelmetal might exist, their suitability to the Australian industry still needed to be closely and objectively assessed
that the alternative products, even if suitable, might not be available where their production was geared to local and existing markets
and that, at that stage, the serious short term supply problem for the Australian foundry industry could not be resolved without recourse to South African supply.

On the basis of the committee's recommendations, I decided on 5 March 1989 to allow the industry as a whole a one-off, nine month exemption to permit the import from South Africa of a quantity of sorelmetal, not to exceed 4500 tonnes.

In notifying the industry as a whole of my decision, it was made clear that the government would not be prepared to consider any further exemption unless it was totally satisfied that there was no alternative to the importation of sorelmetal from South Africa.

On 8 May 1989 my department was advised that another Australian importer had located two alternative sources for the supply of products which they considered suitable, one in Brazil and the other in Norway
Both alternatives had previously been considered by the committee. At that time, however,
supply of the Norwegian product had been affected by a recent fire at the plant which produced it
further analysis was required to determine the extent to which the Brazilian product would meet the Australian industry's needs.

I am pleased to learn that sources for the supply of alternative products may have become available and this new situation will obviously be taken into account in any consideration of extending the one-off short-term exemption already granted the industry, should such an extension be sought.
I do not, however, see grounds for revoking the present exemption given that

it was originally granted to allow time for importers and industry to identify and prove the suitability of alternatives to the import of sorelmetal from South Africa, which they now appear to be actively pursuing
I am advised that importers have already entered into contractual arrangements with South African suppliers on that basis.

It was always envisaged that economic sanctions would entail some degree of sacrifice in Australia, and exemptions to the customs regulations are only granted in the most exceptional circumstances, as in the present case.
The Government remains firmly committed to the sanctions measures it has adopted to increase pressure on the South African Government to bring about the end of apartheid.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to standing orders 401 and 402. I have noticed an increasing tendency for these standing orders to be disregarded. Standing order 401 says:
