DEBATE.TITLE: COMMANDER OF THE MULTINATIONAL FORCES: SINAI

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to Order of the Senate relating to questions on notice, I again ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, Senator Richardson, for an explanation why a question that I asked on 3 March 1989, Question No. 859, concerning the position of Commander of the Multinational Forces in Sinai, has still not been answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rang the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, about this matter just prior to the start of Question Time today. I was not surprised when Senator Newman got up and asked this question. She is entitled to an explanation because the delay has been extraordinarily long. The explanation that I was given by the Minister for Defence was that the answer was sensitive to security.
—How could that possibly be sensitive to security?

—May I finish answering the question? I was told by the Minister that the answer had gone to Mr Beazley's office. He has cleared it and it has gone back to the Prime Minister's office for final approval. We expect that that approval will come either today or tomorrow. I am very confident that we will have the answer to Senator Newman's question by Question Time tomorrow.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR DEFENCE AND MINISTER REPRESENTING THE MINISTER FOR DEFENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in view of the persistence of low professional morale amongst the Australian defence forces under this Government and in view of the significance of Australia's role in international peacekeeping activities, the Senate censures the Minister for Defence and Senator Richardson for their joint failure to answer a straightforward factual question about Australia's important role in leading the Multinational Forces in Sinai and calls on the Ministers to provide a detailed answer to the Senate not later than three sitting days after today-that is, Monday, 29 May 1989.

The reason for moving this censure motion is that this is not a security matter. There is nothing that is sensitive to security in the question that I asked the other day. It is simply that the Government would be embarrassed by giving the answer to the Senate. Sadly, I am not prepared to take any notice of what the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) is now promising. He promised on 3 May that he would get the answer to me the following day, so why should I take his word now? Let me repeat the question so that the Senate can decide whether the question is a matter of security. Clearly, he is not going to stay to defend himself; he is embarrassed. This Government has no concern about defence matters. It will only talk. When it comes to action, it is not interested in that. The defence forces of Australia would like an answer to this question as much as the Senate would. The question was:
(1) Was Australia offered the opportunity to provide a senior Army officer to become Commander of the multinational forces in the Sinai.
What is high security about that? I asked secondly:
(2) Had approval been given for this appointment when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) vetoed the appointment.
What is high security about that? The question continued:

(3) Has the appointment now gone to Lieutenant General McIver of the New Zealand Defence Force; if so, will the Minister advise why the Prime Minister has denied an Australian the chance of such valuable experience when it was at no expense to the Australian taxpayer.
What is high security about that, for goodness sake? Finally, and very importantly, I asked:
(4) Were considerations of Defence Force morale and Australia's international role as a promoter of peace ignored.
Minister for Defence

The answer is, of course, yes, but why will the Government not answer? It is not a question of top security; it is a question of the Government's red face and nothing else. Mr Beazley should be censured because he has failed to provide an answer to a question which I asked on 3 March. The order of the Senate is quite clear on this matter: there should be an explanation given if an answer cannot be given within 30 days. We are well past that. Senator Richardson should be censured because he failed to provide an explanation of any kind or to honour the promise he made to me and the Senate in this place on 3 May. Senator Richardson tried to tell the Senate on 3 May that Mr Beazley received the answer in his office on 21 April, and he promised that he would bring me an answer the next day. He also has to be censured because he has been misleading the Senate and has failed to keep his promise to the Senate. It is just excuses, excuses; there is no explanation.

This matter may not seem to be of vital national importance. Of course, in the world scheme of things, it is not, but it is important on two grounds. It is important to the defence forces of Australia because it goes to the heart of their morale. It shows whether this Government is interested in the forces and in showing the flag in a meaningful way or whether it just sends them off to do the dirty jobs. It is meaningful as to whether a top Australian was going to represent this country as head of the Sinai Force. We know very well that the morale of our Defence Force is already suffering because of this Government's inaction. Here is a classic example. It is a question of an Australian not getting a job that could perfectly reasonably be filled by an Australian and whether the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) vetoed the appointment. Clearly, the job has gone to a New Zealander. Why? That is the reason it is important to the defence forces.

This matter is also important to the authority and the status of the Senate. This Government continues to treat the Parliament with utter contempt. This is but one more example. It has long been the habit of the Government to hide information on defence matters. I know that Senator Ray, being a Minister who attends Estimates committees, is not all that enthusiastic about the willingness of the Department of Defence to answer defence questions. At the moment we are facing a situation where the Department will be looking at when it is going to get its money in the additional appropriations. It has had 120 questions outstanding for over 30 days from Estimates Committee D. A great wad of answers arrived at my office last night after I had spoken in the second reading debate on the Appropriation Bills about the Opposition's position on unanswered questions. Again, five minutes before Question Time today another wad arrived. I think Senator McGauran has about 29 questions that have not been answered yet, and about 14 questions of Senator MacGibbon's and mine have not been answered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three now.

—Where are the others? Are they on their way? I appreciate that, but of course I do not have them yet and we are meant to be debating the committee stage today. This action is unsatisfactory in its entirety. It is designed to give as little information as possible as late as possible so that matters that might be raised in the answers cannot be treated in an effective way in the Parliament. It goes again to my argument that this Government has allowed the Department of Defence to continue this habit of hiding from the Parliament. As honourable senators know, often the Defence Department hides behind security grounds, so I was absolutely fascinated to find that Senator Richardson was telling the Senate that such a straight forward factual question, which required only a straightforward factual answer that had no security implications whatsoever, could not be answered speedily because of high security reasons.
—Senator Richardson is feeling pretty insecure.

—Senator Richardson and the whole jolly Government should be feeling pretty insecure. It is not just the current Senate that has had this trouble with the Department and the Government that is supposed to manage it. I remember Senator Sir John Carrick nearly tearing his hair out while questioning Defence officials on a number of occasions, when they were allowed to obfuscate and hide behind all sorts of excuses as to why they would not be accountable to this Parliament. At the Estimates committee hearing in October last year I asked a very simple question-I would have thought it was pretty direct-on how many matters concerning defence allowances were sitting in the Department of Industrial Relations awaiting determination. I knew there were about 150. In reply I was given a very small table with about a dozen items on it and I was told that the table covered matters in the process of negotiation only--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I did not intervene earlier when Senator Newman went on to mention Estimates committees, because it fitted part of a pattern that may well sustain an argument to deal with the failure to answer a question on notice. But now Senator Newman is extensively going into matters other than the question on notice. I have allowed some leeway on that but I think we are progressing into territory not covered by this particular motion.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I understand that there is a censure motion before the Chair. If Senator Ray read his Standing Orders, he would know there is no restraint on the subject matter covered in a censure motion.
—I ask Senator Newman to confine herself to that motion she moved.

—I believe that in covering the issues that I have, it all goes to establishing a pattern that shows this Government is not prepared to inform the Parliament of what is going on in the Defence Department. The subject of the motion goes very much to the two Ministers who are responsible to the Parliament for the Department of Defence. Therefore I just repeat that the hair-splitting example that I was giving about the involvement of the Department of Industrial Relations was that it did not include matters which are the subject of policy advice or clarification; requests for policy changes which have not yet been responded to; agreed matters awaiting determination; or case work. It is just another example of what this Government allows the Department of Defence to get away with, and perhaps even what suits this Government for it to get away with.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not satisfied that this Government is prepared to be accountable on the subject of its management of defence. The example I have raised today over the Sinai commander is yet another example. In the questions that we have been waiting for answers to in recent days, we have asked about some pretty important matters-such as conditions of service, injuries to service women and fraud in the Department of Defence. What could be more important than the allegations of huge fraud on the Department? We have asked about the contracting arrangements of the Department, Bendigo Ordnance Factory matters and Project DESINE. Project DESINE is a contract worth $400m over five years. There are a huge number of questions hanging over that, yet the Department does persist in dawdling there and the Government allows it to get away with it. There seem to be an enormous number of problems facing the people of Australia, the Parliament and the defence of Australia all relating to Project DESINE. Yet here we find the Government doing its utmost to hide the answers that the Parliament requires on that matter.

I do not intend to delay the Senate much longer. We have certainly had many examples of the very questionable advice that the Department has given to this Government. For instance, Mr Beazley was given the most awful advice as to the need to reorganise the Department of Defence as per the report from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the management of Australia's defence. Mr Beazley, on the advice of his bureaucrats-who would be most affected by it-rejected that report. Mrs Kelly, brand new in the job and shouting off her mouth, came out with a totally inaccurate series of statements in the early days of her responsibility for that portfolio, based, I am sad to say for the poor woman, entirely on briefings which she had received from officers of the Department. Mrs Kelly also got a pilots retention bonus through the Cabinet on the advice of her officers. Just this week we have had yet another example. Mr Beazley is claiming that on the advice of his officers he is getting rid of the Chinook helicopters. There are many more examples; I have just picked out a few recent ones. I believe they are evidence of why this Government is being so obstructive of parliamentary scrutiny with its refusal to answer questions.

Clearly the Defence Department and its Ministers have an empire to protect. They have backsides to defend and the Ministers are just putty in the Department's hands. This Department has a budget of approximately $8 billion but it is very much a law unto itself. It considers itself not accountable to the taxpayers who provide that money. Minister Beazley has kept very quiet. He is allowed to visit his hardware, inspect his toys and have a play in the sandpit. Minister Simmons is just kept under lock and key in case he says something meaningful. But there really is nothing meaningful he can say, because he does not have the resources to do anything meaningful in his area. This Government simply does not have the will--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Again I have allowed a fair degree of latitude, but now the honourable senator is moving on to criticism of Mr Simmons and others. It really has to be kept somewhat relevant to the question before the Chair-which we have finally got a copy of.
—I ask Senator Newman to confine her remarks to the motion that she has moved.

—Thank you, Mr President. I am happy to stay on the motion that I moved, because it is a very serious motion. It concerns the failure of Minister Beazley and Minister Richardson, who are both responsible for defence matters in their respective Houses, to keep the Parliament informed. It is very difficult for Ministers to keep the Parliament informed when they are so snowed by their Department that they cannot perform even if they wish to. I believe that in some cases their wishes coincide with the Department's. As I said, they all have backsides to protect and the Ministers are but putty in their Department's hands. So the Government's and the Department's purpose is served by continually failing to answer questions. The Senate will no longer allow this to continue. As I said earlier, to servicemen this is a symbol of the lack of concern for their status and their professionalism. In fact, they regard it as a direct insult to that status and that professionalism. To the Senate it is an example of the Government's continuing treatment of it.

SPEECH.PARA: If I had more time and if Senator Ray was not so anxious to intervene, I could give some examples of Senator Walsh's attitude to giving answers to the Senate and his attitude to Senate committees. But to keep to the point at hand, I believe that this motion should be supported because these Ministers have failed to provide an answer to a question which was placed on notice on 3 March. It was received in Minister Beazley's office, by Minister Richardson's own acknowledgment, on 21 April and it was promised to the Senate by Senator Richardson on 3 May. It is now 25 May, and the Senate will not stand for this contemptuous treatment any longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman has achieved the distinction of moving the weakest censure motion in the history of the Senate. I will start with the first problem with the motion. We are acting under a sessional order. I think it was first moved by Senator Macklin. Senator Newman was given permission to move her censure motion on the basis of that motion. The motion is in several parts. I will read part (c) for the benefit of the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: In the event that the Minister does not provide an explanation, the senator, may, without notice, move a motion condemning the Minister's failure to provide either an answer or an explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you read it all?

—The reality is that Senator Richardson provided an explanation. He may not like the explanation and will always argue about whether it was the best possible explanation or whether it excused the Department of Defence. Nevertheless, under the sessional order under which we operate, part (c) is triggered only when a Minister does not provide an explanation. I think it is always of slight concern that, having provided an explanation, somebody can be censured, without notice, and then have to defend the matter. That is the first point to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, Senator Richardson, in his explanation, indicated that the answer would be provided tomorrow. One has to be rather unkind and say that this was all pre-planned. It did not matter what Senator Richardson's explanation was, he was going to be censured. It was not in accordance with this sessional order, either in the letter or the spirit. It was a pre-devised tactic to move a censure motion on Mr Beazley and Senator Richardson. Senator Richardson said that the answer would be provided tomorrow. Yet we have had to have this particular motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —How often do we believe him-every day?

—We get this heckle and jeckle from Senator Newman. I am going to give this explanation whether she intervenes or not. It was ironic that I was approached during Question Time and asked whether the rest of the questions on Estimates Committee D could be answered. During Question Time we were endeavouring to relay messages to try to get those answers.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a situation where, firstly, I argue very strongly that this motion is not in accordance with the sessional order. Secondly, the motion censures Senator Richardson and others for not providing answers. Here we have the classic case of Liberal amnesia. Maybe I was lucky or maybe I was unlucky to be in opposition in this chamber. Many of my colleagues have not been. I remind Senator Schacht-Senator Foreman was here with me-of the amount of unanswered questions we used to get when we were in opposition. It was far worse than anything that exists today. I used to put many questions on notice but my colleague Senator Bolkus used to put in many more. Most were never answered. That was not the fault of the then Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, who always tried to chase up Ministers to get their responses in on time. In relation to Estimates committees, there has been a quantitative change and hundreds more written questions are put on notice now. I will be in the same position as Senator Richardson one day because there are certain questions I will refuse to answer when it amounts to a massive cost to the taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no cost in this.

—I am not saying that there is. I am saying that in certain circumstances I will refuse to make the taxpayer pay for the cost of answering some of these questions. I only wish that one was not bound to Senator Newman by the privacy of discussions with her own colleagues about the relevancy of her questions at Estimates committees. One must have some honour in politics. I cannot repeat them here.
—That is the cheapest shot in the book.

—It is a true one-cheap, but true. We are now facing, without notice, this monumental censure motion of two Ministers over one question, the answer to which will be provided tomorrow. Big deal! All Senator Newman is doing is devaluing censure motions by bringing up a trivial one like this.

SPEECH.PARA: On the substance of the question, certain serious matters are raised. Not on all occasions do even those opposite expect questions to be answered within a month but they expect an explanation as to why they are not answered. Given the difficulty we had today in getting the questions answered by the Defence Department I would have thought that a more prudent course would be to allow Senator Richardson and others to pursue them with more vigour. I acknowledge and place on the record that Defence is not the best department for providing answers. That is my own experience. It has also been Senator Richardson's experience. It is very difficult when one is a Minister representing another department to be continually chasing matters up like this while doing one's other duties. The Defence Department will have to lift its game in answering questions on notice, either at the Estimates committees or those asked in the Parliament. I hardly think that fact allows for the successful carriage of a censure motion.

In conclusion, Senator Hill asked me to read the whole of the motion. I have read it but I still do not believe that a motion moved under part (c) can be justified when an explanation is given. It was not as though we did not do it because we were too busy. A full explanation was given as to where the question was at and it was stated that it would be answered tomorrow. I would understand it a little more if the Opposition, having raised the matter today under this sessional order, had pursued it if it had not got the answer by tomorrow.

I do not wish to detain this chamber any longer on this trivial matter. I believe that in the context in which it has been raised and on the basis that the answer was to be provided tomorrow it is not only trivial but also a waste of the Senate's time. It debases and devalues the purpose of a censure motion. If someone is to be censured I would have thought it should be taken seriously. We on this side of the House cannot take this matter seriously. This does not deflect from the fact that answers should be provided as quickly as possible. I concede that it is desirable to answer all questions as quickly as possible. I exempt from that category ratbag complex questions the answers to which would cost the taxpayer a fortune. We were as guilty of asking these questions when we were in opposition as the present Opposition is. I am not trying to moralise from that point of view. Maybe Gordon Scholes had the right idea. When he provided answers he also provided the cost of answering the questions. Some of those questions quickly evaporated in those circumstances. I see my colleague, who is about to be reprimanded here, has come back to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —He can't take it. He pretended he was not even listening yesterday when he was getting a serve. Don't you remember that?

—Senator Richardson would never have to go to see his Deputy Leader and say, `It is time to march on because I have the numbers'. Senator Alston was so weak that he was bluffed out by Senator Lewis. He was so weak that he was done over by the old bull from Richmond-the bloke whose father taught him everything he knows because he learnt his lessons in the Labor Party. That is why we like him so much. That tough old bloke over there did Senator Alston like a dinner. He should not start calling Senator Richardson a wimp. He would have to be the biggest wimp in history to try to pull that trick. I really should not be sucked in by mediocre interjections from those opposite. I was trying to keep my comments relevant, but now I am falling into Senator Newman's trap of irrelevancy.

SPEECH.PARA: To summarise the arguments, firstly, I still maintain that this is not a proper motion. It has not been moved under a proper head of power in respect of Sessional Orders. Secondly, on the basis that Senator Richardson was going to provide the answer tomorrow, one could have well delayed such a motion. Thirdly, I have at least put on record-and I have done it seriously-that there can be criticism of the Department of Defence in its response to questions. Senator Richardson had the matter relating to the Estimates Committee brought to his attention again today in the middle of Question Time. He has addressed and pursued that matter to such an extent that 153 out of the 156 questions have now been answered. I am sure that he will be pursuing it with ever greater vigour because when one is a Minister representing another department one does not want to get stuck with the blame for its failure to deliver. I am certain that Senator Richardson will be having a word to the defence forces in general and the Department, telling them to hurry up-as I had to do when I represented Defence in this chamber-and to get the answers in on time and to ensure that they are satisfactory. I thought I saw some improvement in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have slipped back since you left.

—I do not know about that, but I thought we saw some improvement in that regard for a while. If it is not up to the mark, we must ensure that it gets up to the mark, simply so that we do not have to go through these boring, dreary, trivial, nothing censure motions.

—I will be brief. The Australian Democrats will support this censure motion which we do not regard as trivial. In September 1988, Senator Macklin moved for the adoption of a sessional order after some considerable deliberation in our party room as to whether it was required. That sessional order focuses on the issue of evasion. Frankly, we see that as being the essence of the sessional order. I am convinced by only one of the arguments advanced by Senator Robert Ray; namely, that in the past it has been possible and, to a degree, the practice for the considerable cost and time involved in assembling information to be provided with some answers. This certainly is not true of the questions which are the focus of this censure motion here today. They are not questions which would have taken a long time or involved great expense to answer. We have been advised on two previous occasions that the answer would be given in a short period and it has not. It seems to us that the issue is one of evasion. The essential thrust of the sessional order is to prevent such evasion and we will, therefore, support the censure motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly to the censure motion. I would like to recapitulate the sequence of events. On 3 March 1989 Senator Newman asked a question of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). She raised the matter on 3 May in the Senate. She said quite clearly and unambiguously why it was important that the question be answered. The answer that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) gave her was, quite frankly, contemptuous.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to move to a point raised by Senator Robert Ray. Order of the Senate No. 1 in today's Notice Paper, states:
Questions on Notice-

(1) That, if a Senate Minister does not answer a question on notice asked by a Senator within 30 days of the asking of that question, and does not, within that period, provide to the Senator who asked the question an explanation satisfactory to that Senator of why an answer has not yet been provided-
Certain consequences ensue. The answer given by Senator Richardson clearly was not satisfactory to Senator Newman. That is why we are in this position today of debating this motion.

I do not wish to take up any more time of the Senate, except to touch on a few key points. The Senate is very jealous of its right to have questions answered. The specific question here is a proper, legitimate question. Senator Newman was asking why a senior Australian Army officer could not command the Multinational Forces in Sinai. She also asked whether the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) intervened against the recommendation of the Department that the officer be appointed. That is a very important question. If the Prime Minister intervened, why did he do so? Why did he intervene in the face of professional advice?

This is not the first time that the Prime Minister has come in when personal matters have been involved. He came in on the VIP aircraft acquisition decision. The Royal Australian Air Force recommended one brand; the Prime Minister, in a state of sublime ignorance, decided that the aircraft needed three engines-he is so precious that he feels safer with three engines. He does not know that by having three engines there is three times the risk of engine failure than there is with one and that the economics get all out of kilter because fuel consumption, maintenance and everything else goes up.

What are we looking at here? Are we looking at something that is an extension of the hidden subsidies that are going to the New Zealand defence forces because of the failure of this Government to support ANZUS with our recalcitrant colleagues? What is the effect on the Australian defence forces themselves? What we are saying to the men and women in the Australian Defence Force is that we cannot produce a lieutenant-general who is good enough for the post. This is happening in a force which is shattered through the massive resignation rates and the neglect of this Government. With an expenditure of about $7 billion a year and a Defence Force of over 70,000 men and women and about 30,000 reservists, we cannot find one lieutenant-general to fill an international post. What sort of effect will that have on service morale? The absurdity of the situation is that we have 44 two-star generals and above in Australia-far more than we ever had at the peak of the Second World War when we had about a million men and women in uniform. That is the importance of this question.

The specific question is important but the larger issue is the accountability of the Executive Government to the Parliament. That is why Senator Newman is so right to push this point, having given due warning to Senator Richardson. It is not right for Senator Ray to claim that Senator Richardson can hide behind the privilege of being the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. When he accepts his commission as a Minister and the secondary role of representing a Minister in the other place, he accepts the obligation on behalf of all of us in the Senate to see that the Senate's interests, as part of the Government of Australia, are represented. He has a great obligation to meet those responsibilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to Senator MacGibbon that I take my responsibilities in this place seriously. Despite what he may say, being a Minister representing another Minister has its share of difficulties. When the matter about the lateness of the answer to the question was first raised by Senator Newman, I stood up here and gave the advice which I had been given, which was that the answer would be forthcoming the following day. Someone intervened for that not to happen. That someone was the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who, not unreasonably, given that he was the subject of at least part of the question, wanted to be satisfied with the answer. So the answer was taken to his office. One of the first things I asked when I entered my office in Parliament House at the beginning of this week was, `What happened to this question?'.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledged when I spoke before the censure motion was moved that it was quite reasonable for Senator Newman to be concerned. Because I believed that there was reasonable concern, my office checked with Mr Beazley's office. We have been chasing this matter ever since. With no idea that Senator Newman would move this motion today, I rang Mr Beazley just before Question Time and sought an answer from him as to why it still was not here. I wonder what more Senator Newman or the Australian Democrats can expect from a Minister in this chamber representing a Minister in another place than that. The reality is that it is not possible to get something approved by the Prime Minister, particularly in answer to a question, at a moment's notice. Prime Ministers do have other things to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could have brought an explanation to the chamber.

—It is because I believe that Senator Newman was entitled to an explanation that I asked Mr Beazley before Question Time today. That is exactly why I rang him. I understand what Senator McLean said today. If that is the will of the Democrats, so be it. It places upon Ministers representing an extraordinary burden, one which they cannot possibly meet. Obviously one does not get this problem with questions that come from my Department. It is sometimes difficult chasing Defence. On this occasion, it was a matter of chasing not only Mr Beazley's office but also the Prime Minister's office. What more could I have done? In reality, I did all that could be reasonably expected of me and more. In that respect I have absolutely nothing to be ashamed of.
—So the Prime Minister has?
—No. I have already said that he has not.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Newman's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present a report entitled Drugs, Crime and Society, together with the transcript of evidence. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
The past year has seen a growing debate on the question of the alternatives to the present policy of prohibition in respect of the illegal drugs.
In Britain the economist has advocated a relaxation of the present policy to `get the gangsters out of drugs'.

In the United States hearings have been held in Congress on the issue and in this country a former Deputy Commissioner of Police, in the State of Victoria, Mr Paul Delianis, has suggested that at this time there is a case for making the presently illegal drugs available under strict government control.
This report is going to prove a disappointment to those who expected the Committee to recommend sweeping changes to the present laws.

The Committee believes there is ample evidence that the present policy of prohibition is failing to achieve its objective; namely to reduce the use of those drugs which are presently illegal while preventing supplies of such drugs reaching those in Australia who may wish to use them.

The illegal drugs are available throughout Australia for anyone who wants them, although at prices often artificially inflated by the illegality. The market for illicit drugs is a demand market-that is, those people who desire to use illicit drugs seek out the supplier and create the market by their own demand.

For many years governments have attempted to use the criminal law as a means of reducing supply to the market place. This report clearly demonstrates that such an approach has limitations and in so far as its stated aim is to prevent illicit drugs from reaching the market place it has demonstrably failed.

Evidence before the Committee demonstrated that illicit drugs are available in Australian gaols in all States. If it is not possible to keep illicit drugs from Australian gaols, how is it possible to keep the supply of illicit drugs from the streets in our major cities?

Those who would seek to increase penalties and to have a greater emphasis on law enforcement need to produce evidence to justify the effectiveness of that strategy. The reality is that there is no country in the world which has been successful in preventing supply from reaching the demand market in those societies.

This is not to say that law enforcement has not a major role to play in the illicit drug market. The Committee has found that Australian law enforcement agencies have been more successful in making seizures than they have been given credit for, but even the agencies themselves agree that they cannot stop all drugs from reaching the market place.

Seizures do not represent a loss to importers of the street value of the drugs quoted in press reports but, rather, the purchase price of the drugs in their country of origin. For example, the present cost in Asia of a kilogram of number 4 heroin is $15,000. Recent newspaper reports of a successful interdiction by the Australian Federal Police Force of some 60 kilograms of number 4 heroin put the value of that heroin at $60m. Frankly, this is a nonsense. At $15,000 a kilo, the cost to the importers of that interdiction is some $900,000 at cost, plus the cost of importation into Australia.
In addition, the importing group has lost the services of some middle range dealers and suppliers in Australia.

The experience of law enforcement agencies throughout the world is that the interdiction of a particular importation is immediately replaced by another importation to ensure that supply is readily available on the market place.
The evidence suggests that no special expertise is required to enter the trade so that even if agencies succeed in arresting major traffickers there will be others ready to take their places.
Moreover the more successful law enforcement is, the greater the profits will be for those prepared to enter the trade.

The Committee acknowledges that, by raising the price of the illegal drugs and making access to them risky and difficult, the present policy of prohibition deters new users who might be attracted to these drugs if they were as readily available as alcohol and tobacco. It also encourages heavy users to consider treatment and abstinence because of the cost and difficulty of maintaining a habit.

However it achieves these effects at a considerable cost to the users themselves and to society. The Committee estimates the direct annual cost of drug law enforcement at $123m. The users of heroin in particular resort to crime to support their habits. The community bears the cost of drug related crime through increased insurance premiums and increased security for their homes and business premises.
Users seeking to buy drugs are brought into contact with a criminal subculture and may progress from using cannabis and pills to the use of heroin.
The illegal drug trade is violent because it takes place outside the law and the profits to be made corrupt law enforcement agencies.

The high cost of illegal drugs means that many users prefer to inject them, thus gaining the greatest effect from a small quantity of the drug. Carried out under insanitary conditions this has obvious health risks and it also leads to needle-sharing, spreading hepatitis-B and AIDS. The illegal drugs are adulterated with substances including talc, glucose, strychnine and arsenic, posing further dangers to users' health.

Prohibition has eroded accepted civil liberties. Prosecutions depend on informers and the law bears most heavily on the young and the poor. Prohibition also means that the illegal drugs are not available for medical use.

What are the alternatives to the present policy? The Committee does not believe that increased penalties are a solution. The last two decades have seen a steady increase in the maximum sentences for drug trafficking in this country with negligible effects. Decriminalising the cultivation and distribution of cannabis for personal use would diminish the illegal market but there would be no quality control and no control on underage use.

Prescription of heroin to dependent users might ease their health-related problems and draw them into counselling on needle-sharing and treatment programs but it would leave occasional and new users still seeking their supplies on the black market. Making the presently illegal drugs available under strict government controls with a ban on commercial sale and advertising would eliminate many of the costs of the present policy. At the same time it could lead to a dramatic increase in the use of these drugs and a consequent increase in health problems.

There is no easy solution. Each option involves trade-offs between costs and benefits. The Committee emphasises that the present policy results in an absence of government control over the chemistry of the drugs being sold, the outlets where the drugs are sold and who the drugs may be sold to. The Committee therefore recommends that the community give earnest consideration to options by which governments might impose more controls on the sale and marketing of the presently illegal drugs.

Besides calling for more accurate statistics the Committee proposes that the Commonwealth Government should set targets as indicators of the success of its latest initiatives in curbing the drug trade. Should these initiatives fail to make significant inroads on the market then the Committee suggests that it would be appropriate to consider some relaxation of the present prohibitions as an alternative policy.

In the meanwhile the majority of the Committee recommends a ban on all advertising of alcohol and tobacco products. The Committee was told that young people are faced with conflicting messages as to the acceptability of drug taking. We attempt to convince them that drugs are harmful but at the same time they are bombarded with advertisements promoting the use of alcohol, tobacco and certain pharmaceutical drugs. The Committee believes that the continued promotion of alcohol and tobacco in particular undermines the credibility of the attempt through the national campaign against drug abuse to reduce the consumption of the illegal drugs.

I place on record my appreciation and the appreciation of the Committee for the assistance provided by our secretary, Giles Short, our research assistants, Rosa Ferranda and John Carter, and steno-secretary Chris Migus.

The report commands the attention of the Parliament and of our community. In order to diminish the harm caused by the use of illegal drugs we all need to expand our own horizons and to look at the problem honestly.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

Motion (by Senator Richardson) agreed to:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That these Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
HORTICULTURAL LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

The Bill amends the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987, the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Act 1987, the Horticultural Levy Collection Act 1987 and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987.

The purpose of the Bill is to provide additional charge and levy collection arrangements under which horticultural industries are able to participate in the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation through product levies and export charges.
Two problems have arisen with the current arrangements.

Firstly, some industries, such as the nursery industry have confirmed their willingness to participate in these Corporations. However, there proposed levy and charge collection arrangements cannot be accommodated under existing legislation.

Secondly, more cost effective collection arrangements have been identified for some industries already participating under the Corporations but again these cannot be implemented under existing legislation.

At present, in order for the better securing of levies and charges on horticultural products, amounts are paid to the Commonwealth on behalf of the producer or owner of prescribed horticultural products by the first purchaser, selling agent or exporting agent as the case may be.

This arrangement is satisfactory where there are a relatively few first purchasers and agents. However, this structure is not the case for some horticultural products and alternative cost effective collection arrangements have been developed in consultation with industry.

Under these proposed arrangements, amounts on account of levy and charge will become payable at the point of purchase of prescribed goods and services used in the production of horticultural products prescribed under the amendments. The point of collection will be moved forward in the production and marketing chain to a point before the product being levied has been actually produced.

The sellers of these goods are services will be obliged to pay the amounts on account of levy and charge to the Commonwealth, but only after they have in turn received payments of the amounts from the purchaser.

If, however, the purchaser does not intend to produce leviable or chargeable horticultural products with the goods or services purchased it will be possible for them to seek an exemption from the requirement to make payment. Refunds of amounts paid will also be possible under certain situations.

The nursery industry has advised that it wishes to participate in both the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Research and Development Corporation. Its proposed collection arrangements will be based on the purchase by industry members of containers such as plastic pots used in the production of potted plants, which will be prescribed as the leviable or chargeable horticultural product.

The blueberry industry has confirmed that it wishes to participate in the Australian Horticultural Corporation only and has suggested a similar collection arrangement involving the purchase by blueberry growers of cartons in which fruit is packed for sale.
The operative rates of levy and charge applicable to nursery product and blueberries and other administrative matters regarding the manner of payment will be set down in regulations.

I am particularly pleased to see that these industries have decided to join these Corporations, which were established principally to assist horticultural industries to develop their potential in export markets.

Exports are fundamental to the further development of the horticultural industries. These industries will come under increasing pressure as production rises above the capacity of the domestic market to absorb it, and as competition from imports increases. This competition will occur as a result of such factors as the development of quarantine protocols, and the Government's commitment to the freeing of agriculture and other trade through multilateral trade negotiations.

It is therefore imperative that horticultural industries develop a commitment to export, through marketing; through the development of quality produce; and through a commitment to sustain long term production for export.

While the response needs to come largely from industries themselves, the Corporations are well placed to act as catalysts is this process. The Government is to contribute $7.1 million over five years to assist the Corporations in their early operations. The apple and pear and citrus industries have participated in the Corporations since their inception and the addition of other industries will assist in the longer term industry funding of them.

It is expected that the amount raised under the nursery industry levy and charge will be approximately $750,000 per year, rising to $1 million within the first few years. Amounts equal to half of the total raised are expected to be directed to the Australian Horticultural Corporation and half to the Research and Development Corporation. The Commonwealth will match expenditure of industry moneys identified for the latter body dollar for dollar, up to a limit of 0.5 per cent of the average gross value of production of the nursery industry.

Amounts raised by the blueberry levy and charge are expected to be approximately $150,000 per year. This will have no financial impact on the Commonwealth as all proceeds will go to the Australian Horticultural Corporation. This body is to be fully funded by amounts by levy and charge, and fee for service.
I now turn to the second main purpose of the Bill, that of providing alternative collection mechanisms for industries already participating in the Corporation.

These amendments will provide for the Commonwealth to enter into an agreement with a State or Territory in order to provide for State and Territory authorities to collect horticultural levies on the Commonwealth's behalf.

This arrangement will have particular application to the citrus industry where it will lead to significant reductions in the cost of collecting levies and charges. Levy and charge payers will, under the proposals, be able to make payments to State citrus boards at the same time as they make payments of State levies.

This will provide for substantial economies of scale in the administration of levy collections. In areas where there are no State boards or where a State elects not to enter into an agreement with the Commonwealth, the present arrangements whereby payments are made directly to the Commonwealth will continue to apply.

In addition, provisions in the Bill will allow persons having responsibility for levy and charge collections to receive payments from the Corporations to offset costs borne by them in the collection process.

The Corporations will be able to enter into agreements with these persons on payments of costs. It is expected that they will first need to consult with individual industry bodies on the payment of levy collectors for that particular industry levy or charge. Funds for such payments would be expected to be drawn from the relevant industry accounts of the Corporations.

Finally, the Bill amends the search warrant provisions of the Horticultural Levy Collection Act and the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Act. These amendments refine the powers of authorised persons in relation to entry of premises and provide for seizure of evidence of the commission of an offence.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
HORTICULTURAL LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1989
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Horticultural Levy Act 1987 to increase the maximum rate of levy.

The Horticultural Levy Act 1987, together with the Horticultural Levy Collection Act 1987, provide for the imposition and collection of a levy on prescribed horticultural products produced and sold or used in Australia.
Currently, the Horticultural Levy Act 1987 sets the maximum rate of levy at 2% of the annual average unit gross value in relation to the classes of horticultural products covered by these Acts.
The funds raised are to finance the operation of the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation.

These Corporations are an essential element in the Government's strategy to enhance the capacity of the horticultural industry to expand exports. They provide the mechanism for this sector to realise its full export potential through coordinated and sustained activity both in horticultural products marketing and in research.

Industry, notably the apple and pear sector, have requested the maximum rate of levy be increased from 2% to 5% with a view to possibly increasing levies to support these Corporations' future activities.
This Bill reflects industry's wishes in this regard.

Operative rates will continue to be set by Regulation under the Horticultural Levy Act. Total amounts of levies to be collected will rise over the next few years as the number of participating industries increases, and as the rates themselves rise as determined by the participating industries.

Funds raised through increased levy receipts in respect of the Australian Horticultural Corporation will have no financial impact on the Commonwealth. This is apart from the $5.85 million to be contributed by the Government over its initial 5 years of operation. All operating and administrative costs of the Corporation are to be fully funded by levies from industry and fees-for-service.

Additional funds raised through the increased levy receipts in respect of the Horticultural Research Development Corporation will be matched by the Commonwealth, on a dollar for dollar basis, up to a limit of 0.5% of the average annual gross value of production of groups of products.

The extent of the Commonwealth's contribution to research will thus depend on the number of industries which agree to participate in the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation and the rates, up to the maximum, at which they are prepared to fund Corporation research activities.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
HORTICULTURAL EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1989

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Horticultural Export Charge Act 1987. The Horticultural Export Charge Act 1987, together with the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Act 1987, provide for the imposition and collection of a charge on the export of prescribed horticultural products.
The funds raised are to finance the activities of the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation.

This Bill is the companion of the Horticultural Levy Amendment Bill 1989, dealt with earlier. Whereas the purpose of that Bill was to increase the maximum rate of levy on prescribed horticultural products produced and sold or used in Australia, this Bill increases the maximum rate of charge payable on exports of prescribed horticultural products.
The maximum rate in both cases is increased from 2% to 5%.
There are no financial implications other than those covered in the Second Reading Speech for the Horticultural Levy Amendment Bill 1989.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF CRIMINOLOGYAnnual Report 1987-88CRIMINOLOGY RESEARCH COUNCIL

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Senator Hill:
That the Senate take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I want to put my comments in the context of the National Committee on Violence, which was set up by the Government, in its own terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Having regard to the increased incidence of violence crime in Australia society and the need for better understanding of the problem and improved methods of combating violent crime . . .

One may well ask why that task is not being addressed by the Australian Institute of Criminology or the Criminology Research Council. The reason, regrettably, is that they have been starved of funds. Appropriations for the Institute of Criminology in 1988 actually fell in real terms. If we go back to the previous annual report we find that the board itself found it necessary to comment on difficulties arising from the Government's financial constraints. The Criminology Research Council is half funded by the Commonwealth to the extent of a miserly $125,000, and the funding has not been adjusted for inflation, contrary to the undertaking given previously by the Government. So the two principal research bodies in the area of criminology are inadequately funded and are therefore unable to deal adequately with this very major problem of violent crime. If we go down the burrow a little further we find that of the 114 projects contemplated since the Council commenced operation in 1973, only 10 are directly related to crimes of violence. Of the 25 projects currently in progress, only three would appear to involve at least some consideration of family violence.

The Opposition believes that the low priority that the Government is giving to the issue of violent crime in our community, as evidenced by its attitude to funding of these major bodies, is to be regretted. One would have hoped that the Government, when it set up the National Committee on Violence as a separate committee to look at this question and gave it massive terms of reference, would have learnt its lesson and provided adequate funding.

The Committee is obviously designed to serve some political purpose, but, regrettably, when it comes to the job in hand, the funding that it has been given is totally inadequate. It has been promised funding of $120,000. According to its terms of reference, working from research, the Committee is to examine the economic, social and psychological context of violence, to see whether there are links between violence and alcohol and drugs, and to look at the effects of mass media upon violence. It is a massive subject. The Committee is expected to travel around Australia to investigate this question. It has already had to produce working papers, which are good papers, contributing to public knowledge of the subject. The important point is that it is impossible for a body of this type to carry out the functions that it has been given with the funding that it has been given. The Government will tell us that we always say that funding is inadequate. We say that it is a question of wrong priorities. This Government can spend $40m on an unnecessary referendum while failing adequately to fund bodies that are looking at the level of violent crime and what actions can be taken to remedy this totally unsatisfactory situation. I use this opportunity to express the regret of the Opposition.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Senator Short:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have often spoken in this chamber on the urgent need to reform Australian shipping and the waterfront. The world does not owe us a living, and unless we improve the productivity of our manufacturing sector and our transport sector we are doomed to a very difficult future. It is not that Australians cannot be productive. Per capita, our primary producers are the most efficient in the world. But in areas such as shipping and the waterfront, our record is absolutely deplorable. Our shipping will never be competitive, no matter what we do about reducing manning levels and bringing conditions into line with those of the rest of the community and other richer Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries. That will not be effective unless our ports and our waterfront are cleaned up as well.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not for nothing that our ports have earned the reputation of being the worst in the developed world. We must tackle the problems of both our shipping and our waterfront. We cannot afford to have one waiting on the other like Admiral Sir Richard Strachan and General the Earl of Chatham waiting to launch an invasion during the Napoleonic wars. It was well summed up with the words:
Chatham, with his sabre drawn,
Stood waiting for Sir Richard Strachan.
Sir Richard, longing to be at 'em,
Stood waiting too. For whom? Lord Chatham.

The way this Government operates, everything is waiting for something else and nothing ever comes out at the far end. We must tackle all these problems separately and urgently to attain a coherent end.

What do we need on the waterfront? It is a formidable list. Other countries can do it; why cannot we? We want company employment. We want involvement by the workers in the enterprise through profit sharing linked with company employment, so that employees have some interest in the enterprise. We want proper casual employment, which all other businesses in Australia have, but which is denied to our waterfront. Employees have to be taken from a pool controlled by the Waterside Workers Federation (WWF). We want a single union in each work place, not five or six, with demarcation disputes and one union causing trouble and bringing the whole lot to a shambling halt. We must have competition between stevedoring companies. Competition is without doubt the key to efficiency. We must end the problems of port control and tugs. Finally, and most important of all, we must achieve reliability. The thing that destroys our exports is our reputation as an unreliable supplier. People will not put up with it and will go somewhere else. We have no unique supplies. If we cannot supply reliably, we will not be chosen as the supplier.

We now have the Inter-State Commission report on the waterfront. It has made some useful recommendations, but it has gone nowhere near far enough. Before the ink on the report was dry, the waterside unions began to lobby the Government to reject or modify many of the recommendations for reform. The unions do not want company employment, though they are perhaps prepared to wear it. But they are not prepared to end the monopoly of the WWF in all ports. They want to fight that to the death. They certainly do not want any sensible system of casual employment. The other issues just are not tackled at all.

The Government has to make a decision very soon. But will it decide anything useful? This Government has failed totally to tackle the micro-economic reform. During the six years of this Government, our productivity overall has not risen at all. Not only are we not catching up with the rest of the world but also we are lagging further and further behind. Unless the Government is prepared to take on these issues, we will get into deeper and deeper trouble. The world does not owe us a living. We have to earn it through work, and efficient work at that.

I would like to see some sign that the Government is prepared to take on the unions to get industrial efficiency. It is perfectly prepared to take on people such as the wheat growers because the wheat growers do not vote for the Government. But, as soon as it comes to an important issue to be tackled, where the unions are involved, the Government always behaves like a bunch of wimps. This is much too serious. We have to tackle these issues, we have to tackle them soon, and we have to solve them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Senator Hill:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The National Crime Authority (NCA) is one of the principal bodies in this nation established to combat the scourge of organised crime. I want to put my comments on its annual report 1987-88 in the context of some highly unsatisfactory developments that have been occurring recently, it seems, in the relationship between the Government and the NCA. The first of those developments became evident when we read in the press that Mr Justice Vincent of the Victorian Supreme Court had been approached to be the new Chairman of the NCA. I would have thought that, concerning an appointment of that sensitivity, it was a highly unsatisfactory press report to be reading. It obviously was a leak that had come out of the Government in some way, and it did no more than discredit the NCA. The matter deteriorated even further because, within a few days, we read that the ultimate successful party, a Melbourne Queen's Counsel, had been approached to be Chairman of the body. We read that he had been approached in fact to be a part time member of the NCA, but had refused because he believed that he was being offered the job of Chairman. We read all this in the press. The matter deteriorated even one step further because, when the Government could not find a judge to do the job-which we also learnt, through the press, that it was seeking-it approached the same person to take on the job as Chairman, and he accepted. So he is Chairman on the basis of his first having misunderstood the offer that was made, and now, knowing that he was far from the first choice of the Government and further that he was chosen eventually only because the Government was unable to find a judge to perform this function. Obviously this body has a need to be kept in high credit in the eyes of the Australian public and it cannot maintain the sort of reputation that it is slowly developing if it is to be treated with such disrespect by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise another couple of matters which are equally unsatisfactory. On 30 June this year the three longstanding members of the NCA will all retire. Apart from the member who has been appointed to the recently established Adelaide office, there are only three members and they have been there for some considerable time. The total knowledge and experience built up by Mr Robberds, Mr Clark and Mr Justice Stewart will be lost on one day. Therefore, there will be no continuity. I would have thought that that is a major deficiency and something that the Government should have looked to remedy by legislation if necessary rather than have a situation where there will be no continuing flow of information at the level of the three permanent members of the Authority. I put that concern on the record.

The other matter that I find disturbing is that we also learn through the press, as we seem to learn everything in relation to the NCA, that part of the package that has been negotiated with Mr Peter Faris, QC, the new Chairman, is that the head office of the NCA will be moved from Sydney to Melbourne to accommodate him. At what cost that will be, we do not know. At what cost that will be in terms of disruption of the workings of the NCA and at what cost it will be in terms of disruption to the lives of employees of the NCA living in Sydney, with their families living in Sydney and their children attending schools in Sydney, we do not know. Rather than learn of these matters through the press it is time that we learnt them from the relevant Minister in this chamber. We heard the rationale of the Government for making these decisions which, on the face of them, are highly disturbing.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Senator Jenkins:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I wish to add a few remarks to those made previously on the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission annual report 1987-88. It is stated in the report that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . greater public awareness of human rights issues will eventually lead to the elimination of discriminatory practices.
The stated objective therefore of the Commission is:

. . . to promote the acceptance and observance of human rights and equal opportunity in Australia by developing public awareness of these rights through public inquiries, community education and complaint resolution.

Two major inquiries were conducted by the Commission during the review period. One of those had considerable debate in the chamber yesterday. That was the one on homeless children. The other one was the Toomelah report, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Report on the Problems and Needs of Aborigines living on the New South Wales-Queensland border. That report was launched at Toomelah on 15 June last year. The Commission is to be commended for having launched both of those very important reports.

The Commission states that it receives numerous inquiries on a variety of issues. One series of inquiries concerns prisoners' rights. With regard to prisoners' rights, recent publicity over deaths in custody has revealed that prisoners are not always granted the right to prompt and proper medical attention when imprisoned. I draw the attention of the Senate to the statistics in Western Australia alone, where they are quite appalling. Of the 73 deaths in custody since 1980-34 Aboriginal and 39 non-Aboriginal-around 50 per cent were associated with inadequate and/or tardy medical treatment for accident or illness. Unfortunately, those facts have not always been brought out properly and completely in the coronial inquiries because, under the coronial system in Western Australia, policemen in the case of death in police custody or prison wardens in the case of death in prison custody are not obliged to give evidence. There are signs that some States are making changes in this direction. I would welcome such a change in my home State of Western Australia.

The report also has a section on complaints tendered to the Commission in the area of immigration. Very often these deal with very basic human rights. I draw the attention of the Senate to the proposed immigration legislation which will shortly come before this place. It has been criticised very dramatically on the basis of very basic human rights. In this context I draw to the Senate's attention the Convention and Protocol Relating to the Status of Refugees that we have signed in Australia. Its provisions say that it is our duty not to impose penalties on account of illegal immigration or presence in certain instances. There is no guarantee in the legislation to come before us that we will uphold those particular guarantees. Under the provisions of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 the Secretary of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs will have no choice but to order deportation of a refugee who is an illegal entrant and who has outstayed the period of grace to a country where that person has a well-founded fear of persecution. According to the legislation as it stands now, that order will be non-revocable. Deportations such as the one which I have described would be quite plainly contrary to conventions to which we are a signatory.
I commend this report to the Senate. It is a very full report. It analyses and brings before us the issue of human rights, which must be of concern to us all.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LAW REVIEW COMMITTEE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the motion that the Senate take note of the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee annual report 1987-88. I do so in the context of being aware that the Parliament is finally taking a much greater interest in the area of corporate law reform than it has for a long time. As honourable senators would be well aware, committees of this Parliament are looking at particular questions in relation to this subject matter. For example, the Senate's own Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee is looking at the question of directors' responsibilities; a committee of the House of Representatives is looking at the question of insider trading; and a Joint Select Committee of the Parliament looked in depth at the Government's corporate package, reported back and greatly facilitated the passage of that legislation within the last week or two.

SPEECH.PARA: But the body that has principally had the responsibility for advising in the area of corporate law reform since the setting up of the cooperative scheme in 1983 has been the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee. I believe it has done a good job and deserves credit that perhaps it has not been given. Many of these bodies exist in the Commonwealth structure to advise government and advise the parliaments. They perform admirably but are not recognised for the work that they do. This body has been provided with six terms of reference: the corporate form itself; disclosure and standards of conduct of directors and officers; the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Act 1980; appeals under the cooperative scheme legislation; optional incorporation of accounts; and prescribed interests. A number of the Committee's recommendations have already reached the form of legislation. One immediately thinks of the Close Corporations Bill which we passed the other day and which I understand was based largely on a report of this body.

I want to recognise the contribution that this body has made under the cooperative scheme and to indicate that the Opposition is appreciative of the work that it has done, an area of work in which I believe the Parliament itself should have been more active in the past but where it is finally better meeting its responsibility.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Community Law Reform for the Australian Capital Territory

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments in relation to the motion to take note of the report of the Australian Law Reform Commission on community law reform for the Australian Capital Territory. Provided it is the report that I think it is-this brief description does not give full details-it is the third report in relation to the Australian Capital Territory, that dealing with enduring powers of attorney. It is the Law Reform Commission's report No. 47. This is another area in which an important body, the Australian Law Reform Commission, has undertaken work on behalf of the Australian community for which it receives, regrettably, little recognition.

SPEECH.PARA: Law reform in the Australian Capital Territory is important. The Australian Capital Territory not having had self-government in the past and having only just got self-government, areas such as law reform, where the States have a more direct input and can establish law reform commissions of their own, have had to be met by the Commonwealth. Unfortunately, I regret to say that the Commonwealth has not always well met its responsibility. The Australian Law Reform Commission has stepped into the breach in that regard and has put down a number of papers on areas of reform in relation to Australian Capital Territory law. This particular one, as I said, deals with enduring powers of attorney. As far as the ACT is concerned, this reform is long overdue. This matter has been the subject of reform in various States.

The recommendations included in this report for the establishment of enduring powers of attorney seem to me, on their face, to be sound. Certainly I hope they will be debated and, after due consideration, adopted. It is worth reminding ourselves that the Australia Capital Territory has the fastest growing number of old people in Australia, so the subject of enduring powers of attorney is particularly relevant to the ACT. I rose not so much to discuss the content of the report, but rather to recognise the work that the Law Reform Commission has been doing in this regard and to commend that work to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
