Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The last set of instructions I was given was that the Government had no objection to the Income Tax Assessment (Tax Agents' Fees) Amendment Bill 1989 going through. Someone was supposed to look at it again but did not get back in touch with me. I congratulate Senator Watson-the Bill is about to go through.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a third time.

I thank the Senate for its unanimous support for this very important Bill which seeks to create a degree of equity and fairness in relationships between the Australian Taxation Office and the taxpayers. I wish to explain to the Senate certain arrangements that have been made with the Government. From discussions with the office of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) I have undertaken not to have this Bill introduced into the lower House until the Budget session to enable the Government to make certain amendments which, in effect, will widen the scope of the legislation. I therefore thank the Government for its support and its undertakings of what it intends to do in relation to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have been more appropriate if I had made these remarks in the second reading debate but the Bill came on more quickly than I expected. Senator Watson has spoken to me and to the office of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I want to confirm what he has already said in his broad outline-that is, that the Government is in the process of completing its own review to permit taxpayers to deduct the cost of professional advice when attending to tax audits, in general compliance with taxation laws, representation in taxation reviews and dispute processes and in seeking taxation advice. Therefore, we will not be opposing the Bill. The review has included a full consultation process by the Australian Taxation Office with professional accounting legal bodies and will canvass their views. The final outcome of that review will therefore reflect the needs of both the Commissioner of Taxation and the professional bodies. Whilst not opposing the Bill, the Government has not fully examined it in the context of its own review. It is likely that when the Bill gets to the House of Representatives a number of amendments will be proposed by the Government to make it more comprehensive than it is in the form that Senator Watson has proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other thing I wish to say is that there will be, of course, a revenue cost associated with the measure. It is difficult to quantify-indeed, it is more difficult than normal-because advice of the type that Senator Watson has proposed in this Bill and the more comprehensive proposal which the Government may put up by way of amendment, is already effectively tax deductable to a number of large companies which tend to have in-house people, full time employees, who provide that sort of advice to them. That makes it particularly difficult to cost. It also raises the issue-and this is one of the reasons the Government is not opposing the Bill-that the existing arrangements in that sense are more favourable to certain classes-generally larger taxpayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate my colleague from Tasmania, Senator Watson, for bringing this matter forward. Sometimes people forget that the Opposition is not just here to criticise. In this case Senator Watson researched, investigated and brought forward a Bill that will assist many taxpayers throughout Australia. I congratulate him on the amount of research he has done. I also pay some tribute to the Government for accepting what I believe is a very good proposal. We are all taxpayers after all is said and done. Having spent something like 2 1/2 hours with Mr Boucher last night going into the tax file numbering system, I can understand the massive task that the Australian Taxation Office must have not only with taxation laws but with public relations exercises. I know that Senator Watson is facing a preselection ballot this Saturday and I wish him the very best. I again congratulate him for bringing this Bill forward for the good of all Tasmanians and all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 3 May.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering clause 5, as amended, and a further amendment moved by Senator Jenkins. The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Jenkins be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of clarification, Mr Temporary Chairman: I do not think any amendments have been moved. They simply have been flagged and there has been some open discussion. Is that correct?
—I understand that Senator Walters's amendments were agreed to, so the only amendment before the Chair in relation to clause 5 is your amendment.

—I will speak in part to my amendments. I would initially like to speak to my amendment No. 3 which seeks to insert a new clause after clause 5, new clause 5a (1). If this amendment is carried it will mean that video material which is classified as being suitable only for people over the age of 18 would no longer be placed on displays in the ordinary retail and hire outlets as R-rated videos are at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been a matter of concern to a number of people for a number of years that although the law says that only people over the age of 18 should have access to these videos, that law is not kept. It is very difficult for it to be kept. So, if my third amendment is carried, it will mean that that material will have to be displayed in a separate room if the video outlet is large enough. Such video material could not be displayed at all in outlets such as local garages or local shops and their titles would have to be catalogued.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Jenkins, you are probably a little ahead of us. You have moved amendment No. 1 on your list which reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: Page 4, subclause 5 (3), line 27, leave out ``, whether or not the material'', insert ``and''.

That amendment is still before us. We will have to dispose of that amendment before we can go on to the other amendments on your list. At this stage I put the question that amendment No. 1 be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do wish to speak to that amendment. I addressed some general remarks to this matter when we previously debated this legislation. It is fortuitous that a report on video material was tabled in the Victorian Parliament today. The media reports, such as the one I saw in today's Age, on the report tabled today in the Victorian Parliament are so mixed up and full of so many conflicting statements that they cannot possibly all be true. This has brought this business to a head. I believe that we can clarify matters a great deal in a debate such as this. An article by Robyn Dickson in today's Age, headed `Report urges reforms to allow crack downs on X-rated videos', states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee was concerned about police evidence that any kind of video, including those depicting child pornography, bestiality, extreme violence, sexual violence and terrorism, could be obtained under the counter at Victorian video outlets.

Such videos are banned in Victoria. In fact such videos are banned all over Australia. They are not X-rated; they are not classified; they have no classification at all in Australia. The report goes on to say that they are banned in Victoria but they are distributed from Canberra by mail order. These are not the videos we are discussing in the Regulation of Video Material Bill 1988 which is before us. Everybody should understand that.

The Joint Select Committee on Video Material recommended, by a narrow majority, that Australia should have the category of NVE-non-violent erotica. Had that recommendation to allow videos which contained erotica but not violence been implemented, any video which currently has an `X' rating would be regarded as an illegal video. One of the problems is that X-rated videos in the United States of America and in the United Kingdom can contain not only sexual material but also violence.

This Victorian report has come out very dramatically against violence. We now have a situation in which in the States Australian X-rated videos are banned but there are criminal activities related to the production of video materials which are totally banned in Australia. Therefore, most likely it is a very different matter for the police and other people to distinguish between them. As I said before, videos such as those depicting child pornography and so on are banned everywhere and are not classified in Australia. Part of the problem is that there has been so much misinformation put out to the public that it simply does not understand these matters.

During the second reading debate I commended Senator Walters for having the courage to define explicit depictions of sexual acts in her legislation because these definitions are not available through the Film Censorship Board. It strikes me as being far more sensible to look at the definitions of and perhaps tighten up on our present X-rated videos which contain non-violent erotica-in other words, depict human actions which are lawful-so that we have total control over such material. Then it would be much easier to know when we have illegal material in this country and to cope with it properly.

I personally have no truck with the non-violent erotica type of videos. The ones that I have seen have nothing much to commend them, certainly nothing much of artistic merit. But if we were to ban them on those grounds we would be banning a lot of material that is around both on video and on our television screens. However, having said that, many people in Australia would object and do object very strongly to people standing up here and deciding what they should and should not be allowed to view when, in the minds of many people, non-violent erotica is not harmful.

This Victorian report cracked down very heavily on all forms of violence-violence on television screens, violence on the news; all sorts of violence. It cracked down primarily on violence. There is confusion in the debate because X-rated videos are linked with violence. In Australia they are not. That confusion could be solved very easily by the first recommendation of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material being implemented. I would be very interested to hear what Senator Walters has to say on these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins's first amendment does indeed liberalise the present situation. How many different copies of the amendments does Senator Jenkins have? Is it the fourth or fifth different copy of the amendment?
—There is no real change. Simply the heading has been changed-moved by me instead of on behalf of the Australian Democrats.
—Presently I have four different printings of amendments. Is it the fourth or the fifth?
—Senator Walters, the one I am dealing with-I think that is the one we should be dealing with-has `revised 2' on the top right hand corner.

—I have the revised copy, the one before that and the one before that in my keeping. So we are dealing with the fourth lot of amendments that have been revised by Senator Jenkins. As she says, the first amendment she has put up is the same in all the revised editions she has handed us but it leaves out `whether or not the material' and inserts `and'. Consequently, that scuttles the whole of the Bill as I had intended it. I am sure that Senator Jenkins just intended to include X-rated videos as they are presently classified, thus changing my section that excludes them. But she has indeed done more than that. I do not know whether she is aware of it but she has made it more liberal than the present situation. Because it would be in legislation, it would override the present guidelines. Clause 5 (3) of the Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: Without limiting the generality of subsection (2), video material shall be refused classification for any of the purposes specified in subsection (1)-
which is the one that would give the Censorship Board the right to classify them-
if the material includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults, . . . includes any depiction suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind.

That is very specific. It reintroduces the old classification of X-rated videos as we knew them when we were sitting on the Committee. But the guidelines have changed quite considerably since then. I do not think Senator Jenkins can be aware of them. The Film Censorship Board has tightened up those regulations. Senator Jenkins's amendment liberalises the guidelines as they have been put forward by the Film Censorship Board. I ask Senator Jenkins: is that her purpose? Does she intend to liberalise the present guidelines the Film Censorship Board has put out very recently-in the last few weeks?

TALK.START.PARA: —When moving my first amendment, my intention was not to ban erotic material in which there is no violence or coercion of any kind. I am firmly convinced that that will lead to criminal activities, as indeed we see is currently happening in Victoria. That is why I have moved my other amendments. I believe there should be a tightening up of the availability of both the materials and the promotional materials of the videos which are available only to people over the age of 18 years. In other words, the young should be protected from the availability of current R-rated and X-rated videos and people who find objectionable the promotional materials of both R-rated and X-rated videos should not have to be confronted with those materials and therefore offended by them unless they choose to go into areas where those materials are available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I ask Senator Jenkins: is her intention-she did not answer this-to liberalise the latest guidelines set out by the Film Censorship Board? Her amendment does that. The very recent guidelines put out by the Film Censorship Board are stronger than her amendment. Because this is legislation, it would override those guidelines. In this amendment that Senator Jenkins has put forward for this legislation, is it her intention to liberalise the present guidelines that the Film Censorship Board has recently put out?
—Is Senator Walters referring to the guidelines put out by the Chief Censor, Mr John Dickie, of the Film Censorship Board on 24 April this year?

—I am not sure of the date. Let me read from the guidelines to show that this proposal would liberalise them considerably. What Senator Jenkins proposes would result in material being refused classification:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if the material includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults and includes any depictions suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind.
Is that not right? Am I not correct in saying that classification would be refused if such material were included?

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree very strongly that videos including erotic material, violence or coercion of any kind should not be available.
—Order! We will have one speaker at a time.
—So Senator Jenkins's amendments would result in material being refused classification:

SPEECH.PARA: if the material includes explicit depictions of sexual acts involving adults and includes any depictions suggesting coercion or non-consent of any kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Senator Jenkins says, `Yes'. As I have already indicated, the most recent film censorship guidelines go further. They exclude other things that Senator Jenkins's amendments would permit. I am asking her whether that is what she intends. Her amendments would permit mild, non-violent fetishes, which are excluded by the present guidelines. It has to be understood that legislation will override the guidelines. I ask Senator Jenkins again whether it is her intention that those guidelines should be overridden by this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 5 (1) (g) of the Bill refers to

SPEECH.PARA: . . . video material that is not to be sold, let on hire or delivered to a person under the age of 18 years . . .

That would include classifications R and X under the current and updated guidelines put out by the Film Censorship Board. Senator Walters has the definition in clause 5 (1) (g). I am following her definition. Obviously it refers to video materials being allowed to be sold or hired under the current guidelines, only to people over the age of 18. If the guidelines were tightened tomorrow, the new ones would be the current guidelines. As I indicated when I spoke earlier, I believe that some of the guidelines should be tightened somewhat as they relate to some of the currently X-rated material that is available. But that is something else, and it is not dealt with in this legislation. What we are looking at in this legislation is whether currently X-rated material should be banned totally.

I have given two basic reasons why I feel very strongly against that. One of them concerns censorship. I concede that some of the depictions in X-rated material should go out, but I do not believe that we in this chamber should be making decisions about X-rated material on behalf of Australian adults. One of the first things that a totalitarian regime-whether a communist regime on the Left or a fascist regime on the Right-does is impose censorship, and one of the first things to be censored is sexual material. I personally do not want a bar of going down that track. Protecting the young is another matter; tightening up on the material is another; and being sensible and categorising material honestly as NVE-non-violent erotica-is another. But those matters are not addressed in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins and a number of other honourable senators have claimed that they cannot support my Bill because they do not believe in censorship. We have had a proliferation of some of the most extreme charges about Nazi censorship, communist censorship, and so on. Does Senator Jenkins believe in the censorship of bestiality? Does she believe in the censorship of child pornography?
—Of course.
—Senator Jenkins says, `Of course'.
—I did not say anything.
—I am sorry; I thought she said, `Of course'.
—I said, `Of course'.

—I am sorry; it was Senator Zakharov who said it. To do Senator Jenkins justice, I will wait to hear whether she believes in the censorship of child pornography. She should not make the mistake that Senator Zakharov made when she was debating this matter with me on television and say that the only reason child pornography is not permitted is to protect the child performer. That is not the case. Indeed, the Film Censorship Board made it very clear that an adult depicted as a child could not perform any acts of child pornography. That would be censored. The ban on child pornography is not just to protect the child performer; it is to censor videos depicting child pornography.
—The same as bestiality.

—I was just about to come to that. It is censorship to prohibit bestiality. It is censorship to prohibit the advocacy of drugs or terrorism. All these areas are already covered. There is no point in the honourable senator saying that her dislike of censorship drives her to oppose my Bill. It is already acknowledged, both by Government senators and by Senator Jenkins, that censorship has a place. It is freely acknowledged by the arms of the law that censorship is necessary. The evidence that we received from numerous groups all over Australia and from international groups is that continual viewing of X-rated video material has a desensitising effect, even if there is no violence, because it degrades women. While videos that degrade women continue to be produced, I do not want ever to hear the Government say that it is working on behalf of women.

SPEECH.PARA: Women's groups from all over Australia have expressed support for my Bill. Only one-a group that has something to do with science-said that it would rather proceed through education. From the extremes of both sides the women of Australia have said, `We do not want X-rated videos because they do indeed degrade women'. People are desensitised when they continually see women degraded. Pretty extreme feminists have said to me, `It is the first time I have agreed with you on anything, senator, but I agree with you entirely about this'. This has brought together women's organisations from all over Australia. Senator Zakharov shakes her head. The only group on which she can rely-and it is no use Senator Ray encouraging her to get on her feet--

TALK.START.PARA: —I had asked her not to speak but, after that, I am saying that she can.

—I am just reminding the chamber that the only group that Senator Zakharov was able to bring before us as supporting it was the Office of the Status of Women. In evidence before us, the women from the Office who came before us said that they had not viewed any videos, had no intention of viewing any and would not be supporting any that depicted women being subjugated and degraded.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jenkins wants to put into legislation a relaxation or liberalisation of what is allowed in X-rated videos. She will continue to support her amendment. If the Government wants to override the guidelines of the Film Censorship Board, it will support Senator Jenkins's amendment. We have to remember that the women of Australia are feeling vulnerable. They know that rape has increased 140 per cent in 10 years. They know that severe violence has increased over 200 per cent in the same period. Women will no longer open the door, even in the middle of the day, to answer a knock. When we are campaigning, and we all go out campaigning, we realise that that occurs. As I have said in the Senate before, 14 years ago, when I first came to this Parliament, I was able to go out doorknocking, and women used to open the door straight away. Now they do not. They say, `Who is there?'. They do not trust the knock on the door. They are concerned at being very vulnerable.

How many sessions have Senator Zakharov and Senator Jenkins attended recently where instruction on self-defence has been given for women? I have attended many. In the community now, women feel that they need to take self-defence courses. We have not had this need in the community before. In the 14 years since I first came into this place, I have never had it suggested that women should attend sessions on self-defence. That is now common. All women's groups are conducting these sessions. Honourable senators might not like to acknowledge the situation and might not like it, but that is the present situation and that is what has resulted from the fact that women feel vulnerable.

All of these women's organisations have pleaded with the Government and the Australian Democrats, who hold the balance of power, to support my Bill. If the Government and the Democrats are to ignore the pleas of all of those women's organisations, I do not want to hear them in this place again talk about assisting women and helping them to retain their dignity and their methods of bringing up the Australian family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to take much of the time of the Senate, but I cannot let pass some of the things that have just been said-such as that women no longer want to open their doors in the middle of the day. Maybe they do not want to open them to Senator Walters, but I do not have any problems with people opening their doors when I am doorknocking. We had a by-election in Victoria not long ago, so I have been doing so recently. I was campaigning during the middle of the day and I had no problems with people not opening the door.

SPEECH.PARA: The figures that Senator Walters quoted are obviously those for reported rapes. Anybody who knows anything about changes in the law and in community attitudes will know that, 20 years ago and more, many rapes went unreported because of the way victims were treated by the police and other people. It was often said that the woman brought it on herself because of the clothes she wore, because she went out at night, et cetera. They are all bygone attitudes in most places and, therefore, the rate of reported rape is very much higher. The Australian Institute of Criminology will tell us that there is no hard evidence that the actual incidence of rape has risen. This is typical of the sort of arguments we get on these matters from Senator Walters.

Senator Walters claimed that every women's organisation in Australia bar one supported her point of view. That is absolute nonsense. We all know the sort of organisations that would have been contacted by the Liberal Party when raising that matter of public importance some months ago. They were the predictable organisations, such as the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association and Women Who Want to be Women-who I understand have a new name, Endeavour something; it has a membership of about 30 people. Those were the sorts of organisations contacted. Naturally the Liberal Party did not want to canvass some of the other organisations, but it is nonsense to say that all women's organisations bar one support her point of view.

They are the two main matters raised by Senator Walters to which I wanted to reply. Most of her points were not worth referring to, anyway. I wonder about the question of mild, non-violent fetishes. That is undefined and I have not had the opportunity to check out what is meant by that change in the guidelines. It could have a very wide range of interpretations. I do not think it has been tested yet and it is not a particularly relevant point to raise.

In general, I support everything that Senator Jenkins has said. For the sake of my Victorian colleagues I wish to refer to the Age article. Like Senator Jenkins, when I read the article this morning I was appalled at the ignorance displayed in it. I spent some time on the telephone talking to the secretariat of the social development committee in Melbourne, and also to the chair of that committee. Subsequently, I was able to get a copy of part of that report faxed up to me. In fact, the Age article is extremely misleading. The headlines do not match anything in the report. Much of what is in the Age report has been taken totally out of context, obviously for reasons of sensationalism. As a usual supporter of the Age, I am extremely disappointed in the way that that story was handled.

The report contains something like 26 recommendations. Not one of them refers at all to X-rated videos. The main reference in the report to X-rated videos and so on, which was the last item in the Age report, concerns a provision in the Victorian law which is interpreted as requiring the police physically to send any video which it seizes because it is believed to have been hired in contravention of Victorian law to the Chief Censor for certification of classification. Clearly, that obstructs the operation of the law because that could take up to six weeks and the same Victorian law requires charges to be laid after a period of 14 days.

I have had pointed out to me the relevant sections of that report which in any way back up the sort of claims that appear to be made in the Age about X-rated videos. The clear misunderstanding that is portrayed there, and was portrayed on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio this morning-and, to the credit of Pru Goward, was later corrected-is about the confusion which is compounded very often by those in the Opposition about what X-rated videos really are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, could I just deal very briefly with three matters? The whole question of the Victorian Age report is a reflection on the person who wrote the article, not on anyone else. I tried to get the actual report but I could not get it today; so I do not know what was contained in it and whether it did or did not refer to X-rated videos. I assume that it did not and that the media report incorrectly titled it.

SPEECH.PARA: But that is completely beside the point. Let us deal with what this material does contain. The amendments by Senator Jenkins are to gut the Regulation of Video Material Bill 1988 in respect of the intention of Senator Walters in moving the legislation. The intention is to gut the Bill so as to enable the continued availability of material which is officially described as hard core pornography. That is what Senator Jenkins is saying. I do not know about the other Democrats. The material is officially described in the explanatory memorandum as hard core pornography. The decision by Senator Jenkins to amend Senator Walters's Bill will have the effect of entrenching hard core pornography in this country.

There is no need for me to go over the type of material that is contained in X-rated videos. It is unfair for Senator Jenkins to say that by a narrow majority the Joint Select Committee on Video Material decided on non-violent erotica, implying that the majority wanted the current X-rated material to go into a new category of NVE. That was not so. The majority of the Committee expressed its view to the contrary. The majority response to that NVE proposal, on page 302 of the Committee report, stated:
1. Recommendation II proposes that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current classification of X.

2. We, the majority of the Committee, strongly oppose that proposition. It would entrench X-rated pornography (described officially as `hard core pornography'-see paragraph 3.40) in the community under the guise of the misleading title of NVE.

I also want to say-and I beg the Committee to accept this-that last time we were on our feet there was a reference to the fact that the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association (SDA) had misunderstood what was in the material. The SDA has sent us three letters, each distinguishing X-rated videos as being physically non-violent. It is important to place that on record. That organisation knows what is contained in the video materials. The national council of that organisation expressed strong concern about the availability of pornographic video material and the employment opportunities and working conditions of that union's female members. In part, the Association indicated:

We believe that pornography which portrays women as having an insatiable sexual appetite and/or as the willing victim of sexual domination and humiliation is more dangerous to the status, rights and safety of women than material which shows women as non-consenting victims, since such material creates and perpetuates the myth that women generally are highly promiscuous and available, that they enjoy domination by men . . .

Those people knew what they were talking about. I have seen material in the X-rated category which deals with employment on the basis of the sexual characteristics of the females concerned. Is that what Senator Jenkins wants? Does she want the perpetuation of that sort of material in the X-rated category? Is she suggesting that on the one hand we condemn, quite justifiably, sexual harassment at work while on the other hand we permit this type of material to go through the Film Censorship Board without any guidelines being applied by the Film Censorship Board except that nobody punches somebody else or shoots somebody else.

I remind the Committee, when we are talking about censorship and these other issues, of an observation that was made by Dr Zubrzycki, the Emeritus Professor of Sociology at the Australian National University. He said that pornography functions quite similarly to anti-Semitic or racist propaganda in that it distorts the image of a group or class of people by depicting them as objects for exploitation. This is precisely what pornographic material does to women. I challenge anybody to get up and say that the majority of this material does not do that. The majority of this material has as its intent the purpose of making women objects of sexual pleasure for men and is intended to be a turn-on for men.

TALK.START.PARA: —And vice versa.

—Yes, there are such X-rated videos, but a very narrow band of them. The majority of them are the other way. Also, about 25 per cent have homosexual characteristics in them. I want to correct those matters that were raised. I hope that Senator Jenkins has heard what Senator Walters has said about the other implication of deleting the words concerned. I have the guidelines in front of me. Some of the people who were talking against this Bill on the last occasion did not, but I did and obviously Senator Walters did. Senator Jenkins should take to heart what Senator Walters has said about the presumably unintended consequences of her proposed amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure why I am doing this again. Neither is the Whip. Everyone groaned and said, `You are not really going to say something, are you?'. But I am, again, briefly. Like many other people in this country, I share very deeply the concerns that Senator Harradine has and even, if I really stretch it, the concerns that Senator Walters has.
—We all do.

—That is right, but it is such a difficult and subjective area. The reason that I rise briefly is that once again Senator Harradine talked about the classification of non-violent erotica (NVE) that was determined by the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. I rise to make the point again-as I did in the previous major debate on this subject-that that majority recommendation on NVE and the qualification that was then put on it by Mr Jull, who provided that majority, simply indicates the artificiality of a great deal of what has been said in this debate. The distinction was, as Senator Harradine will recall, that Mr Jull was in that same middle ground. He is not a person who supports that particular material. He would not walk across the street to watch it himself. But, because of his true liberal ideals-and, from my slight knowledge of Mr Jull, I do credit him with those sentiments-he is not a person who wants to impose more censorship and more government regulation on a free democratic people than is absolutely necessary. That is where we are all torn.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a very large collection of videos. I bring them down with me from Darwin every now and again in the Budget sessions of the Senate, and we watch them in the annexe. Very few of my videos were produced after 1960. Most of them are in black and white and star Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. If I had my choice and I were to impose my views on the world, that is the sort of movie I would want people to watch-no sex, no drugs, no rock and roll, no violence and no plots, actually. But there would be great music, great dancing, and very corny sets-wonderful stuff. I yearn for the days when that was the accepted norm-when that was what people liked to watch. That is what people like me still love to watch. I would like, if I could, to pass a law in 1989 saying that that is the sort of stuff that everybody should watch and, in fact, that that is all they can watch.

TALK.START.PARA: —Make it compulsory.
—Yes, I would make it compulsory to watch Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. But I have an emotive approach to this debate, as has Senator Harradine. I respect his commitment to this issue.
—I thought I had spoken without any emotion.

—Senator Harradine has a logical and rational as well as an emotive commitment to this debate, but I would not suggest that he would want to deny that he has an emotive attachment, as I do, to this debate. My emotive attachment to this debate is that I passionately and virulently do not want people like Senator Walters to tell me what I can read, hear and see. I may disagree with a great deal of that material, but I do not want people who have that particular view of the world telling me that I am not allowed to see, watch or listen to it. I would like, in a free society, to be able to make that choice myself.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a great deal of talk about the alleged effects of this material in terms of inciting the level of crime and violence that exists in the world today. The people who tell us this say with a straight face that crime and violence has never existed to such an extent in the world before. I must say that they have an extraordinarily warped view of history, even recent history. How could anyone who was even mildly familiar with the history of Australia say that we have only recently become a violent society? What about the First Fleeters and the conditions under which they lived in the mother country? What about the laws that were applied to them and the things that could be done and were done to them by the state as a result of laws passed by members of parliament? It could be cogently and, I think, effectively argued on many fronts that in 1989 we have, to a very great degree, become a far more civilised society than that which existed 50, 100 or 200 years ago.

The trouble with people generally is, whether or not one believes in the Christian concept of original sin, that we are pretty violent animals. We do violent things to each other, to other animals of this planet and to the environment which we inhabit. In fact, I think it is fair to say that the violence we have done to our own environment in the last hundred years can be very graphically and effectively described by a crude Australian expression which I cannot use, because it is unparliamentary-but we are in fact fouling our own nest. That indeed is a very profound form of violence. But in terms of the kind of violence that Senator Harradine was talking about-violence to women and to each other-one could argue that, if anything, at least in an organised sense, we are becoming a more civilised society.

Let me deal with the things that corrupt. This is obviously a major concern for everybody, particularly for parents. I am not suggesting that these feelings are confined to parents, but they are felt by parents, particularly parents of young children. The greatest corrupting influence on young people in this world today is, and always has been, money. As I said before in a previous debate, we are not really taking a rational approach; there is no question about that. If one talks to the people who deal with the most horrible forms of sexual exploitation, the pederasts-the people who organise themselves on an international basis into clubs; they exist in Australia, as everyone knows, and elsewhere in the world, and consist in the main of extremely wealthy and well placed people in the community-one finds that money, and the exploitation of economically deprived people by using money, is still the greatest form of corruption of youth. If honourable senators do not believe that, they should just go the Philippines. But they need not go to the Philippines; they need go only to Sydney or Melbourne. The rational way to counter that is not to ban $50 bills; that simply will not work.

The Age story has been mentioned again today. The whole point of the Age story is that the material that was described is currently, under present laws, illegal material. We should remember that before we dealt with Senator Walters's legislation, the kind of material that was being hawked around Victoria is currently banned and illegal and people can be prosecuted for trafficking in it. It has been illegal since 1984. That does not stop the traffic. No parliament can do that. As I also said in a previous debate, if the welfare of my children in terms of their moral, spiritual and physical well-being is dependent on laws passed in this Parliament, God help them.

What I am saying-and I am saying it with some feeling-is that I am personally in a very difficult position on this debate, as are many other people. But, finally, I have come down on the side of drawing a line, as everyone else does. I suppose it is fair to say that the only difference really between Senator Walters's position and mine is that I have drawn the line on one particular part of the map and she has drawn it on another. I guess that is really the only difference between us. But I have, I guess, a predisposed bias to counter and to oppose government regulation on things that we can think, see, read, hear and speak. It takes a lot of persuasion and an enormous amount of evidence to persuade me that I should change my view on that, despite what I think personally.

An obvious example is the recent movie The Last Temptation of Christ. I have certain beliefs and principles to which I adhere in my own life. I profoundly disagree with a great deal of what was portrayed in that film-and I saw it. But I would really hate to live in a society which successfully passed laws saying that I was not allowed to see it. The fact is-and Senator Harradine cannot deny it-that the people in this place this afternoon, like Senator Walters, the sponsor of this Bill, who are telling us that we cannot see this material and that we should ban it, are the same people who wanted to see that film banned and prevented from being displayed at all in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Excuse me!

—Senator Harradine can look at the Hansard; I am referring to people such as the sponsor of this Bill, Senator Walters. I do not know what Senator Harradine's position was on that film, but I certainly know what Senator Walters's position was.
—No, you do not.

—Is Senator Walters telling me that she had no objection to that film being shown? Questions were asked and petitions were laid before this Parliament by people who wanted to see that movie banned. I assumed, from the interjections that Senator Walters was making at the time, that she was very enthusiastic to see movies like that banned. The problem is that it is all a question of subjective judgment. It is all a question of beauty being in the eye of the beholder. It is all a question of who is qualified to be the censor.
—Who censors the censor?
—That is right, who censors the censors. It is the old question that is constantly asked.
—Juvenal.

—Yes. The Joint Select Committee on Video Material watched an X-rated movie along with a lot of other rubbish, called Deep Throat Two, which was produced by the adult video industry in the United States as a lobbying tool. I must say that, when the pornography was taken away from that movie, the point it made was a very valid one. It featured an American Senate committee deliberating on the question of X-rated movies. The point made throughout the movie, in which American politicians were thundering from the pulpit, `We do not think that people should see this material because it corrupts them', is perfectly true. The question was always asked, `Your committee has sat through dozens of these things. Are you now corrupted as a result?'. The answer from the politician is always `No, I am immune from that personally, but it is the ordinary people out there in the streets who will be corrupted'. Politicians of course, are a special breed who are not corrupted! There are probably as many corrupt politicians around the place as there are in the community at large. By and large, politicians are ordinary people. Some of them are very ordinary people-by and large it is ridiculous for us to take the stand that we are in some way immune from this material ourselves but that everyone else out there should be prohibited from watching it.

SPEECH.PARA: I personally draw the line on this issue in terms of the protection of young people. I come down quite happily with banning beastiality, child pornography and violence. They have all been banned and prohibited since 1984. But adult people have to have the right in the privacy of their own homes to watch what they want within those broad limits, provided that the youth of this country is protected to the maximum degree that that is possible to do so by passing laws. Despite my own personal views on the question of this material-of course, there is a very large market for it among the good burghers of the Australian Capital Territory-consistent with the recommendations of the Meese report brought down in the United States, I am perfectly happy for the elected government of the Australian Capital Territory to make the decision whether the electors to whom it is responsible can watch it or not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only thing that I agree with in what Senator Collins has just said is that this debate is all about where one draws the line and, I might say, in what circumstances one draws the line. Apparently Senator Collins is opposed to X-rated material-that is, material which depicts explicit sexual acts-being permitted for public viewing in cinemas, but is prepared to allow private viewing of such material, on the ground that it may be harmful to his and other children. That is one of the main concerns of those who draw the line at a different place from where Senator Collins draws it. In being available in private homes, this material easily gets out of control and falls into the hands of those whom Senator Collins, on his own admission, wants to protect and in respect of whom he thinks censorship is justified.
—On those grounds he would ban alcohol.

—We know that Senator Zakharov takes a much more liberal view of life than that which Senator Collins has been trying to portray. He tells us that he is a great liberal and that is why he is against censorship except in certain cases.
—Not a great liberal, just an ordinary liberal.

—I am talking about a small `l' liberal. Senator Collins has just given us a speech about how liberal he is in the social, moral sense. This debate has never been about whether there should be censorship, despite what Senator Zakharov may believe. The substantial debate has been about where one draws the line.
—We all agree on that.

—Again, I will not speak for Senator Zakharov. It is certainly not about whether we should have censorship. The vast majority of us agree that there has to be some censorship, which does change from time to time because of community standards. The question is where and on what basis one justifies censorship occurring. This is a very difficult question for people such as ourselves to decide in what is an emotive and politically charged atmosphere. In order to assist us to make the decision as to where the line should be drawn, the Senate referred this matter to a committee to see whether it was possible to get some guidance and help from experts, with scientific knowledge and experience of psychology in particular. It seems to me that the only justification for censorship in this area is whether viewing material of this kind-or hearing it-is or could be, on any reasonable grounds, harmful to other people. That is the test, and I would think that that is the test that Senator Collins adopted in the remarks that he has just made.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of going to a committee and getting an in-depth study and an expert opinion was to get some guidance on what sort of material is or may be harmful in certain circumstances. The scientific evidence that was received by the Joint Select Committee on Video Material may have differed, and certainly members of the Committee differed in their views of it, but authoritative and convincing scientific evidence was put before the Committee which pointed to the fact that, regardless of whether there is any violence or coercion in this type of material-namely, explicit depictions of sexual acts-the viewing of such material in some circumstances by some individuals could produce conduct which was harmful not only to those people but also to others. I think that what we should mostly be concerned about is not so much the effect of this material on the viewer but the behaviour which may result in certain circumstances from watching this material.

I have quoted the evidence from Professor Sheehan, a professor of psychology at Queensland University, a leading Australian psychologist who has been a member of the Films Board of Review for some years. He must be taken as an expert who can guide people such as us in coming to these very difficult decisions. I do not propose to read the evidence. I quoted some of it in my speech in the second reading debate. It is quite clear from Professor Sheehan's evidence that there is a real possibility of harmful effects occurring as a result of this material being available. Senator Walters's Regulation of Video Material Bill is simply designed to return the situation to what it was, before changes were made to the censorship laws a few years ago by the present Government. For the first time it allowed an X-rated classification for videos not for public viewing for people over 18 years of age. I find that a most extraordinary distinction for people to be drawing, as I have already indicated. For instance, does Senator Jenkins believe that it is all right to have this material in the home but it is not all right to allow people over the age of 18 years to go into a public cinema and view it? What is the difference? It is totally illogical.

I believe there is sufficient evidence for us, through this legislation, to change the situation brought about by fairly recent legislation which resulted in this particular category for application to videos only. That is the purpose of this legislation. If Senator Jenkins's amendment is carried, the whole purpose of this Bill will be completely destroyed and it will become a totally pointless exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to spend long on the amendment that has been moved. As honourable senators have correctly pointed out, the amendment would retain the status quo. Under those circumstances I think those of us who would support this amendment-I would be amongst them-believe that there is some debate as to where one draws the line, as both Senator Hill and Senator Collins have quite correctly pointed out.

SPEECH.PARA: At the second reading stage I spoke at length on the analogy with the drug trade. I think it is appropriate today to raise that issue again, because the report to which I was referring was introduced into this chamber by Senator Alston this afternoon. The report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority mentioned a number of issues with regard to the problem of drugs in Australia. In that circumstance it is probably relatively clear, unlike in this circumstance, that an enormous amount of damage is being done to the community. But what is not clear is the correct public policy stance to take with regard to that. Senator Walters's response to my comments on that were again of a simplistic kind: did I want this, that or something else. I do not intend getting into a slanging match with Senator Walters if she wants to carry on that type of hysterical debate. The debate was not about who could be more holier than thou but what in fact is the correct public policy to deal with a serious issue.

I was explaining that in the drug situation there are two legs-the supply and the demand. We spend most of our time trying to interdict the supply of drugs but very little both in time and resources in trying to do anything about demand. In this area Senator Walters is again taking on the supply exercise. The supply is there because there is a demand. I would prefer us to spend the short time that we have in this place on trying to look at why our society is demanding these types of things, including drugs. Hence, in that report on drugs, I but not everyone on the Committee recommended banning the advertising of tobacco and alcohol. I remind Senator Walters-she should have a look at that report-that we could not get everybody on the Committee to sign that, and they put in a minority report. The reason I signed that recommendation to ban the advertising of tobacco and alcohol was that last year tobacco killed 17,000 people in this country. I think the very least we can do is ban the advertising of that lethal drug, but we could not even get the agreement of everybody on the Committee for that single proposition. I am not casting any aspersions on those people. They argued their case in their minority report. However, I am saying that people with goodwill, who are trying to approach serious issues, will differ on what might be the correct public stance to take on how to deal with them.

I thought Senator Collins was spot on in his contribution, because he was talking about the type of thing I want to talk about; that is, what is the reason for people wanting these types of materials? Where should we be directing our attention if we feel that is wrong? We will be having other debates in this place, including presumably about abortion, and I am sure the same type of argument will occur. They are not easy ones to deal with. We may all agree that there is something we do not like. In fact I took Senator Collins's point that he does not agree with these videos. We do not have them in my home. I do not permit my children to watch even most of the R-rated movies. I do not permit them to attend many of the M-rated movies. I may be old-fashioned and very hard, but there is a rating provided for the guidance of the community that I take seriously, as does my wife, and our children respect that. In fact we do that even with regard to television at home. Many people in the community do the same thing. But I am not saying that such movies should be banned. They are there, and if other people wish to view them, that is their prerogative. If they wish to send their children along, I do not like that idea but that is their choice. As time goes on my children will view more of those things. We will discuss them and I hope, if our family remains the way it is and we can still talk to one another, their ideas will develop as they grow older. I am not holding that up as though I am better than anybody else, but that is what we do in my family. I do not want to go around dictating what other people should do in their families or how they should deal with these matters.

I have often said that I am not particularly interested in sex education being taught in schools. I am quite happy-and I have done this from the earliest days of my children-to conduct sex education lessons at home, for my children, as is my wife. But I am also a realist, having been in education all my life, and I know that is not something that is done by everybody in the community. Hence, I have supported sex education in schools, to provide for those children who do not have the opportunity to get that knowledge and understanding at home to get it elsewhere so that they are then able, hopefully, to react responsibly on the basis of knowledge. I find it very odd that time and time again people attack a variety of issues, and I say, `In that case, will you stand shoulder to shoulder with me? I am trying to get sex education into Queensland schools'. Then they say, `No way'. There ought to be a consistency of approach. I think a consistency of approach in terms of a liberal stance-Senator Walters is in a party which calls itself liberal-means that one needs an overwhelming reason before imposing a state directive with regard to any personal activity. We have mentioned some of those and I agree there are quite a number. Senator Walters mentioned some of them, for example, child pornography. Not one person in this place has disagreed on that. There are a whole host of others, but obviously Senator Walters would not want tomorrow's edition of the Sydney Morning Herald to be banned. She too draws the line somewhere. She is drawing it on one side on this issue and other people are drawing it on the other.

On this particular issue I think it is sensible and reasonable to do two things. The first is to allow adults to make up their own minds and to have a series of controls, which hopefully will restrict this material to adults; and secondly, with regard to the Australian Capital Territory-because a lot of this revolves around that issue-if the elected representatives of the ACT wish to prevent the sale of this material in the ACT, then they should have the power to do so. In other States the elected representatives have made that choice. Presumably, the elected representatives in the Australian Capital Territory will follow that. That will solve Senator Walters's problem. It seems to me that at the moment, due to the coming together of the Legislative Assembly in the Australian Capital Territory, and our Constitution which allows free trade between the States other States can receive the material by mail. If the Australian Capital Territory follows the States it will prevent that activity. On a number of occasions this chamber has expressed its view with regard to the general issue. I do not think that will change. However, the circumstances in Australia may very well change. That will depend upon the elected representatives in the Australian Capital Territory, not upon us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins told us about our violent history and how violent Australia has always been. He believes that we are becoming less violent as time goes on. The incidence of rape has increased by nearly 140 per cent. SPEECH.PARA: One of the causes we were given for the increase is the video viewing of excessive violence. Senator Collins also said that he would not be told by people like me what he could see. He did not say that his Government did not allow people to view X-rated videos in cinemas. DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill provides an additional weapon against potential corruption in the Australian Federal Police, increases the functions of the Australian Federal Police and improves the administration of the Australian Federal Police in a number of significant respects.

The Bill proposes the inclusion of a new Part VA in the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 which provides for existing and former members of the Australian Federal Police to lose certain superannuation rights and benefits if convicted of an offence involving corruption and sentenced to life imprisonment or a term of imprisonment longer than 12 months or, if a member is found guilty of a relevant disciplinary offence and dismissed from the Australian Federal Police, as a penalty for that offence.

The amendments provide that all contributions payable by the Commonwealth under a superannuation scheme in relation to a relevant member or former member of the Australian Federal Police shall cease, or cease to be payable, when the appropriate court makes a superannuation order. In such cases, the Commonwealth is not liable to pay any employer contributions or benefits under the scheme in respect of that person. The amendments entitle a member or former member of the Australian Federal Police to payment only of a sum equal to the employee contributions plus the accrued interest on those contributions. Similar provisions apply where a member is found guilty of a relevant disciplinary offence and dismissed from the Australian Federal Police for that offence.

The Australian Federal Police (Discipline) Regulations do not apply to the Commissioner or the Deputy Commissioners. Amendments to section 17 will enable the Governor-General to determine terms and conditions about superannuation in relation to the Commissioner or Deputy Commissioners having a comparable effect to proposed subsection 49 (2) and applying where that person's appointment is terminated because of misbehaviour involving:
(a) corruption;
(b) an abuse of office; or
(c) the perversion of the course of justice, or an attempt to pervert the course of justice.

The loss of superannuation rights and benefits are penalties for dishonest service and breach of obligation to the Crown. They are not and should not be seen as penalties for committing certain criminal offences. Part VA is not retrospective in operation. Division 2 only applies to existing or former members of the Australian Federal Police convicted after the commencing day for Part VA while Division 3 will only apply to members found guilty of relevant disciplinary offences and dismissed from the Australian Federal Police as a penalty for that offence after the commencement day.

This Government is adamant that it will not fund superannuation benefits of any kind for corrupt members of the AFP. This should be a major financial disincentive to any member of the Australian Federal Police who may be thinking of becoming involved in any corrupt activity now or in the future.

While this Bill only applies to existing and former members of the Australian Federal Police it is this Government's intention to introduce similar legislation in the Budget Sittings of the Parliament which applies to officers of the Australian Public Service, other government employees and persons holding statutory offices.

This Bill also provides for the repeal of the cumbersome redeployment and retirement provisions currently in the Australian Federal Police Act and the inclusion of streamlined provisions. The proposed redeployment and retirement provisions will enhance the efficient administration of the Australian Federal Police to the mutual benefit of the community and members of the Australian Federal Police alike.

This Bill also gives effect to the Government's decision, in light of the recommendations of the Parliamentary Joint Committee, that a national witness protection program be established. It is to be administered by the Australian Federal Police on a cost recovery basis. Section 8 of the Australian Federal Police Act is being amended to enable the Commissioner to enter into arrangements with a Commissioner of a State or Territory police force, the Chairman of the National Crime Authority, and a prescribed authority of the Commonwealth, State or Territory-other than the Australian Capital Territory-to facilitate the provision of appropriate services. The Australian Federal Police Act as currently drafted allows the Australian Federal Police to provide protection for witnesses in relation to Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory offences.

The national witness protection program will not be fully operational until a substantial number of Commonwealth, State and Territory laws are amended to facilitate the effective operation of the program. It is an important and necessary tool in the fight against organised crime in Australia, and the Government is determined to ensure its early implementation.

This Bill also contains amendments to the Australian Federal Police of a minor policy nature relating to the appointment of fixed-term senior executive officers, superannuation for fixed-term senior executive officers, prescribing fees for certain police services, the making of regulations for the advancement or accelerated advancement of a member within a rank and for arrangements between the Minister and the Administrator of an External Territory for the provision of police services in relation to that Territory. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the continuation of a grant to the Northern Territory to subsidise its electricity operations in 1989-90.

The Commonwealth Government has subsidised the Territory's electricity operations since self-government. The arrangements that commenced in 1985-86 provided for an annual indexed payment of $40m until 1988-89. This amount has applied with the exception of 1986-87 when a lower amount was paid because of reduced oil prices and budgetary considerations. The amount that was provided for 1988-89 was $50.9m.

It was envisaged when the arrangements were put in place in 1985-86, that electricity assistance to the Northern Territory would terminate after this financial year. Accordingly, there was no provision made for such assistance in the Forward Estimates.

However, it is now evident that the complete cessation of electricity assistance in 1989-90 would place an unreasonable strain on the finances of the Northern Territory and its Power and Water Authority.
The effects of this on the day-to-day finances of Territory households through significant rises in the cost of electricity would also have been unreasonable.

This point was raised with my colleague, the Treasurer, by those representing the Northern Territory both here and in another place. The Treasurer agreed that Territorians should be shielded from massive electricity price rises.

His response to this issue is a fine example of how vigorous representations by our Government colleagues from the Northern Territory have won for the people of the Northern Territory protection from what would otherwise have been a major attack on their standard of living.

The Government has decided therefore to continue assistance for electricity generation and distribution beyond 1988-89. In respect of 1989-90, a grant of $40m is to be provided. This Bill provides appropriation for that amount.
In order to help the Territory adjust to the lower level of assistance, it so also intended that the $40m for 1989-90 be paid before the end of 1988-89.
The Commonwealth has agreed with the Territory that is the years following 1989-90, the level of assistance will be fully phased out.
It is intended that for 1990-91, the grant will be reduced to $30m to $20m in 1991-92, and $10m in 1992-93. The grant will be discontinued in 1993-94.

The Government's offer of assistance to the Northern Territory provides for the amount of grants for 1990-91 to 1992-93 to be reviewed in the event that more favourable circumstances arise. Grants for those years will be provided for under the normal appropriation Bills in the relevant years.

In addition to these payments, the Government has decided to waive, from 1 July 1989, the Northern Territory's electricity debt to the Commonwealth with a net present value of $31.9m. This will relieve the Territory of scheduled repayments of principal and payments of interest to a cash value of $6.4m for each of the next nine years.

The Northern Territory will also be able to continue to submit requests to the Treasurer for special additions to its global borrowing limits to fund the remaining electricity operating deficits of the Power and Water Authority.
The assistance which has been agreed with the Northern Territory for its electricity operations is an important part of the Commonwealth's financial assistance to the Territory.

The arrangements have been designed to ensure that the adjustments to the Territory's finances will not be unmanageable in any one year. Without the proposed assistance, the burden of restraint which the Northern Territory would be expected to bear would be far greater than the States.

Nevertheless, the Commonwealth is clearly indicating that assistance in respect of the Territory's electricity operations cannot continue indefinitely: for that reason, the Commonwealth has insisted in its negotiations with the Northern Territory that the assistance be phased out. I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sheil) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

But, unfortunately, although the Minister has clarified the position with regard to specific services provided by the National Library, the National Gallery and the National Botanic Gardens, such other national public bodies within the ACT will be left in doubt. That is regrettable because there was an opportunity tonight for the Minister to clarify the position. I take into account that the paper put out by the Department of Finance is not new; it was reported in the press on 3 April this year, so it has been around for some time. I thought there might be an opportunity tonight to settle the matter once and for all. SPEECH.PARA: The next matter I wish to raise is also a matter of great disappointment to the people of the ACT. The Government is reneging on its undertakings to guarantee funding for the ACT in real terms, at the same level, for the first two years following self-government. As the Minister will be aware, that promise was given by Mr Holding in his second reading speech to the self-government Bill in the other place. It was reiterated by Senator Richardson in this place when giving his second reading speech to the self-government Bill. It was restated time and again, as I am sure Senator Reid will confirm, during the local election campaign. Federal spokesmen restated that a guarantee similar to the sort of guarantee in relation to the Northern Territory would be given. If the Minister looked at the Estimates Committee debate on 14 April he would see that the public servants talked about the guaranteed funding for that period. There was no question that that would be other than honoured.

Last week the Government reneged and, under pressure, entered into some weird arrangement. It said that it was possible that the Australian Capital Territory could get the difference between what it was promised and the grant that was given at the Premiers Conference last week if it could prove a special case. The important thing that arises from this is if the Government is prepared to break its promises as easily as that and as quickly following the making of those promises, what does it mean in relation to the various other undertakings that the Commonwealth has given to the Australian Capital Territory upon self-government-undertakings which were accepted in good faith and which became a basis not only for honourable senators on this side of the chamber to enter into long and difficult negotiations but also negotiations that led us, at least in part, to support the legislative package? I bring to the Minister's attention the fact that the people of the Australian Capital Territory feel particularly let down by this breach of promise and would like to hear from him tonight as to how he regards the balance of the promises relating to the acceptance of the Commonwealth's obligations for funding under the self-government package. TALK.START.PARA: —It is odd to choose to raise this matter with this Department. Senator Hill is an experienced front bench senator. He knows that we have just dealt with the departments covered by Senate Estimates Committee C and that Treasury matters are dealt with by that Estimates Committee, not in this Estimates Committee. He also knows that what he has put to me is indeed a Treasury matter, not a matter for the department that is before the Senate at this stage. If this be another of his invitations, I am afraid it is an invitation I must decline, although in declining with whatever grace I can muster in this debate, I might add for the record that the use of the word `renege' to imply that we have done less than honour our obligations is something I do not accept on behalf of the Government. That is not the case with this Government; it might have been the case with the government the honourable senator was part of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an astonishing answer and cannot be let lie in its present form. I can only assume that the Minister fails to understand what has happened in relation to the ACT funding, which comes under the Commonwealth's obligations to the Territory and particularly under this portfolio. I guess we have to take him back and give him a little history lesson. That is a bit disappointing because we wanted to keep the business moving tonight. The Minister will be--
—Don't bother doing a gratuitous thing like giving me a history lesson because I have an interest in keeping the business going.
—The Minister does not understand.
—If you miscue, despite your experience, and start asking questions in an inappropriate portfolio, I can hardly answer them here.

—Let me remind the Minister that for some hours in the Estimates Committee debate we went through with this Department the undertakings that were given in relation to the finances of the Commonwealth vis-a-vis self-government and the new self-governing Territory. The officers of this Department answered questions on that. —Are you going to do that? Is that a threat or a promise?

—If the Minister persists with the attitude that we have seen displayed tonight we will make it a promise. It seems to us that the people of the ACT, at the very least, can hear from this Minister under this head under which the whole matter has been debated from the start of the self- government Bills through to the negotiation of the outstanding financial relationship-not through Treasury, not through the Department of Finance, but through this Department. The Minister would realise that if he read the Estimates. The people of the ACT have a right to know the Commonwealth's position on all the outstanding financial matters. The Government said that for 1988-89-the year in which this new self- governing body of the Australian Capital Territory came into being-it would honour its financial undertakings. It said that for the next two years it would maintain the finance in real terms. The officers of this Department-not the Department of Finance; the officers of this Department-have been busy calculating exactly what that means in dollars. They talk about it in these Estimates. The officers of this Department say to us that it is an extremely difficult task. Yet tonight the Minister tries to pass the buck to somebody else. Nevertheless, it is maintained that the Government will honour its undertaking to maintain finances for the Australian Capital Territory in real terms for two years. Following that, there is to be a transitional period when it will be phased out. What is the Government's current attitude to that? What calculations are being made that will end up putting the new self-governing Territory in the same financial relationship as the States of Australia vis-a-vis the Commonwealth? What is the Government's attitude now?

SPEECH.PARA: Whether the Minister likes to acknowledge it or not-he is the first person in Australia I have heard deny that in fact the Government has reneged on its promise-implicitly the Government acknowledged that at the conference last week, because it then entered into these special side arrangements with Chief Minister Follett. Nevertheless, I guess this Minister has not kept up with that debate. But he does have a responsibility to the Senate tonight. He has been given the task of handling these appropriations and the people of the Australian Capital Territory want to know whether the reneging on this promise means that other promises that have been made about the continuing financial affairs of the Commonwealth in respect of the Territory will not be honoured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an extraordinary display. Senator Hill ought to know better than this. TALK.START.PARA: —I will therefore ask for clarification of the answers to questions that have been provided by this Department under this Estimates inquiry. The first answer that was given-that is, in regard to the financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the Australian Capital Territory Government-related to the transitional arrangements following the real terms guarantee period. —We are moving into farce. TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that, if one is unable to obtain answers during an Estimates committee hearing itself because the officers regard the matter in question either as too complex or as one that requires further consideration, and if, as in this instance, they undertake to provide answers later, this is the legitimate occasion on which to seek clarification of such answers if they are unclear. SPEECH.PARA: I will therefore move to the second area that this Department said was outstanding-the role of the Commonwealth Grants Commission during the guarantee and transitional periods.
