SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My particular interest was flagged in a speech I made yesterday concerning the Antarctic Division, particularly with respect to the letting of tenders for the Aurora Australis and the subsequent interference by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) in that process. The matter was discussed at length and questions were asked during Estimates hearings. My concern is that the cost of this whole exercise has been blown out of all proportion by interference from the Minister in what should have been a normal tendering process. As I said yesterday, half the trouble arose from the fact that the Minister was interested in getting the ship built at the Carrington Shipyard in New South Wales prior to a State election. The machinations of all that have resulted in what I believe and I am sure any thinking person would believe is a quite unacceptable situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to a media release issued by Senator Richardson in 1987, when he announced with great pleasure that the tender for the new Antarctic vessel, scheduled to be in service by 1989, had been let for $124m. The press release says:
`The shipyard will be chosen on a competitive commercial basis, and will be announced shortly'.

That sounds fine, but in practice, because of a subsidy from the New South Wales Government, the so-called competitive commercial basis disappeared. The tender from the Western Australian shipyard was omitted though it had the backing of a very good overseas firm.

To start the ball rolling, in the Estimates hearings I asked what the actual cost of the vessel was estimated to be at that time. I was told that the all-up cost would be $124m, as Senator Richardson said in his press release. When I asked what the actual up-front cost would be I was told that, because of the operation of cost-inflators, I think, it was impossible to give me an answer. I think it was said that the figure would not be known until the charter started because there were a number of variables. I ask the Minister: why, if these variables were used in arriving at the figure of $124m, can the same variables not be used to come up with an up-front figure so that the people of Australia might know what this vessel is actually going to cost?

Back on day one we were looking at something like $7m per annum for an overseas company and, in the case of an Australian company, about $10m per annum, which could have blown out to $12.5m per annum for a 10-year contract. The Secretary to the Department said that this was not a normal process. I think it was a very unusual process for the Minister to come out and announce the tender before the contract negotiations had been completed. In any business enterprise that would be highly irregular, to say the least. Because of those actions by the Minister this vessel has ended up costing Australia heaps more than it should have, yet no one has said too much about it.

By normal tendering processes it would be absolutely ridiculous, before the tender had been let and the final contract signed, to let the tenderer know that he was going to get the job. As a result of this, not only was the project delayed by up to six months, but also the people who were given the preferred tender were put in a position in which they screwed the Government to the floor for at least an extra $25m.

It is a shame that the Minister responsible is not in the chamber. I did give Senator Richardson notice that I was going to ask him some questions tonight. Obviously he has forgotten, just as he forgot about the fact that he had never been to the Antarctic Division. When I asked him whether he had been down to the Antarctic Division he said, `Yes'. About three or four weeks later he decided to go there. To me, these convenient lapses of memory just do not add up.

I should like to know when the ship is scheduled to begin service. Will it be in October 1989, as the Minister promised? If not, how much extra will it cost the Division and the Antarctic program? This is most important to Australia. We hear all about the proposal for a world park in Antarctica. I believe that our Antarctic Division needs all the support it can get. It certainly did not need the interference of the Minister on this occasion. All it has done is delay what the Division is trying to do, and it has cost the taxpayers of Australia many millions of dollars. One conservative estimate that I have received-and it does not include any extra hiring of ships-is at least $60m. Can the Minister tell me when the new ship will begin service? Also, can he possibly tell me what the estimated all-up cost of the ship is at the moment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Calvert has observed, I am not the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. —I hope the quality will improve.

—I do not think it is possible for the quality to improve. It can be matched, but I do not accept that it can be improved. Senator Calvert has asked a series of questions in what, may I say without any criticism of him, was a fairly long dissertation. Let me say first, so that I do not have to dwell on it in dealing with each point he made, that he made quite a number of political references. SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, let me go to some of the issues the honourable senator raised. The next matter deals with the charter of this vessel for a 10-year period. The basic price for charter was $10.8m per season. It varies because of currency fluctuations. It is now estimated that it will commence somewhere between 15 December this year and 15 January next year. It could be delayed a little, I should caution. That is the best estimate of commencement that I can give. I am advised that the Department is taking action to provide an interim vessel at a lower cost for the period that the new vessel is delayed, so there will be a stopgap measure to cater for any lapse in fulfilling the program. There may have been some other questions asked but, in terms of taking down all of them in the honourable senator's long dissertation, they are the only ones I have identified and thus answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall try to keep any more questions for the Minister brief. In answer to my question about the commencement date for the new vessel, the Minister intimated that it could be between 15 December and 15 January, which is well into the season, and he indicated that another hire vessel would be used. Could he tell me the name of the vessel and how much it will cost?

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, the delays were caused by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) interfering in the tendering process. The Secretary to the Department admitted that it was not a normal process for that Minister to announce the tender before contract negotiations have been completed. Senator Cook might think that I am being political but, to say the least, the whole exercise has been very extraordinary. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories admitted that he had attended meetings during the tender assessment and contract negotiation period and did not have a departmental officer with him. That would lead one to believe that there was something crook in Tallarook, to say the least. It is very irregular for lobbying meetings to be held during tender assessment. The Minister for Resources would have to agree with that. I am not saying that Senator Richardson did anything illegal, but in his haste to get this contract let to an Australian company in New South Wales he did not have a departmental officer with him so that he could protect not only himself but also his Department. Why not? Again, why did he announce the selected tenderer before negotiations had been completed? On top of that, I presume that it was he who authorised the Deputy Director of the Antarctic Division to sign a letter of intent to P and O before negotiations had been completed. I cannot be convinced that that is not irregular. Was not Senator Richardson advised by the Australian Government Solicitor about signing it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me go to the first set of questions, about the interim vessel, and if our worst fears are realised and there is in fact an inability to meet the 15 December to 15 January target.
—What is the vessel, for a start?
—That is a good question, for this reason--
—What is the answer? Why don't you tell him?

—Honourable senators should make all their interjections now because they will be sadly disappointed when they hear the answer. It is a good question for this reason: the tender for it has not yet been finalised. I answered the honourable senator's earlier question by saying that it would be cheaper than the tender figure when the proper vessel comes on stream. I am able to answer that question in that way because tenders have been called, the tendering process has been exhausted and tenders have closed. But no adjudication has yet been made on which will be the successful tenderer. Looking at the body of tenders submitted, we are able to say directly and informatively to the chamber that it will be cheaper than the $10.7m plus the inflator effect that I referred to before. I cannot answer the question until the tender process is completed and I am sure that the honourable senator does not want me to interfere in the tender process to provide him with an answer.

SPEECH.PARA: The second set of questions concerned Senator Richardson. I feel sorry for him in a way in that Opposition senators sometimes use him as a coconut shy for whatever allegations they want to trade. I think that is a little unfair to him and it is particularly crook when he is not in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are starting to become more impressed by him. We are comparing you with your colleague.

—Senator Hill is fairly pathetic himself and the way in which he performed earlier was a shabby reflection on his ability on the front bench. The fact that he was a successful conspirator with those who deposed Mr Howard confers on him the privilege of sitting on the front bench; it says nothing for his intelligence.

—On a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman: I ask you to direct the Minister to address the Chair rather than address a member of the Opposition across the chamber, therefore being totally disorderly.
—Order! I know how to conduct the chamber.
—Mr Chairman, through you I might say that if Senator Stone--
—Mr Chairman, I do not like being referred to as a conspirator. I find that quite offensive. I ask you to ask the Minister to withdraw it.
—I did not hear the world `conspirator'.
—Everyone else did. Ask him whether he said it.

—If I said something unparliamentary, I withdraw it. I do not think it is unparliamentary, but if it is I withdraw it. I should have said he was a colleague of those who moved to depose the former Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Howard. We have heard from some of those on Four Corners how they saw that. One could accurately describe it as a conspiracy. It is under the bridge as far as I am concerned. Members of the Liberal Party have done it to themselves and they will have to live with it.

SPEECH.PARA: But let me not be distracted from answering Senator Calvert's question. That was the purpose for which I rose. I intend to complete my answer so that I can resume my seat. The tenders that Senator Calvert raised were departmental tenders. The Minister was not involved and did not interfere with them, nor did he direct that the work be allocated to a company in New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a shame the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is not here. Perhaps Senator Cook can tell me why he is not. The tenders have closed yet he cannot tell us who will do the job in December or January. That is most unusual.

SPEECH.PARA: The contract price that we have agreed upon is $124m, plus a figure that we do not really know about because of all the variables and cost inflation factors. I am sure ministerial advisers, if they had the time and could be bothered, could work out this figure because they did that previously to arrive at the $124m. That is a straightforward question without any political bias. TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of Senator Calvert's question was another effort to obtain an answer to a question that I have already answered. That will be achieved because of an adjustment in the program for the Department so that it will not involve an extra cost. If the honourable senator wants the final answer to his question, I am absolutely certain that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) will oblige when all the information is known on which he can give that answer.

—The Minister has not answered the question. Was there an overseas bidder who offered to build a ship as good for half the price? I will give him the answer. It was Reiber of Norway, if he wants to know. Is that correct?

—The answer-and the honourable senator knows this-is that it was a Government decision to have the vessel built in Australia. Any other ruminations by me out loud in this chamber about the process would breach commercial in confidence rules. Surely the honourable senator does not want me to do that. Even if he does, I will not.

—I do not argue with the aim of having an Australian shipbuilder and an Australian crew. I think it is a very meritorious aim. I am querying the way it happened. —I have some questions on the proposed storage at Redbank for low level nuclear waste. Because the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) has either had a bad tea or is not very happy tonight, and is not in his normal humour, I will be quite happy for him to wait until later on when we discuss primary industries and energy for these questions to be answered. Part of the responsibility lies with the Department of Community Services and Health; part lies with the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories; part lies under the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation; part lies under the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. I do not mind under which department I ask all of these questions. It would be more appropriate if I asked them under one rather than spread them out, but I am happy to spread them out over the whole lot and go on until tomorrow. It might be better to bunch them together. Because the Minister is a bit testy tonight, he might indicate when he would like to answer these questions.

—I am happy to indicate that. I am not testy with Senator Macklin. I am testy-and rightfully so, as I am, after all, but a frail human being-with questions that are silly. But Senator Macklin's questions are not. They can be answered, and I am in a position to answer them under any heading under which the honourable senator chooses to ask them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. As he is aware, the Queensland Government last year made an announcement that it would build a special materials store at Redbank, a suburb of Ipswich, at a cost of half a million dollars. The site was proposed for the storage of radioisotopes and radioactive hospital wastes. As the Minister is probably already very much aware, this has caused a great deal of public concern, particularly among those people living in Ipswich, about the safety and public health implications for residents who live near the site. The relevant local government authority-the Ipswich City Council-has also been opposed to this.

SPEECH.PARA: The site itself is well known. It is unsatisfactory for a variety of reasons, not the least of which are: the unstable nature of the area due to now disused coal mines; the possibilities of flooding; the seismological activity that occurs in this region; and, last but not least, its very close proximity to the Brisbane River, where there is already a problem with regard to toxic wastes coming from various other dumps.

The situation that I am concerned about is what the Commonwealth has done with regard to this proposal. It is fairly obvious that the Commonwealth has a role because it has a whole range of powers with regard to the dumping of nuclear waste in Australia, whether they come under the heading of the corporate powers or, for example, the range of conditions which are imposed on the isotopes which are sold from the Australian Atomic Energy Commission facility at Lucas Heights, or whether other conditions are imposed. I understand some of the products are used in hospitals and therefore produce these wastes. Some of those isotopes are imported already under certain conditions. So the Commonwealth Government is already involved in the usage of these isotopes. What is more, the Commonwealth Government is involved in the transportation of radioactive substances.

Last year the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin-not the Minister for Resources, who is in this chamber-issued a press release which indicated that the Commonwealth is committed to developing a national repository for low level radioactive wastes. I believe that the Redbank proposal could very well be that national repository, without any announcement having been made. Be that as it may, I would like the Minister to respond to whether the Department, whose estimates we are currently discussing, has allocated any resources with regard to the announcement made last year. What communications has this Department had with the Department of Primary Industries and Energy with regard to development of that national repository? What, if any, has been the Commonwealth's involvement in regard to the proposed establishment of the dump at Redbank? Lastly, does the Government currently have in progress any studies within any of those relevant departments with regard to a national nuclear regulatory authority dealing with the end products? In other words, do we have a body which is concerned with the licensing, regulation, inspection and advice on the disposal of the nuclear waste which is generated from hospitals?

As the Minister well knows from his own portfolio, there are currently about 50 of these disposal units around the country, which is, of course, inadequate. Obviously, the Commonwealth is involved because of the power it derives from international treaties, its foreign affairs power, its corporations power or simply its import power and its control over Lucas Heights. Obviously it must have undertaken something.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Macklin for his question. Let me go to the first part of the question: has the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories had any allocations? The answer to that is no. Secondly, Senator Macklin asked me: What communications has the Department entered into with the Department of Primary Industries and Energy? I am not entirely sure about that, but I am sure someone can inform me in a minute. However, I can answer the other parts of Senator Macklin's question in terms of the Commonwealth involvement in Redbank, Commonwealth studies on a nuclear regulatory authority and the process of assessment we have engaged in to determine what powers we have in relation to the States and the storage of nuclear waste.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take them all in omnibus fashion and answer this way: I understand that this particular nuclear waste is, as Senator Macklin rightly described it, low level waste-clothing and other materials which are adjudged by the authorities to be low level-and that it is material that is generated in the State of Queensland. This material is not brought into Queensland for the purpose of storage and as such the Commonwealth would not be clothed with special powers to regulate it. The Commonwealth, however, is not happy about the unilateral decision of the Queensland Government to relocate its repository at Redbank, and we have expressed that dissatisfaction.

The Commonwealth is, and has been, engaged in a study with States and the Northern Territory to see whether we can properly establish and be satisfied with a national radioactive waste repository so that many of the things to which Senator Macklin referred in his question are properly addressed and answered. The Government of the Northern Territory has expressed a particular interest in hosting the site for such a repository. That Government has contacted the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) to undertake a feasibility study. I understand that that study by ANSTO has been completed and is under consideration by the Northern Territory Government at present. The Commonwealth has contributed the sum of $100,000 to the completion of that study and, obviously, once the consideration of the outcome of that study has been completed, we will be in a position to announce what our intentions are. Indeed, the Northern Territory Government may be in a position to make such an announcement first.

With respect to the exercise of constitutional powers-Senator Macklin referred to a few heads of powers, particularly the corporations power in the Constitution-the advice I have before me at the moment on which I can base an answer is that the materials that are being stored at Redbank are generated in the State of Queensland and there appears to us to be no appropriate head of power under which we can regulate the handling of those materials in Queensland. However, we do want to encourage the Queensland Government to join the community of other States and the Northern Territory in supporting a national repository. We think that is sensible and rational; it is something which the people of Australia ought to support. We deplore the unilateral action of the Queensland Government on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his comprehensive answer. I will make just one point with regard to the powers: is it not the case that the radioisotopes which are used in hospitals are either imported or generated at Lucas Heights? In both of those situations there are already in place a series of requirements about end use. In other words, it would be reasonable for the waste generated by the use of those materials also to be regulated. For example, I draw the Minister's attention to an answer that I received in this place a couple of days ago-in fact, the Minister gave it to me-with regard to the inspection of food. We place those types of controls on food. The Minister indicated in his answer that, where there was an excess, the Government issued a licence only when it was satisfied that no health risk to any Australian was involved. I am thinking of the same types of usages in these circumstances.

—I thank Senator Macklin for his comments. I accept what he says about these materials being either generated from Lucas Heights or imported. In regard to the rest of the proposition contained in his question, I will ask his indulgence to take the matter on notice in order to give him a considered reply.

—I think in this day and age all of us are realising that we must take a more holistic approach in our examination of all issues, and especially environmental issues. I would like to ask some specific questions about the degree of cooperation or communication on matters involving the environment, specifically the National Estate and, more specifically, the south-east forests of New South Wales. I would like to find out what efforts the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) has made to protect the National Estate values in the south-east forests. I also ask: what is the extent of cooperation between the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and DASETT in preserving these national forests? How well do they work together; how do they work together; do they consult with each other; and is there communication? I do not know whether this is in the environment portfolio or the resources portfolio, but certainly the Minister at the table could answer the question. What alternatives to logging have been studied and rejected in the Government's deliberations over the National Estate areas of the south-eastern New South Wales forests?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an extraordinary conjunction of fate that I should be answering on behalf of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson). I see that Senator Sanders, ever with an eye for the main chance, has picked his opportunity to put these questions to me. Let me answer them as properly and as fully as I could were I the Minister for the environment. Let me answer that part of Senator Sanders's question which relates to my portfolio responsibilities as Minister for Resources, for I fear that he will ask it later in any event under my portfolio. We might as well dispose of it now. I hope it will be a clean finish to the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The first part of the question, as I took it down, was: What has the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) done to protect the National Estate in the south-eastern forests? Acting on the advice of both this Department and my own Department, the Government initially put a proposal to the New South Wales Government that there be no logging in the areas of the National Estate and areas on the interim list of the National Estate until such time as we could have a further round of discussions with the New South Wales Government to settle the areas that should be protected in order to meet the requirements of the Harris-Daishowa woodchip export licence. Agreement between the Commonwealth and the New South Wales Government was reached in January on the understanding that when I met with Minister Causley in March we would again discuss the areas to be protected prior to making a decision but that in the meanwhile there would be no logging in areas of the National Estate or on the interim list.

I regret to inform Senator Sanders that, without reference to me and unilaterally, the New South Wales Government commenced logging, as it said at the time, to supply saw logs to the Bombala sawmill prior to the opportunity for Minister Causley and me to meet again to settle any issues that were outstanding. I believe that that Government, although I disagree with what it did, acted within its constitutional authority to authorise logging for sawmill purposes. Because that logging, in the integrated form of forestry that is practised by the Forestry Commission of New South Wales, generated materials that would normally be sent to the woodchip mill at Eden, those materials were sent there. When I became aware of that I instructed Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd to comply with the terms of its licence and quarantine that supply of material because it was not from an area that the Commonwealth had approved.

Indeed, I have been to the Eden woodchip mill this very day. One can visually inspect an increasingly large stockpile of materials from the area in which Minister Causley has authorised the cutting-which, moreover, on my instructions, is not being processed by Harris-Daishowa. Indeed, Harris-Daishowa has gone further and said that if it does not process it soon it will have to stand down workers. Nonetheless, in talking to those workers today, I said that I would not agree to the processing of that material until such time as we had an agreement with the State of New South Wales on how the National Estate should be treated in the south-eastern forests.

As to Senator Sanders's other questions, the form of procedures involved here is the standard form of procedures followed. Whenever a State proposition comes to me involving a proposal which cuts into any area designated as National Estate or as interim-listed National Estate, I refer it to the Minister for the environment. Comment is sought by the Heritage Commission, comment is given by the Australian Heritage Commission and, in the meantime, I busy myself trying to find, to quote the terms of the relevant Act, prudent and feasible alternatives to cutting in the National Estate. I accept the advice of the Minister for the environment and the advice of the Heritage Commission, and I do my level best to find alternatives. If I cannot find alternatives that are prudent and feasible and believe that there is no alternative but to proceed to log part of the National Estate, which is something that I authorise from time to time-and not just in the case of the south-east-as a matter of form I am bound to seek comment from the Heritage Commission on how it is proposed to be done. I get further advice from the Commission about that, but in the end make a decision, based on my statutory obligations, as to what the final proposal will be and notify the State governments concerned of that proposal. The head of power that I operate in doing all that is the export control power, expressed as conditions on the export licences for woodchip companies in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there any direct contact between the personnel of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DOPIE) and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT)? Do they actually work together or is there an almost adversative set-up whereby Primary Industries is looking at industry and Environment is looking at environment, they both feed information to their respective Ministers and the Ministers then try to sort out the differences, if any? Is there any direct contact between the personnel of DASETT and DOPIE? If not, would such direct contact be advisable?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is quite a deal of direct contact. During the process of making these decisions, it could be fairly said that we live in each other's pockets, not only at departmental level but also at ministerial level. While Senator Sanders is right in identifying the distinction between the responsibilities of each of the departments, if I might draw an analogy it would be that of the inbuilt conflict between a quality control officer and a production officer in a manufacturing plant, where there is always a constructive antagonism in relation to each other's requirements and a desire by management in the end to produce a product which conforms with the needs of both.

SPEECH.PARA: To end that analogy and refer to the present circumstances, there is an earnest and well documented desire-documented by achievement-on the part of this Government to protect the environment. I will not go through the list of achievements that this Government can point to, but they are impressive and numerous. On the other hand, there is an economic responsibility to the community about production, employment and the socioeconomic effects of industry. The process is one of sorting out those differences so that the outcome for both the environment and the economic aspects of the issue is a win.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) certainly knows his woodchips. I believe that he is going to leave the chamber in a moment, so I will be dealing with the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh. I wish to return to the few queries I had concerning the tender for the Antarctic ship Aurora Australis. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) announced the preferred tenderer before the contract had been negotiated. I think the Minister for Finance would know more about that than the Minister for Resources, who has just walked out. Is it normal business practice for someone to announce who is going to get the tender before anything is actually signed and final negotiations take place, with a resultant delay of six months while negotiations are going on, meaning that the tenderers, who have the great advantage of knowing that they are going to get the job, are able to screw the Government down to the point where they can obtain an extra $25m out of it? Surely the Minister does not believe that is normal practice? I asked a question, which was never answered: While this was going on, was a letter of intent sent to the prospective tenderers? I wanted to know who it was sent by, whether it was cleared by the Minister's office, and was that outside the terms of the Cabinet decision.

—I am pretty confident the answer to the last question would be no. It is regrettable that Senator Richardson is not here. I understand he had to go to Sydney. Obviously I do not know anything about the other questions that Senator Calvert has raised. I think the best thing I can do is speak to Senator Richardson tomorrow and try to get him to give the honourable senator a reply as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —When questions are not answered and accusations are made, things transpire around the country and we hear all sorts of rumours about kickbacks. They reflect not only on the Department but also on the Minister. I would like to get these matters cleared up tonight. A lot of the information is contained in the review of the tendering process. Some of the answers were given in the Estimates hearings, but some were not. The point I am trying to make is that when a tender is being let for anything, it is important to do the best one can for whoever one is working for. I put it to the chamber that in this case, Senator Richardson's impetuosity in trying to get the tender let to New South Wales had the net effect of blowing out the price by at least $25m. The contract negotiations took so long because the tenderers knew that they were going to get it. As I found out earlier tonight, that has resulted in the vessel not being ready when it should be, which means that another vessel will have to be taken up in the short term. Whilst I have been told that it is cheaper-and I have to accept that-I do not believe it will assist the Department in planning its ongoing program. I did ask whether there was a letter of intent sent to P and O before the final contract negotiations had been completed, and the Minister said no; but there was.
—I neither confirmed nor denied that, because I just don't know. It is just the last question that I answered.

—I think the Minister would have to admit, even though he does not know anything of what I am talking about, that in usual business practice letting a tenderer know that it has got a job before final negotiations are completed is not, I think in the words of one of the advisers, normal process. That is the point I have been trying to make. I have been trying to find out why it happened and what the overall cost increase is because of that. I think the chamber has a right to know, as the Estimates process oversees this type of operation. It does not reflect very well on the Department or on the Antarctic Division. Allegations have been made, and they were referred to in the Estimates hearings, by Mr Ralfs that in the early days of tendering he was given documents by the Seamen's Union of Australia. I find it incredible that confidential briefing information that is supposed to be provided to Cabinet by the Antarctic Division could end up in the hands of one of the prospective tenderers. Not only that, when the Australian Federal Police investigated the matter they actually showed the documents to the then Director and the Deputy Director. Mr Ralfs believes that his submission was sabotaged. It was admitted in Estimates. Senator Puplick asked a question about this and I think the answer went something like this, `Essentially the answer is that there was an error in the information that went to the Minister. But it was not material to any decisions'. But the fact is that the submission made by Mr Ralfs was changed, by persons unknown, between the time it left his hands and when it got to the Minister. Whether in the final analysis that had any effect on his tender I do not know but in those early days, from what I have read here, it seems the Antarctic Division was quite happy with the proposal he put up.

SPEECH.PARA: When we asked in the Estimates hearing what had been done about it, we were told the officers did not know the answer to the question, but they were satisfied there was no evidence to suggest that it had been done by the departmental sources and therefore there was no investigation. Surely to goodness when the Australian Federal Police are involved and documents that are supposed to be confidential Cabinet briefing documents are in the hands of the Seamen's Union and the prospective tenderers, that warrants an investigation. I think that is a reflection on the Department and the Minister involved. I believe this whole exercise has been dubious. It is a shame that the relevant Minister is not here to answer the question directly. As I said, I find it very hard to continue with any more lines of questioning when I cannot get any answers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The document to which Senator Calvert referred was not a Cabinet document, and it is important to note that. It was a one-page brief, I understand.
—A seven-page brief; a draft submission to Cabinet.

—I am sorry, a one-page attachment-anyway, a brief prepared for Senator Richardson, following a query from him about what Australian tenderers had been involved. I understand that the one-page attachment had a factual error. I have just been shown the Hansard of the Senate Estimates Committee meeting of 13 April, when the question was asked about an announcement or indication that a particular tenderer has been successful without the contract actually being signed. Mr Blunn and Senator Richardson both commented on that. Off the top of my head I am aware of one very important case, the portfolio of the Defence Service Homes Corporation, when it was announced that the Government had accepted the Westpac Banking Corporation tender but no contract had yet been signed. Indeed the details of the final agreement which was signed were not fully negotiated, I would say from memory, for several weeks. It may even have been more than a month after that. So it is certainly not unprecedented for an announcement to be made that the Government has accepted or is going to accept a particular tender without all the details having been fully negotiated, let alone a contract signed.

—Would the Minister accept or reject the proposition that if a tender is announced prior to the final negotiations being finalised, it does put the known tenderer in a position where he can extract further concessions from, in this case, the Government that perhaps it might not normally have been able to do? In this case I think it was about $25m?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prima facie I think it probably is possible but if the tenderer tries to exploit that potential advantage too much a government always has the option of saying, `We will not accept this tender because you people are coming the raw prawn and we will take one of the others'.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case to which I refer and which I know a good deal about-the Westpac case-that was no realistic alternative other than to do what was done. There were many matters of fine detail and it would not have been a practical proposition to discuss them with all the people who had put in a tender. That would have probably strung the whole process out for another six or 12 months. I expect that was a significantly more complicated deal than the Antarctic ship project is likely to be. Senator Puplick asked whether it was normal. I do not know what is normal, but it is certainly not unprecedented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the Minister will say it is unusual, just like many of the things that have an irregular or unusual occurrence. For instance, I go back to what I said originally. In his press statement the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) said that the shipyard would be chosen on a competitive commercial basis. I asked a question before and the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) did not reply. If it was to be chosen on a competitive commercial basis why was that taken out of the draft submission to Cabinet by the Minister? Obviously Senator Walsh would not know. I suppose Senator Richardson would have to answer.

—I am informed that the Government had no direct dealings with any shipyard. The Government had dealings with the P and O company which made the decision as to where the ship would actually be procured from.

—I would like to take the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) back to matters that I raised earlier in relation to the financial relationship between the Commonwealth and the new Australian Capital Territory Government. I do so out of the Estimates. A number of questions were left outstanding or unclear. I guess the position is even more unclear for Australian Capital Territory residents now than it was a week or so ago. Until then they understood that they had an undertaking from the Commonwealth that for the first two years after the new government came into being Commonwealth funding would be maintained in real terms. As we are all aware, last week the Commonwealth, to put it in a very moderate terminology, varied that undertaking-for whatever reason is irrelevant at the moment. It leaves considerable doubt as to the current position in relation to Commonwealth guarantees for funding for the balance of the first two years and thereafter for the next two years in which it said there would be a phase-down period. The Minister has the advantage of being the Minister for Finance as well. I would like to know what is the Commonwealth's position in relation to the guarantees it gave to the Australian Capital Territory upon attaining self-government.

—Normally, my position as Minister for Finance might have helped me to answer this question. I was on leave during the week of the Premiers Conference. I have not yet caught up with that sort of detail regarding what happened. I think as the Finance Minister I could provide Senator Hill with an answer-not at the moment and not tonight, but within a reasonable time-to the latter part of his question. In regard to the first part of his question and his reference to the earlier questions, which I did not hear, I am advised that the officers who spoke on Australian Capital Territory matters at the Estimates Committee hearings last April are not now with the Australian Public Service but with the Australian Capital Territory territorial government. Those individuals and their functions are no longer part of the Commonwealth Department. The Commonwealth Department's residual involvement with the Australian Capital Territory now revolves around national functions-for example, the National Capital Planning Authority, the Parliamentary Triangle and related matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct; I accept that. I am interested in the national functions and responsibilities. In particular, I am looking at the national responsibilities of funding, both through the transitional period and thereafter-funding obligations which the Commonwealth has accepted and which remain in an unclear position. This was accepted in the Estimates Committee when the relevant officer said there were still a considerable number of outstanding issues that required resolution or clarification concerning financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the Australian Capital Territory Government. Over the range of these matters a very large sum of money is involved. The people of the Australian Capital Territory believe that they require clarification.

SPEECH.PARA: Uncertainty now exists in relation to the transitional arrangements following the events of last week. I would like the Minister to take a look at that. I do not mind if the answer is not given tonight. I think it is important that the position be clarified, particularly as to how it affects the second year, which is part of the real terms guarantee and the two following years which was to be the period of phase down. What undertakings is the Commonwealth now giving, bearing in mind that the undertakings which it gave only a few months ago at the time of the introduction of self-government appear now to be outdated? I think the Minister would say that they were superseded by unexpected economic circumstances. Where do the people of the Australian Capital Territory and the new Australian Capital Territory Government now sit in relation to the Commonwealth undertakings that were given?

Another matter which has been put to us by officers of the Department in answers that were recently provided to Estimates inquiries that remained outstanding relates to the role of the Commonwealth Grants Commission during the guarantee and transitional periods. The people of the Australian Capital Territory and the Government would like to know what the Commonwealth is intending to do in that regard. The Minister will recall that the Grants Commission carried out an inquiry into Australian Capital Territory funding. This covered the year 1986-87. It found that after taking into account Commonwealth functions and financial support equivalent to that for the States, the requirement for the Australian Capital Territory was $80m more. Is it the intention of the Commonwealth to have the Grants Commission update those figures? Are they to be taken into account in the transition period?

The third matter that requires clarification arising out of the Estimates Committee in relation to these transitional financial relations is the treatment of the cost of land development prior to 1 July 1988. In April the officers of the Department told us that the matter was being worked on and that the land in question was pretty much settled. They thought the figure would be in the vicinity of $50m. The considered answer to the outstanding issues question indicates that there is still doubt about the treatment of the costs of land development. I do not know what that means. It is unclear to me and I request clarification. A number of other matters need to be clarified. I do not know whether the Minister can assist us tonight-perhaps he might be able to give us some indication.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot do anything tonight. The honourable senator wanted to know precisely what happened at the Premiers Conference in regard to the Australian Capital Territory and what changes, if any, were made at the Premiers Conference or because of the Premiers Conference to the decision announced, I think in July of last year, about Australian Capital Territory funding. I do not know the answers off the top of my head but I am confident that I could get that sort of information from the Department of Finance. SPEECH.PARA: As to what the Commonwealth's policy will be in regard to a Grants Commission review, I think that is a Treasury matter, not a Finance matter. Likewise, I should be able to get an answer from the Department of Finance to the third question about the financial treatment of developed or semi-developed land that is being transferred to the Australian Capital Territory Administration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am satisfied with that approach and, on that basis, I will simply run through a list of outstanding issues. I remind the Minister that they are not issues which I regard as outstanding but issues which the Department itself regards as outstanding. The Minister will remember that one of the key subjects of the whole self-government debate was the financial relationship between the Commonwealth and the new self-governing body. With the experience of hindsight, we realise that much less was determined before self-government than we had realised. As I said, these matters in total add up to very large sums of money and are, therefore, very important from the point of view of Australian Capital Territory residents and their future likely local taxation requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: The fourth of these areas is the treatment of notional levels of Commonwealth debt calculated for the period up to the establishment of the Australian Capital Territory trust account. I would be pleased if that could be clarified. The fifth area-and this is being particularly raised with me-is the treatment of superannuation liabilities relating to Australian Capital Territory government employees who were taken from the Commonwealth. I understand from the officers' helpful information in the Estimates Committee hearings that in the case of the Northern Territory the Commonwealth met that requirement for the first seven years. Under a strict interpretation of the guarantees that the Commonwealth has given, which guarantees perhaps have already been modified-

TALK.START.PARA: —That was changed when I became the Minister for Finance.
—Right. A strict interpretation of the guarantees which his Government-
—It was a disgraceful bit of open-ended sloppiness inherited from the Fraser Government.

—I am to interpret from that that this Government is certainly not going to give financial support for seven years to Commonwealth employees who have become Australian Capital Territory employees. This might be of interest to them. They will be even more interested to learn what the Commonwealth is giving because, on a strict interpretation of the guarantee, one could say that that meant that the Commonwealth would guarantee only the excess superannuation requirement for a period of two years. But, as we know, that guarantee was modified last week. Therefore, there must be a great, currently existing doubt as to exactly what is going to be the liability that the Commonwealth is prepared to pick up. The employees of the Australian Capital Territory would appreciate the Minister's clarification in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: The next area that remains vague is that of financial adjustments relating to the transfer of territorial functions, the funding of which was not included in the ACT trust accounts in 1988-89. Examples are given of the Australian Government Solicitor functions, the administrative appeals-ombudsman functions, the Public Service Commission's functions and the Archives functions. There may be others. I would be pleased if the Minister could in due course give some indication as to what moneys are involved in relation to those adjustments.

The next matter that has been raised by the Department in its list of outstanding issues in the financial relationship is that of financial adjustments relating to the definition and gazettal of national land. We would appreciate clarification as to what moneys are involved in that regard, and how long it will take to settle and resolve what moneys are involved. Also, the establishment grant which was foreshadowed in the second reading speech to the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill has to be clarified. The Minister will remember that it included undertakings by this Government in relation to the Parliamentary Library, the Treasury computer system and building to house the Assembly and the Executive. They are in a building and I take it that that obligation is being met. What about the other undertakings; are they still to be honoured? What sums of money are involved? The funding basis for the specific purpose payments to the Australian Capital Territory Government for 1989-90 according to the list of outstanding issues, is, as I just said, outstanding and we would appreciate clarification.

Whilst this list is helpful in that it sets out a whole series of heads, in effect, it really does not provide the substantive information upon which the Australian Capital Territory residents or the Australian Capital Territory Government can assess their future financial obligations. That is what we are seeking in this request for further clarification. We would also like clarification in respect of funding for territorial functions retained by the Commonwealth in relation to the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court and policing; the determination of general revenue and special revenue assistance grants for 1989-90; the determination of the general capital assistance grant for 1989-90; and the Australian Capital Territory Government Loan Council borrowings for 1989-90. We are also advised by the Department that further work is required on the operation of section 64 of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act which relates to guarantees offered by the Australian Capital Territory Government. We seek clarification as to what further work is necessary in that regard.

We would like to know when the role of the Commonwealth Auditor-General is to be settled. The financial arrangements for services provided by the Commonwealth to the Australian Capital Territory remain to be settled. We would like to know what ongoing work is in train in that regard, and what will be the obligations of the Australian Capital Territory. The financial arrangements for services provided by the Australian Capital Territory to the Commonwealth are important and require clarification. Recognition of the Australian Capital Territory and Commonwealth-State financial forums still requires further clarification. The Department speaks about `a longer term timetable for inclusion of the Australian Capital Territory in the general revenue pool on a similar basis to the States and the Northern Territory'. What is meant by that? The stated intention of the Government requires clarification.

I know that list is long, but it indicates the level of outstanding difficulty, or at least the number of significant issues which as I said add up to a lot of the money, that still are required to be resolved before there can be certainty in the financial relationship between the Commonwealth and the Australian Capital Territory. We would be genuinely pleased if the Minister would have his Department look at that list which has been prepared by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and give us further information as to what is meant under each of these heads, what are the finances involved, and when the matters are likely to be resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not realise that the list was going to be so long or so wide ranging. I am confident however that we will be able to answer some of those questions from within the Department of Finance and some of the others perhaps in consultation with other departments. I will get what information I can, although I suspect that it is not possible to answer some of the questions at this stage. If that is the case, we can advise the honourable senator.
—That and a timetable would be helpful.
—Yes, but given the length and the diverse nature of the list, it might take quite a while.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point that strikes me when looking through this review is: why was Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd included in the final short list by the Minister even though it had been excluded, for cost reasons, from the list recommended by the Antarctic Division? During the tendering process and before negotiations were finalised, was a letter of intent sent to P and O Steam Navigation Co.? Was it approved by the Minister? Whom was it signed by? If that did happen, was the letter of intent outside the terms of the Cabinet decision? Was Cabinet warned by the Australian Government Solicitor about signing it?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the letter of intent was certainly acknowledged by the Minister. I have been asked what seems to me to be the same question I have been asked before; that is, was it outside the terms of the Cabinet decision? I do not believe so. My recollection of the Cabinet discussions at the time-it has however been confirmed by the officers here-was that the Commonwealth's dealings were with P and O. Whoever actually built the ship was P and O's affair rather than the Commonwealth's per se. I am advised that the TNT tender was included on the list so that there would be one wholly Australian tender for Cabinet discussion should Cabinet have decided to give particular preference to an Australian firm.
—What about the Western Australian firm, ASI?
—It has just been confirmed that TNT was the lowest Australian tender received.
—That was after they received the subsidy from the New South Wales Government though, was it not?
—I do not know anything about a subsidy from the New South Wales Government.
—So there wasn't a subsidy?

—I do not know whether there was or not but I do not believe it would have been relevant for the Commonwealth Government to consider whether the lowest tender to the Commonwealth from a wholly Australian supplier was included on the list and whether that tender was lower because somebody else had paid or was willing to pay a subsidy. I do not know whether that is correct but I do not believe it would have been considered to be important by the Commonwealth had we chosen to accept the Australian company's tender nor in my opinion should it have been considered important by the Commonwealth.
—Wasn't the ASI's price the best price? They offered the best price and then Carrington received a subsidy from the New South Wales Government.

—I have just been told that Australian Shipbuilding Industries (Western Australia) Pty Ltd (ASI) did not tender. The contractor could have approached ASI to construct a ship but ASI did not submit a tender.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter that came up in the Estimates Committee. It is the matter of the construction of a child-care centre on the lawns of the old Parliament House. We raised the matter of the necessity for a child-care centre and of course its location is a matter of interest as well. As a consequence of the questions which were asked, some answers have since been supplied, which in some ways raise more issues than they answer. At the time we questioned the need for child-care places in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). In fact, Senator Hill asked a question-it is recorded on page 155-that has subsequently been answered. One paragraph of the answer is of particular interest:

SPEECH.PARA: There are no formal mechanisms to assess the overall need for and number of places or resulting shortfall. However, in a general sense it is accepted that the demand for places exceeds the present levels of supply. This is supported by the size of waiting lists, the number of enquiries, and information received from individual services particularly for children under 2 years old.

Interestingly enough, it then says that a more detailed brief on the above can be provided upon request. I thought the honourable senator had requested the information at the hearing itself. What we were trying to get at is: what is the need for child-care places? We had asked whether there was a list that indicated the number of people registered as eligible for subsidised child-care in the ACT. It seems to me that there are no lists. Presumably, each child-care centre keeps a list of names of people who have dropped in but in that case the same child may be on four or five lists. So I do not feel that that answer tells us of the need for child-care places in the ACT. In fact, I know of private child-care centres in the ACT that do have places.
The other answer of interest related to the Children's Services Planning Committee setting priorities. The supplementary answer was as follows:
The Children's Services Planning Committee meeting of 14 August 1987 recorded the following decision in its minutes.
The Committee, after considerable deliberation, accorded the new Parliament House as a high priority for child care based on the following' . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —What committee was that?
—It was the Children's Services Planning Committee, which apparently gave advice to the Government. The minutes went on to record the following factors:

SPEECH.PARA: -the parliamentary triangle has always been considered a high priority area
-the facility would take pressure off other ACT child care facilities
-the facility should be built as an extended hours service.

There is no information there as to what other centres would have pressure removed. There is no indication as to how the funding for the extended hours service would be provided or whether the funds available for child-care services generally in the ACT would be eaten into. I am sure that I do not need to remind the Minister that two or three years ago the National Library said that it had the space for a child-care facility and wanted to provide one. The difficulty of the Library could have been met by placing a child-care facility there.

We also asked whether the lawns next to the old Parliament House were the only site available for a child-care centre within the Parliamentary Triangle. The supplementary answer lists 15 or 16 places where a child-care centre, if needed, could be placed. That makes it even more intriguing as to why it has to be placed in what I regard as a heritage area, right next to the old Parliament House. I wonder whether the Minister can give us more information to convince us that if there is to be another child-care centre in the ACT it should be in that particular position.

TALK.START.PARA: —One answer to that question is that a few years ago Don Grimes wrote a letter to somebody in which he promised-perhaps `promised' is too strong a word, but it was something close to that-to do so.
—He is not here to defend himself. We could give him the bird for it.
—Senator Puplick can take my word that that happened.
—I am sure it did.
—It was something, I might add, that I was not very happy about.
—The Minister will be in trouble with Senators Giles and Zakharov if he is not careful.

—I have been in trouble there before, I suppose. I have not been particularly worried about it. The question of numbers and so on is now an Australian Capital Territory Administration responsibility. However, I can give some background information. An assessment made by the Department of Community Services and Health and the Department of Finance about two years ago concluded that the unmet demand throughout Australia was some 120,000. `Unmet demand' was defined as demand either from sole parents, or from dual parents already in the work force, who had children below five years of age and who wished to have some child-care facility other than private arrangements such as leaving a child with a grandparent. I do not know whether there was a regional breakdown of that figure, but I think it was assumed that provision of facilities would be fairly uniform, on a pro rata basis throughout the country. When an additional program was announced, providing a total of 3,000 places, if I remember correctly, the Australian Capital Territory got an approximately per capita share.
—Pro rata or per capita?
—What is the difference?
—One is proportional; one is per head.

—The total was 3,000. The Australian Capital Territory has about 2 per cent of the nation's population, so it would get 2 per cent of 3,000, or something close to that. The proposed centre referred to will be part of the Australian Capital Territory allocation of approximately 60 places.

—I thank the Minister for his answer. In a sense, there are two parts to this matter. One concerns the siting of the facility. It is clear from the departmental answer that a number of other situations could have been used.
—That is true. It was a Cabinet decision. There were about 15 possible sites.

—Yes. The other aspect of the matter is whether this is the best means of using Government money to provide child-care for people in genuine need. This facility is going to cost a considerable amount of money to build. The information that I have seen indicates that placing a child in a government centre costs considerably more than in a private centre. In Canberra there are private centres that are extremely well run. As was indicated at the Estimates hearings, they are monitored by the Department, and no one challenges the Department's expertise. These private centres are extremely good. If children in need were placed in private child-care centres and the parents were subsidised, it would be possible to get a lot more children into child-care than I believe is possible in providing for them in the way proposed. Is there no way of using the money to better advantage to ensure that the children who really need child-care so that their mothers can get on with the lives are the ones who get it?

—If this were an Estimates Committee, clearly that would be regarded as a policy question, and there are different views about that. I presume that Senator Reid knows that the Australian Bureau of Statistics has done a survey of commercial or private child-care centres, or whatever she likes to call them. The results, which were published at least a month ago, confirmed at least some of the things that Senator Reid has said. There was factual information about fees and, I think, much less reliable information about the income stratification of the users. For the first time we now have some reliable information about the private or commercial sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to return only briefly, and in summary, to the matters raised by Senator Calvert in relation to the question of the tender for the Antarctic vessel. It is not our intention to detain the Committee overly long this evening or to move that these matters be stood over until such time as Senator Richardson is here to answer. I want simply to draw together some threads arising from what I believe to be the scandalous way in which this tender process has been handled. There are a couple of points to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: First, there appears to be absolutely no doubt that the Commonwealth taxpayer has been required to fork out a far larger sum of money than was necessary, for no reason other than to attempt to bolster the electoral stocks of the Unsworth Government in New South Wales. A tender was specifically directed, channelled, guided, towards the New South Wales shipyards for no bona fide purpose, for no purpose other than to allow the New South Wales Government, under the direction of Mr Unsworth, as it then was, to gain some electoral advantage by claiming that it had secured work for a shipyard in an area which, had the matter been dealt with on a strictly commercial basis, would not have got it. This is simply an example of the extent to which a government was prepared to pervert the proper processes of Australian Government tendering to seek political advantage in that respect.

The second point that arises from it is that the Commonwealth taxpayer, in fact, at the end of the day has to pay a considerably greater sum of money for a vessel than would have been the case had the lowest possible tenderer been selected, and the determination of the Government, for whatever purposes, to secure some local manning and construction of this vessel has been set against the best financial standards which should have been applied to ensure that the Commonwealth received maximum value for dollars expended out of Commonwealth revenues.

The third issue is that letters of intent were clearly sent out. They were signed not by the Minister but by an officer of the Department. Had the Department been entirely forthcoming with us tonight it would have been in a position to indicate to us the name of the officer whose signature appears at the bottom of that letter of intent. We know whose signature appears on that letter. It is not the responsibility of the Opposition to intrude upon the privacy or the personal status of the individual concerned. The opportunity was available for the Government to indicate to us this evening who the officer concerned was. The Government chose not to. We accept the decision made by the Government to choose not to. We know that the Australian Government Solicitor advised that this course of action should not be followed. We know that; the Government could have indicated that but chose not to.

We know that the draft Cabinet submission considered by the Minister on 23 November 1987 indicated, I think the proper words are that the Australian shipyard be selected on a competitive commercial basis. That formulation appeared in the draft Cabinet submission. It did not appear in the final Cabinet submission. The Government was in a position to indicate to us whether in fact that was the case or not the case and the Government chose not to indicate to us what that position was.

We know that, on 9 November 1987, the Minister approved a short list and, contrary to the recommendation of the Antarctic Division, included the first preferred option put to him by Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd (TNT), because it was allegedly the next lowest offer made by an Australian company, and that information needed to be before the Cabinet for the purposes of allowing Cabinet to make its judgments. We know that as a result of the comments made in para 5.76 of the report entitled Review of the Tendering Process for the Antarctic Replacement Vessel.

As to whether in fact that was a genuine attempt to allow Cabinet to make comparisons between Australian tenders and overseas tenders we really do not know. All we know is that the Antarctic Division had recommended that TNT's first option be excluded because it was outside the competitive price range but the Minister, for reasons which have not been adequately explained either to the Estimates Committees or the chamber, insisted that the TNT first option be included in the material that was put before Cabinet for consideration.

We know from the review of the tendering processes for the Antarctic replacement vessel that the review panel found that not all appropriate practices and procedures were observed. I must say that even after the extensive questioning that went on in the Estimates Committee, conducted by Senator Calvert, by Senator Archer and by me, among others, no satisfactory explanation has been provided to the Parliament for what changes have effectively been made to ensure that the gross failures of the Department to observe proper Commonwealth standards in this matter have been adequately rectified or dealt with.

One could go on for a considerable time through this particular unhappy saga. At the end of the day, one is left with several basic premises. The first of them is that the Commonwealth taxpayer is now required to pay a far larger sum of money than was absolutely necessary for the securing of a replacement Antarctic vessel. That results from a series of policy decisions made by the Government. I and the Opposition do not argue with the fact that a Government decision has been made and that a particular course of action should have been preferred over another course of action in relation to the selection of Australian construction and eventual Australian manning of this vessel. But it really does concern me that the process of obtaining that information has been akin to the process of drawing teeth. Instead of being entirely forthcoming with the Estimates Committee and entirely forthcoming with the Parliament with the information that that was a result of a deliberate Cabinet decision or Government policy, one has had to painfully extract that information which could have been given at an early stage. Indeed, had that been made quite clearly known to the Parliament a great deal of the time of both the Estimates Committee and the chamber may well have been saved.

Secondly, there is, to my way of thinking, no satisfactory indication that the deficiencies in the procedure or in the processes indicated by the Review of the Tendering Process for the Antarctic Replacement Vessel have been adequately addressed and that the necessary remedial action has been taken. Thirdly, one is left with a nagging and continuing suspicion that, at the end of the day, considerations about the potential survival of the Unsworth Government were the primary considerations in the mind of the Minister and the Government in this whole process.

Fourthly, and perhaps most regrettably, may I say that, in the consciousness of mind of what I believe will be the senior members of the incoming administration after the next election, the probity and veracity of officers in the Department concerned in this matter is open to a sufficient degree of concern for us undoubtedly to require necessary remedial action if and when we have the opportunity to do so.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

—I apologise if we were distracted in the changeover during the question.

—In my earnest endeavour to provide Senator Walters with the accurate one of those two alternatives, I have delayed my answer. I shall now answer. I ask the Minister for Resources again why it is that a merchant navy man or woman who has seen service is not represented at the inquiry? Can the Minister explain?

—I will explain. I understand that the inquiry is conducted only by Ms McGirr, the Deputy President of the Repatriation Commission.
