TALK.START.PARA: —I gave notice to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) of a number of questions with regard to the services provided to members of Parliament from the Department of Administrative Services. I do not want to detain the Committee if in fact the Minister has those. The questions are as follows: what is the total number of full time equivalent public servants employed in providing support services to members of parliament? What is the average annual overtime earned by electorate assistants? What are the average annual charter costs utilised by honourable members and senators? What is the average amount spent annually on equipping an electorate office? What is the average amount spent annually on maintaining an electorate office? What is the cost per annum of an average lease for an electorate office? What is the average annual cost per electorate office of staff fares, ground transport and travel allowance?

SPEECH.PARA: A short explanation of why I am asking those questions here is that we have been endeavouring for the past three weeks to get this information and we have run up against so many brick walls that I have decided in despair that this is the only place where I may get some answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Macklin. He has just run through the wall. I have all the answers here. I did not realise this was coming on so quickly so I have not been able to go through the courtesy of showing members of the Opposition the answers. They are just standard answers and I seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, 25 MAY 1989
QUESTION-Senator Michael Macklin
What is the total number (full-time equivalent) of public servants in your Department employed in providing support services to Members of Parliament?
ANSWER

Public servants in Government Departments Australia-wide provide support services to their Ministers directly and to the Parliament indirectly. The Department of Administrative Services provides support services to all Senators and Members, Ministers and Opposition Office-holders, former parliamentarians and former Prime Ministers. It also provides support services to staff employed by Senators and Members, Ministers and Opposition Office-holders and former Prime Ministers. In total, 224 sitting Members, some 115 retired members of Parliament and approximately 1,000 staff.

The range of service provided by the Department of Administrative Services involves staff from a number of the Department's programs, some full-time, some part-time. For example staff of the Transport and Storage Group provide car with driver service, Australian Property Group arranges leasing of office accommodation and the Parliamentary and Ministerial Services Group arranges purchasing and payment of accounts in compliance with the Audit Act and Finance Directions.

The Department of Administrative Services has a total staff of some 18,000. Of these approximately 100 staff located in Canberra and the States are employed full time in providing support services to sitting and former parliamentarians and their staff.
COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, 25 MAY 1989
QUESTION-Senator Michael Macklin
What is the average annual overtime earned by electorate assistants?
ANSWER

In 1988/89 it is anticipated that an amount of approximately $1.742m will be spent on overtime payments for Electorate staff. With a total staffing of 667 this amount equates to a pro rata figure of $2,600 per staff member per annum or on average, payment for about 2 hours overtime per week.
COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, 25 MAY 1989
QUESTION-Senator Macklin
What is the average annual charter costs utilised by Members/Senators?
ANSWER

The Remuneration Tribunal has determined that a Senator or Member shall be entitled, at Government expense, to use charter transport within and for the service of the State, Territory or electorate to the annual limit specified. The value of the entitlement is determined by the size of the State or electorate.
For Members the range is between $5,325 and $25,000 per annum with a minimum requirement for an electorate size of 10,000 square kilometres. The average annual cost of the entitlement is $11,160.

For Senators the range is between $5,325 and $20,000 per annum. Senators for the Australian Capital Territory do not receive the entitlement. The average annual cost of the entitlement for Senators is $7,670.
Overall the average annual cost of the charter transport entitlement is $8,853.
COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, 25 MAY 1989
QUESTION-Senator Michael Macklin
What is the average amount spent annually on equipping an electorate office?
ANSWER

The Department of Administrative Services provides office equipment, furniture, general official requisites and stores to electorate offices. Approximately $4m will be expended this financial year in providing those services-an average of $17,800 per electorate office. Expenditure in one year doesn't necessarily mean that the same amount would be spent in the following year. For example, all photocopiers in electorate offices were upgraded this year to provide collating with 20 bin capacity and second workstations are being provided to electorate offices.
COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, 25 MAY 1989
QUESTION-Senator Michael Macklin
What is the average spent annually on maintaining an electorate office?
ANSWER

The cost of maintaining electorate offices, ie postage, telephones, repairs and maintenance to office equipment and furniture and fittings will amount to approximately $3.4m this financial year-an average of $15,000 per electorate office.
COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, 25 MAY 1989
QUESTION-Senator Michael Macklin
What is the cost per annum of an average lease for an electorate office?
ANSWER

Lease costs for electorate offices are dependent on a number of factors. For example, the area of the office, whether within or outside the Central Business District, the location (for example ground floor shop front or above ground floor in an office building), and the demand for leased space in the desired location. Senators and Members have the flexibility within guidelines on area and the availability of reasonably priced space, to determine where their electorate offices are located to best meet their representational responsibilities. Rental is generally between $20,000 and $30,000 per annum. An average lease cost does not provide a meaningful reflection of the discretion Senators and Members are able to exercise in relation to their office.

In addition to separate electorate offices, the Government provides conference and visiting facilities in capital cities to enable Senators and Members to fulfil their parliamentary and electorate duties.
COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, 25 MAY 1989
QUESTION-Senator Michael Macklin
What is the average annual cost per electorate office of staff air fares, ground transport and travel allowance?
ANSWER

Each Senator's and Members' electorate staff travel costs are met from an annual budget. The budget is based on the cost of 15 return air fares to Canberra, 100 days travelling allowance and associated car transport costs. Each budget is therefore specifically designed for the Senator and Member taking into account the distance from the electorate office to Canberra. The total cost of all budgets this financial year is $3,398,000-or an average of $17,520 for each Senator and Member.

An average cost does not however reflect the tailored nature of individual budgets, the flexibility Senators and Members have to determine their staff travel needs and the ability for individual budgets to be adjusted to accommodate extra parliamentary sittings.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Attorney-General's Department
Proposed expenditure, $28,771,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 May this year I gave notice of a motion with regard to a cost of justice inquiry. As honourable senators will remember, two days later the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was successful in having a motion carried with regard to a reference on the cost of justice inquiry. While that was somewhat narrower than the one I have been consulting on for some 18 months with members of community groups and the legal profession, I still give that inquiry my wholehearted support because it deals with an issue which is becoming of ever-increasing urgency in the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I want to raise one issue, and that is with regard to community legal services. As honourable senators are aware, the ability of community legal centres to meet community needs is being severely compromised by their inability to obtain adequate funding. These important community service organisations are now struggling to maintain the high level of service that they have traditionally supplied. I hardly need stress that these services promote social equity and justice; yet they are being neglected at the moment by a government whose policy professes a commitment to equity and justice. It is hoped that by the time that that inquiry finishes we will have a very clear and unequivocal case for rapidly increasing the funding of these centres. These centres play a vital role in giving support to many people-particularly people without a regular income or with low incomes or people in economic difficulties for one reason or another-who find it necessary to be involved with legal services. But in the meantime, it seems to me that these centres are in fact being deprived more and more of their ability to play that role. The quality of the services provided by the community legal centres is high and they are highly cost-effective due to the level of volunteer involvement.

The cost benefit argument can be added, of course, to the arguments that I have already made concerning social justice and equity, that volunteer involvement exists only because some funds are provided. If the funds are cut, there will be no avenue for that volunteer involvement. As in so many other areas, as the Government realises, government dollars are amplified enormously when there is volunteer involvement and some government moneys. Honourable senators are well aware, of course, that there are a large number of these organisations. I do not want to run through them all, but every State has a number of them and they have worked extremely well over the years in providing that type of service.

My question to the Government is: in terms of the provision of legal services to the community via these community legal centres, is it the Government's intention to continue to starve these centres of adequate funds, or does the Government actually have some long-term suggestions with regard to funding that it wishes to make on this matter? I think that unless there is a basic and firm funding commitment from the Government, much of the good work that has been done to date in establishing these centres and keeping them running in that mixture of paid and voluntary work will have been lost, and it will be almost impossible to recreate these centres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Macklin for the question, because it evinces an interest in an aspect of the provision of legal aid in the Australian community which I regard as extremely important; that is legal aid provided through community legal centres, as opposed to the State legal aid commissions which exist in every jurisdiction except the Northern Territory and Tasmania where Australian legal aid offices provide Federal funding for legal aid.

SPEECH.PARA: The community legal centres have in fact fared as well as they might realistically have hoped in the last couple of years in that their appropriation in real terms has been maintained at a time when many other areas of the portfolio were being cut back. Indeed, I have been concerned to ensure that at least that funding is maintained in real terms. Only today I sent out letters to all States and to every community legal centre in Australia indicating the provision of, I think, $2,517,000. I will later have incorporated in Hansard a table of the individual grants to each community legal centre. I agree that all that has been achieved is that we have maintained in real terms the funding for these centres. But, as I say, in this current period that represents some modest achievement.

It has been impossible to secure funding for new centres. Although we did receive several letters and representations from members and senators pleading that that be done in certain instances, we thought it best to consolidate those centres that were already offering services and had built up an established network. I say `network' because, as Senator Macklin quite rightly observed, one of the great virtues of community legal centres is their ability to attract, in addition to the work performed by salaried persons within the community legal centres, contributions of very high quality and calibre from practitioners and other persons who come in-perhaps for two or three hours once very fortnight, but in any case on a regular basis-and deal with clients who seek advice. So the $2.5m that we expend is multiplied, amplified and supplemented many times so that the dollar value of the services provided far exceeds the approximately $2.5m that the Commonwealth puts in.

I think that is about all I can say in regard to community legal centres. I recognise their important place in the provision of legal aid. I think they are to have their annual meeting in Maroochydore on the Gold Coast on the Queen's birthday weekend, whenever that happy event falls.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 12 June.

—The monarchist at the table tells me it is on 12 June. I am sure that they will send out resolutions from that meeting for me to consider. I must say that I wrote to them a couple of days ago indicating that a small grant of $4,000 would be made available to them to help them with the National Legal Aid Advisory Committee's work in relation to aspects of the provision of legal aid in Australia so that their Executive can compile a response and submission to that Advisory Committee. Mr Temporary Chairman, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the 1989-90 community legal centre funding program, State by State and centre by centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a couple of questions or points in relation to the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC). I want to draw the Senate's attention to the comments that were made in the report of Estimates Committee E, because I think they are important not just in relation to the Attorney-General's Department but also in relation to the conduct of Estimates committee hearings. In the report of Estimates Committee E we expressed concern that the NCSC was not represented at the hearings of the Estimates Committee. We had given advance notice to the Department that questions would be directed to the NCSC and, therefore, we quite reasonably expected that there would have been at least a representative of the NCSC at the Senate Estimates committee hearings. Of course, that was not the case. Therefore, we had to make do-with all due respect to the officers of the Attorney-General's Department-with officers of the Department.
—Would you like me to answer before 10.30? I get the gist of your complaint.

—Yes, I think it is an important point that ought to be made and ought to be taken note of by the Government because if we are to treat the hearings of the Estimates committees seriously, as I think we all want to, this point requires consideration.

—As I understand it, officers of the Attorney-General's Department did invite the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) to send up a representative from Melbourne. That organisation indicated that it had some other priorities and felt that perhaps the officers of the Department could deal with the matter. I regret very much that it proved on the occasion of the Estimates Committee meeting that that was not the case. I am distressed that the Committee found it necessary, through Senator Durack, to put so many questions on notice. I believe that they have been answered adequately. I approached Senator Durack in the corridor a couple of days ago to ask whether he wanted somebody from the National Companies and Securities Commission to be here for the Committee of the Whole debate. He indicated that he did not require that. I apologise to the Committee for that, and I will make sure it does not happen again.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Our Homeless Children-Department of Defence Employee: Protective Clothing-End of War List-Annual Reports

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to the report of the National Inquiry into Homeless Children by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission called Our Homeless Children. The reason I wish to do so is that I have received from the Weston Creek Community Service a very detailed response to that report. I hope that those considering the report of the Human Rights Commission will look at this very closely, together with the other submissions they receive. I will not go through the response in detail, but the Service comes to the following conclusion:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that there are young homeless people living in our communities should be of enormous and grave concern to everyone. In responding to this very significant report on ``Our Homeless Children'', the Weston Creek Community Service has registered its concern and its willingness to do what is necessary to alleviate youth homelessness in Weston Creek in Canberra.
It refers particularly to the recommendations, but I want to refer to their comment in relation to recommendation 20.3. It is a comment that I particularly wish to endorse. It reads:

The Weston Creek Community Service believes very strongly that non-government agencies are better accepted by the community in supporting families under stress and reiterates that its current level of family support funding is insufficient to meet current community needs.

There are very positive suggestions throughout this report in relation to the recommendations of the Human Rights Commission, but I think there is a very real place in this area for groups such as the Weston Creek Community Service, as a non-government agency, to be involved. Earlier today I showed to the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) the introduction to the report. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the first two pages of this report, which I commend to those who will be responding on behalf of the Government.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
RESPONSE TO ``OUR HOMELESS CHILDREN'': REPORT OF THE NATIONAL INQUIRY INTO HOMELESS CHILDREN BY THE HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION BY WESTON CREEK COMMUNITY SERVICE.
The Weston Creek Community Service agrees with the Commission in its adoption of the South Australian Council of Social Services definition of homelessness as being:
``for homelessness to exist, at least one of the following conditions should be operative:
(a) an absence of shelter;
(b) the threat of loss of shelter;
(c) very high mobility between places of abode;

(d) existing accommodation considered inadequate by the resident for reasons such as overcrowding, the physical state of the residence, lack of security of occupancy or lack of emotional support and stability in the place of residence;
(e) unreasonable restrictions in terms of access to alternative forms of accommodation.''
We believe that it is essential that homelessness as it relates to young people be discussed in its widest context to enable a comprehensive and sensitive response to be made to the problem.

The Weston Creek Community Service believes that it is totally unacceptable for the community to allow the problem of youth homelessness to continue unchecked and we are keen to do what we can to alleviate youth homelessness in Weston Creek in Canberra.

We agree with the Commission in that failure to address the problem of youth homelessness results in costs to the individual and costs to the community. The costs to the individual, as identified in the report, are considerable; financial costs, social isolation costs, psychological injuries costs, health costs, drug and alcohol costs, prostitution costs, disrupted education costs and disrupted employment costs. The costs to the community, as identified in the report, are also considerable in government outlay costs and costs related to crime in the community. The Weston Creek Community Service strongly believes that a perceived lack of current financial resources is no excuse for government failure to address the youth homelessness problem as a matter of urgency.

We support the ``Declaration of the Rights of the Child'' which states ``that all children have a right to enjoy special protection, to receive adequate housing and to be protected against all forms of neglect, cruelty and exploitation.''
The comprehensive response needed to youth homelessness as indicated earlier must be rapid, sensitive and appropriate to the differing needs of young homeless people.

We must respond appropriately to young people who leave home for short periods to ``cool off''. We must respond appropriately to young people who need only minimum support by ensuring they have enough financial support and a number of housing options available to them.

We must also respond appropriately to the chronically homeless, those who share a profound alienation from society, and respond sensitively to each individual on the basis of their age, intellectual disability, emotional disturbance, poor education, inadequate living skills, extensive poverty or combinations of these.

We know in the Australian Capital Territory that there are at least 50-60 young people homeless each night and we also know from the report that the youth workers in our community are perceived by young people as trusting and supportive. We need to encourage our young people to seek out our youth workers for assistance when they become homeless and when they are thinking of leaving home.

The Weston Creek Community Service acknowledges that young people leave home when their families are under stress, and agree with the Commission that insufficient funds are currently spent on family support services and preventative programs aimed at families under stress. We know already that our level of family support funding at Weston Creek is totally inadequate to meet the needs of the community we serve. We also acknowledge that family poverty and isolation are important factors in young people leaving home and urge the Federal Government to ensure that all individuals and families have an adequate income to enable them to properly function in our community.

Before examining the Commission's recommendations in detail, it remains to be said that we agree with the Commission that the number of crisis refuges currently in existence appears to be adequate, that more medium and long term accommodation for young people is desperately needed and that accommodation needs to be different for 13-18 year olds and 18-25 year olds, respectively, according to their different needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise another matter. It is a story I find quite appalling and one I can hardly believe, but I can only present it to the Senate as it has been given to me. I read from a letter which has been written from a constituent to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons). The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: I am writing to you as an employee of the Department of Defence and Taxpayer. I am employed as a Senior Storeman at the Fyshwick Bulk Store of the Department. An incident happened on Thursday 18 and Friday 19th May which caused me great concern and extremely upset me.

Due to a recurring chest complaint and recent respiratory infection the week before (on sick leave for 4 days), I was wearing a personally owned jumper to help recover from my infection and was told by the Executive Officer of Stores to ``take off my jumper'', as according to Stores' regulations I was out of uniform for wearing the jumper as an outer garment. I have been supplied with a jacket which is regulation issue but it fails to keep my chest warm and is cumbersome for me to carry out many of my duties . . . I refused to remove my jumper on explanation of my illness, and was informed that I would be on leave without pay if I did not. At 9.30 a.m. I was advised by the Stores Manager under instruction from the Executive Officer of Stores that I was indeed on leave without pay. I telephoned Senior Executive Officer of Transport and Stores to request that I could leave my jumper on, and was advised no. As I was quite adamant that I should be allowed to wear it, considering my illness, I continued to refuse to remove it. I remained at work and continued my duties for the day.
It gets worse:

On Friday 19th May, I was issued a Minute from the Stores Manager under instruction from the Executive Stores Officer that confirmed the previous days action, i.e. on leave without pay . . . I contacted Branch Staff Cell to ask for a telephone number for Civil Personnel, and was told that I was not allowed to talk to Personnel, I had to go through them. I explained the previous days events and they said that they would investigate the matter. I did however contact Civil Personnel myself and they too said they would investigate the matter. I have in support of this letter, copies of correspondence from my doctor and my mother confirming my health problems, and would ask that you find the time to investigate this matter.

I have in my possession a copy of a letter from the man's doctor confirming a recurrent respiratory infection and his need to take steps to keep himself warm and well. I also have a confirmatory letter from the man's mother. I have what might be regarded as a remarkable document which is a copy of a minute paper, headed `Subject: Protective Clothing', and directed to my constituent. It reads, in part:
You are advised that as at 0930 hours 18 May 1989 you were on leave without pay until 1651 hours 18 May 1989.

I find it hard to believe that such a thing could happen when we are talking about productivity and people attempting to do their work and to be a part of the community. It may well be that the clothing issued is not adequate for this climate and that there should be regulation jumpers, if jumpers are in fact required in that area. The jackets may not be adequate. A situation where a man has been off work sick with respiratory problems for four days and is then faced with this sort of petty bureaucracy is something that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel should look into as a matter of urgency. I hope that his representative in this chamber will report back to the Senate equally as a matter of urgency. I will be very disappointed indeed, to put it very mildly, if this man suffers the consequence of leave without pay for that one day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to a question that I asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) today in Question Time in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. The question I asked was in reference to the establishment of an end of war list. I asked the Minister whether he would approve a request for an end of war list. I wish to reverse a perception that he gave in his answer. The perception would be that the decision of the Minister for Defence in the McMahon Government, Mr Fairbairn, to reject the establishment of an end of war list was endorsed or carried on by the Minister for Defence in the Whitlam Government, Lance Barnard, for the same reasons. However, following a freedom of information request, I have received documents which I believe reject that sort of perception.

SPEECH.PARA: The decisions made by Mr Fairbairn and Mr Barnard were made for different reasons. Minister Fairbairn's decision followed a request by the Australian Army, the Royal Australian Navy and the Royal Australian Air Force to establish an end of war list. Mr Fairbairn rejected the establishment of an end of war list on the grounds that the hostilities in Vietnam were still going on and that Australian troops were still in South East Asia. However, he did not rule out the establishment of an end of war list in the future. A request was also directed by the three armed services to Mr Barnard. His reasons for rejecting the establishment of an end of war list were different from Mr Fairbairn's because the troops were back from the Vietnam war zone. The Minister rejected the proposal on the grounds that it would be seen to be celebrating the war. What I thought of that reason I dealt with in my second reading speech. It was purely a political decision by Lance Barnard and was in no way, I believe, fairly based. But above all, unlike Mr Fairbairn, Lance Barnard completely ruled out the chance of an end of war list. So the Fairbairn and Barnard decisions were different. They were different men, from a different time in politics and, above all, they had different reasons to reject the end of war list. So I ask the Minister to reconsider the answer that he gave today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise the matter of the annual reports of two Commonwealth bodies. I do so because it is now evident that there will be no other opportunity for the Senate to discuss before it rises the still considerable list of annual reports that remain undealt with. I wish to discuss these two reports because they are added to the list of indefensibly late reports covering the period ended 30 June last year. For the benefit of honourable senators who are not aware of it, it is now May; it is almost a year later that we are eventually getting these annual reports. The standard of Commonwealth reporting is still appalling, particularly in the matter of time.

SPEECH.PARA: For example, in the annual report of the Attorney-General on the Operation of the Bankruptcy Act 1966, we have a statement from the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) expressing great pleasure in presenting the report, without bothering to put a date on it. So the report of the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy has no date on it whatsoever. One wonders whether the delay is due to printing problems or simple bureaucratic delays, but late reporting is bad reporting. The annual report of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation at least has a date on it, December 1988. Why on earth did it take until May 1989 for a report presented to Mr Peter Morris, the Minister for Industrial Relations, to come to this chamber? We are accustomed to being dealt with with contempt by this Government, which apparently does not like the inconvenience of having to have its reports discussed in a timely and proper way.

As I said, we do not get the opportunity to discuss these very significant reports in this place unless we raise them during the adjournment debate. The Government brings them in here, in this case 11 months after the end of the financial year, as some kind of gratuitous insult to this chamber. As both of them contain matters of some significance, I would have hoped that the Government would try to do a little better. For example, it should try to do as well as it requires public companies to do. If public companies reported as belatedly and incompetently as this lot, they would be fined, their executives would be in gaol and the companies would be delisted from the stock exchange. We can bring no sanctions against those like Mr Peter Morris, MP, who has apparently been sitting on this report, or doing something else with it-heaven knows what-since December 1988, before getting around to presenting it to this chamber.

I would like to raise some matters in the annual report of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation to dramatise the magnificent impact the former Waste Watch Committee, which I chaired, has managed to have on the level of payments under the Commissioner, and the way the exposing by that Committee of the rip-offs and rorts that were going on has brought about a significant improvement by reducing the level of wasted money. This report reveals:
For the second year in succession, expenditure on worker's compensation declined in real terms. The incidence rate of new claims per thousand employees covered fell to its lowest level in a decade.

If the Minister, in his summing up, is prepared to say thank you to the Waste Watch Committee, I am prepared to accept his grateful thanks at a time when the Government is being enjoined to reduce its expenditure, particularly to limit its wasteful expenditure. However, the report says:

Despite the overall reduction in continuing cases there was a further increase in long term cases from 9,351 in 1986-87 to 10,041 in 1987-88. This rise of 7.4 per cent implies that adequate attention has not been given to rehabilitation and redeployment needs of long term compensation recipients.

Quite frankly I hope that the new arrangements that the Government has entered into-because this is after all the last report for the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation-will involve a much better and much more coherent approach to the rehabilitation and deployment needs of long term compensation recipients, because this is just a waste of a human resource, involving with it a waste of money. As I said, the Government must be commended for responding to the Waste Watch Committee. We see that the report reveals:
The average incidence rate for 1987-88 is 59.9 per thousand employees covered.

That is about 6 per cent of the workers compensation rate. By the way, I understand that is about double the great bulk of the private sector-the more clerical ends of the private sector, not those industrial ends where unfortunately the workers compensation rate is much higher-but it is nowhere near as bad as the previous incidence rate. The rate in the latest year of 59.9 per thousand is certainly far better than the previous year's rate of 71.3 per thousand.

There are still other matters of concern because, as the Waste Watch Committee found, Victoria still has this extraordinary incidence of workers compensation requirements in the Commonwealth Public Service and Commonwealth agencies. It has the highest expenditure and has 31 per cent more long-term cases than New South Wales, even though Victoria has only 72 per cent of the number of employees that New South Wales has. I do not know whether this is because of some sweetheart deal done with some Victorian doctors, whether it is because of the football they play or whether it is the climate. Whatever it is, there is some basic continuing problem which must be addressed. We have the same problem in South Australia, which has double the rate of incidence of new cases in the Australian Capital Territory, which really requires some explanation.

There is still a curious variation between the incidence of workers compensation claims of various departments and government organisations. For example, it seems to me that there are an extraordinarily large number of claims in the Office of Defence Production. The Government is making changes in the structure of Defence Production, and not before time. The Williamstown Dockyard has an incidence rate of about 35 per cent of workers compensation claims among employees. That is a rate of 350 per thousand employees. That is simply unsustainable; it is incredible. When we look at other Office of Defence Production areas we find, for example, that in the Garden Island Dockyard the incidence of workers compensation among the work force is 27.5 per cent; at the Mulwala Explosives Factory the incidence is 32.4 per cent; at the Maribyrnong Ordnance Factory the incidence is 25.5 per cent and at the Small Arms Factory in Lithgow the incidence is 18.3 per cent. Yet when we look at the figures for the Department of Defence, we find that there is only a 3 per cent incidence among the defence forces. In other words, as I made the point when I was Chairman of the Waste Watch Committee, it is something like 10 times riskier, at least in terms of workers compensation, to work in a defence factory than it is to be in the defence forces. That seems to me to be absolutely ludicrous. Either it means that there is an extraordinary risk variation or, more likely, there is a far greater willingness to find accommodating doctors or extraordinarily bad work practices in that area. This ratio of workers compensation days is also excessively larger that the Australian National Railways Commission where the incidence rate is 21 per cent.

I would like to deal very briefly with the annual report by the Attorney-General on the operation of the Bankruptcy Act 1966. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that according to this report in the latest year there has been a 12.8 per cent increase in the total number of bankruptcies and orders for administration in Australia under this Government. This means that there were 8,124 bankruptcies in the latest financial year. This is an increase of something like 58 per cent since the Fraser Government's last year in office, which was massively drought affected. Many people went bankrupt because of the impact of the worst drought for about 50 years. This Government's bankruptcy level is four times the average under the Whitlam Government. Everyone knows what a disaster the Whitlam Government was, but to think that this is four times as much is absolutely incredible. Liabilities amounted to something like $511m and were covered by assets of only $62m, involving not only a massive economic cost but a large social cost as well.

I say once again, very briefly, that it is extraordinary to notice the disastrous level of people not engaged in remunerative employment who end up as personal bankrupts. It is extraordinary that 4,400 people were not engaged in any work yet were able to go into debt to such an extent that they became bankrupt, either suggesting there is an excessive level of selling of debt or people are behaving in an extraordinarily reckless way.

I conclude by saying that there is also an extraordinary variation between the States in bankruptcy experience. Queensland and South Australia are extraordinary. In Queensland something like three times the number of business bankruptcies took place as took place in Victoria. In South Australia the amount was double. It seems to me that there is a very sound case for a far greater examination of the reasons why this Government has created an environment in which bankruptcies are four times the Whitlam average. This annual report in itself condemns this Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.54 p.m.
